questions.text: A mother died after an illegal abortion. The section of IPC under which a doctor could be prosecuted:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IPC 314:

  • According to 314 IPC, doctors could be prosecuted if the female died after an illegal abortion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IPC 312: 312 IPC states that a doctor can be prosecuted for criminal abortion even if consent is taken.

Option C - IPC 315: Killing child or foetus about >28 weeks of gestation..

Option D - IPC 318: Concealment of birth..

questions.text: A 39-year-old HIV-positive male patient presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. His latest CD4 count is measured to be 420/mm3. He is currently asymptomatic. At what CD4 count should prophylaxis against Pneumocystis carinii infection be initiated according to current guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Start when the CD4 < 350/mm3:

  • Prophylaxis of opportunistic infection: Pneumocystis carinii (also known as pneumocystis jiroveci)
  • One double strength tablet = 800mg sulfamethoxazole + 160 mg trimethoprim
  • Start when the CD4 < 350/mm3
  • Stop when the CD4 >350/mm3 on two occasions six months apart + ascending trend of CD4 + no WHO stage 3 and 4

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman came with complaints of swallowing difficulties, dysarthria, fluctuating limb muscle weakness, and bilateral eyelid ptosis with incomplete occlusion. The symptoms decreased with rest and sleep. On examination, there was asymmetrical bilateral eyelid ptosis, unequal palpebral fissures with incomplete occlusion, limitation of facial movements and dysphagia. A neostigmine test was done with the improvement of symptoms post-injection. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease described here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors

  • The given clinical features and examination findings point out this as a case of Myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease caused by a defect of neuromuscular transmission due to an antibody-mediated attack on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors or muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK) receptors at the postsynaptic neuromuscular junction.
  • It is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability. Myasthenia is improved by acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or immunosuppressants, and in selected cases, thymectomy can be performed.
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria are two of the common symptoms and are due to oropharyngeal muscle involvement. They can be the first symptoms of the disease and sometimes can be misdiagnosed as emotional problems, usually depression.

Option A: Mutation in ryanodine receptors

  • Mutation in ryanodine receptors causes a rare, life-threatening condition called malignant hyperthermia, in which inhaled anaesthetics or succinylcholine induce severe muscle contractions and hyperthermia. 
  • Susceptibility is often inherited as autosomal dominant with variable penetrance.
  • Mutations in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) cause Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.            
  • The treatment is dantrolene (a ryanodine receptor antagonist)

Option C: Autoantibodies against synaptobrevin

  • Synaptobrevin (VAMP) is an integral membrane protein of synaptic vesicles that plays a major role in the formation of larger SNARE complexes, along with SNAP-25 and syntaxin. 
  • Synaptobrevin has been shown to be essential for two fast synapse-specific membrane trafficking processes: fast exocytosis for neurotransmitter release and fast endocytosis that mediates the rapid recycling of synaptic vesicles. 
  • Decreased levels of synaptobrevin in the human hippocampus and cortex have been correlated with cognitive defects in Alzheimer’s disease.

Option D: Autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channel.

  • Autoantibodies to presynaptic Ca2+ channel.
  • Calcium influx causes acetylcholine (ACh) release
  • Characterized by proximal muscle weakness, autonomic symptoms (dry mouth, constipation, impotence) and hyporeflexia.
  • Weakness improves with muscle use.
  • It may be the paraneoplastic syndrome of small-cell lung cancer
  • Administration of acetylcholine esterase inhibitors has minimal improvement

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of frequency, urgency and a sense of incomplete evacuation for 1 year. She is non-diabetic. Her past ultrasounds, urine examination, and high vaginal swab cultures have no pathology. On pelvic examination, there is no significant vaginal discharge. Cystoscopy is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided, the most probable diagnosis is

Option A. Urethral syndrome (also known as Frequency-Dysuria Syndrome).

Urethral syndrome is characterized by symptoms of frequency, urgency, and dysuria without evidence of urinary tract infection (UTI) or any other obvious pathology. It occurs more commonly in women and is often associated with irritation or inflammation of the urethra. Urethral syndrome can present with symptoms similar to UTI but without the presence of bacteria in the urine (as seen in urine examination) and with a normal cystoscopy, ruling out bladder or urethral abnormalities.

Let's briefly discuss the other options:

Option B. Asymptomatic bacteriuria: This condition is characterized by the presence of bacteria in the urine without symptoms of a urinary tract infection. Since the patient is symptomatic, asymptomatic bacteriuria is not the correct diagnosis.

Option C. Vulvovaginitis: Vulvovaginal infections can cause symptoms like vaginal discharge, itching, and discomfort, but they typically do not present with urinary symptoms such as frequency, urgency, and incomplete evacuation. The absence of significant vaginal discharge and normal high vaginal swab cultures make vulvovaginitis less likely in this case.

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder and usually presents with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain. However, in cystitis, the symptoms are more consistent with lower urinary tract infection, which typically involves the bladder. The absence of significant vaginal discharge and normal cystoscopy make cystitis less likely in this case.

Given the absence of significant findings in the tests and examinations mentioned, urethral syndrome is the most probable diagnosis. However, it's important for the patient to consult a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain upon exertion for one week. The pain is associated with palpitations and sweating and is not relieved with rest. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes controlled with metformin, and asthma, for which he occasionally uses a salbutamol inhaler.His ECG is shown in the image below; his cardiac enzymes were within normal limits. He was admitted to the CCU for further evaluation. Therapy with a maximal tolerable dose of amiodarone was only partially successful. Which of the following drugs could be useful in treating the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ivabradine

  • The ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with no visible P waves is diagnostic of supraventricular tachycardia. This increase in heart rate is the main cause of the patient's symptoms, e.g. chest pain and palpitations.
  • Calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are commonly used in the treatment of angina; however, as the patient is asthmatic, beta blockers are contraindicated. And since the maximum tolerable dose of amiodarone was not effective, ivabradine is the next most suitable option.
  • Ivabradine selectively inhibits hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels (HCN-4 channels) present in the SA node. These HCN channels normally generate funny currents which are responsible for spontaneous depolarization during phase 4 of cardiac action potential. Ivabradine reduces heart rate by inhibiting these channels thereby inhibiting the funny currents and slowing the heart rate
  • Reducing the heart rate decreases cardiac oxygen demand and prolongs diastole, which improves myocardial perfusion and oxygen supply.

Option A: Propranolol

  • Although beta blockers are routinely used in the treatment of unstable angina and NSTEMI, they are contradicted in asthmatics.
  • When used, cardioselective blockers, e.g., atenolol, and metoprolol, are preferred over non-selective blockers, e.g., propranolol, as the latter may worsen angina by unopposed alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction.

Option C: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is a positive inotropic agent that causes a dose-dependent increase in cardiac contraction.
  • It is indicated in the treatment of certain supraventricular tachycardias, e.g., chronic atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation, when accompanied by heart failure.
  • CCBs, beta blockers and ivabradine are safer, much more effective options.

Option D: Aspirin

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX1 and COX2 decreasing the formation of thromboxane A2- a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator. Aspirin acts as an anti-platelet agent. It also has analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties.
  • It is contraindicated in asthma, bleeding, renal disease and peptic ulcers.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient with a family history of glaucoma undergoes visual field testing using an instrument as shown in the provided image. Which procedure is being carried out in the given image and which statement is true about it?




	Lester perimetry and sensitivity is directly proportional to luminescence
	Humphrey field analyser and sensitivity is directly proportional to luminescence
	Humphrey field analyser and sensitivity is maximum at fovea i.e., can be upto 39-40 dB
	Humphrey field analyser and sensitivity are inversely proportional to luminescence
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 3 and 4:

Statements: The procedure being carried out is a Humphrey field analyser a test to asses the visual field of the patient

  1. Lester perimetry and sensitivity is directly proportional to luminescence: This statement is incorrect because the test being conducted is by Humphrey field analyser, not Lester perimetry.
  2. Humphrey Field Analyzer and sensitivity is directly proportional to luminescence: This is inaccurate, as increased luminescence allows for less detection of visual field defects.
  3. Humphrey Field Analyzer and sensitivity is maximum at the fovea, i.e., can be up to 39-40 dB: This statement is accurate. Sensitivity is typically highest at the fovea.
  4. Humphrey Field Analyzer and sensitivity is inversely proportional to luminescence: This statement is accurate; sensitivity is generally indirectly proportional to luminescence.

So, the correct option is C containing both the correct statement 3 and 4.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: How does the submucosal tissue in the larynx compare between adults and infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: More in infants

  • The submucosal tissue is more prominent in infants compared to adults.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep. The symptoms have been present for the past 4 days and are not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Hypomania

  • The patient's presentation of an elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep lasting for more than 4 days suggests hypomania. Hypomania is a milder form of mania and is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning.

  • Criteria

    Mania

    Hypomania

    Duration

    At least one week

    At least four consecutive days

    Severity

    Severe impairment in functioning and may need hospitalization

    Less severe than mania, no psychotic features

    Impairment

    Often requires hospitalization or is disruptive to daily life

    Typically less severe and less disruptive to daily life

    Symptoms

    Exaggerated elevation in mood

    Elevated mood, increased activity

    Energy

    Highly energetic, excessive

    Increased but manageable

    Risky Behavior

    Pronounced and risky behavior

    Risk-taking behavior, but less extreme

    Psychotic Features

    Often present (hallucinations, delusions)

    Absent

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Major depressive disorder: The patient does not exhibit symptoms of a major depressive episode. Major depressive disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest or pleasure in activities. The scenario describes an elevated mood, which is inconsistent with a major depressive episode.

Option C - Generalized anxiety disorder: The patient's symptoms are not indicative of generalized anxiety disorder. Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive worry and anxiety about various events or activities, whereas the scenario describes an elevated mood and increased energy.

Option D - Borderline personality disorder: The patient's symptoms are more indicative of a mood disorder (hypomania) rather than a personality disorder. Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable moods, impulsivity, and difficulties with interpersonal relationships.

questions.text:
Below is an image of a sports injury with a direct blow to the knee involving a positive gravity sign. Select the correct statements regarding the most likely diagnosis and the most common structure involved



a) Sag sign is positive in this injury
b) Hamstrings are the primary restraint to posterior tibial translation
c) It is stronger and thicker than the other cruciate ligament
d) X-ray is the investigation of choice
e) Quadriceps tendon-bone graft is involved in the treatment.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- a,c,e:

The image shows a direct blow to the posterior part of the tibia injuring the posterior cruciate ligament.

  • Sag sign is positive in this injury
  • It is stronger and thicker than the anterior cruciate ligament
  • Quadriceps tendon-bone graft is involved in the treatment.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- a,b,d:

  • PCL is the primary restraint to posterior tibial translation, not hamstrings.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice, not X-RAY

Option B- c,b,d: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

Option C- b,c,e: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

questions.text: Which of the following drug use is not associated with gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sulfonamides:

  • Sulfonamides are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit bacterial folate synthesis.
  • Side effects of sulfonamide use include diarrhoea, nausea, dizziness, pruritis and hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Sulfonamides are not known to cause gynecomastia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cimetidine:

  • Cimetidine is an H2 histamine antagonist used to treat gastric acidity.
  • It can cause breast enlargement along with headache, diarrhea, dizziness, and drowsiness.

Option B - Spironolactone:

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic linked to gynecomastia.
  • Other side effects include cramps, dizziness, lightheadedness, and diarrhea.

Option C - Digoxin:

  • Digoxin treats atrial fibrillation and heart failure but may cause breast enlargement due to estrogen receptor effects.
  • Other side effects include arrhythmias, photophobia, and vision changes.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lactating mother visits the community health center for contraception counseling. She is exclusively breastfeeding her 4-month-old infant. She wants to use a reliable contraceptive for birth control. Which of the following is the most preferable method of contraception during lactation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Copper-T:

  • The most preferable OCP during lactation is Copper-T IUD.
  • It is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that does not interfere with breast milk production.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D, which are oral contraceptive pills containing estrogen and/or progesterone, are generally not recommended during lactation due to concerns about their potential effects on milk supply and composition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was brought in with complaints of postural instability. Post examination, you confirm that it has nothing to do with vertigo and suspect it could be of cerebellar origin. Which of the following symptoms cannot be seen in cerebellar lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Resting tremors:

  • Resting tremor is the manifestation of basal ganglia disorders like Parkinsonism.
  • In cerebellar lesions, intentional tremors are seen.
Feature Resting Tremors Intentional Tremors
Definition Tremors that occur when muscles are at rest and completely supported against gravity. Tremors that occur during voluntary movement or intentional actions.
Characteristics Typically present in conditions like Parkinson's disease. Characterized by a rhythmic, oscillatory movement. Tremors are often associated with conditions such as essential tremors or cerebellar disorders. They are usually more noticeable during specific tasks or movements.
Trigger Often exacerbated by stress or emotional factors. Typically triggered or worsened by movement or purposeful actions.
Frequency Generally occurs at a frequency of 4-6 Hz. The frequency may vary depending on the task or movement being performed.
Location Commonly affects hands, fingers, forearms, jaw, and lips. It can affect various body parts depending on the task, but it often affects hands and arms.
Progression Tends to worsen over time as the underlying condition progresses. May remain stable or worsen with age, depending on the underlying cause.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ataxia:

  • Due to injury to the spinocerebellar tract [anterior lobe]
  • Uncoordinated clumsy movements
    • Not able to walk in a straight line [loss of coordination]
    • Keep falling towards the side of the lesion

Option B - Nystagmus:

  • Nystagmus refers to a disorder that results in involuntary eye movements
  • It can cause damage to the cerebellum
  • Can be caused by stroke or tumor in the cerebellum

Option D - Past pointing:

  • The patient is asked to point/touch the target direction while the eyes closed.
  • The inability to do so refers to damage to the cerebellum.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male with congenital achalasia cardia underwent transabdominal esophagomyotomies, but dysphagia was not relieved, for which he underwent oesophagal dilatation. But dysphagia is still not relieved as the patient developed oesophagal perforation. Which of the following is the most common cause of Esophageal perforation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Iatrogenic

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette has oesophagal perforation caused during balloon dilation.
  • The most common cause of oesophagal perforation is Iatrogenic.
  • Signs and symptoms of oesophagal perforation
    • Chest and abdominal pain
    • Fever
    • Vomiting
    • Hematemesis
    • Shock
    • Subcutaneous emphysema

Causes:

  • The most common is iatrogenic, usually caused during endoscopy or balloon dilation of the oesophagus, as in this patient.
  • Other causes include acid/alkali ingestion, trauma to the chest, and violent vomiting.

Option A: Mallory Weiss syndrome

  • The most common oesophagal lacerations are Mallory- Weiss tears, often induced by severe retching or vomiting.
  • It does not cause perforation.

Option B: Borehave syndrome

  • It can cause lacerations extending from the mucosa to the muscularis layer.
  • It occurs after violent vomiting.
  • It can sometimes cause oesophagal perforation but is not the commonest cause.

Option D: Esophageal varices

  • Varices do not cause oesophagal perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the rotator cuff?

choices.text: Teres major is one of its four constituent muscles.
The suprascapular nerve innervates the infraspinatus.
Part of its action is to pull the humeral head superiorly.
Subscapularis inserts onto the greater tuberosity of the humerus.

questions.solution:
Option B: The suprascapular nerve innervates the infraspinatus.

  • A rotator cuff is a group of muscles in the shoulder that allow a wide range of movement while maintaining the stability of the glenohumeral joint. The rotator cuff includes the following muscles. 
    • Subscapularis
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Supraspinatus
  • The primary biomechanical role of the rotator cuff is to stabilize the glenohumeral joint by compressing the humeral head against the glenoid. These four muscles arise from the scapula and insert into the humerus.
  • The subscapular nerve (upper and lower branches) innervates the subscapularis muscle. 
  • The suprascapular nerve innervates the infraspinatus and supraspinatus.
  • The axillary nerve innervates teres minor.

Supraspinatus

Greater tuberosity

Infraspinatus

Greater tuberosity

Teres minor

Greater tuberosity

Subscapularis

Lesser tuberosity

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Teres major is one of its four constituent muscles.

  • Teres minor is the part of the rotator cuff muscle, not the teres major.

Option C: Part of its action is to pull the humeral head superiorly.

  • The rotator cuff provides stability to the shoulder joint by pulling the humeral head inferiorly.

Option D: Subscapularis inserts onto the greater tuberosity of the humerus.

  • It inserts into the lesser trochanter of the humerus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was found to have clinical features of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia(CML) on a peripheral blood smear. On detailed evaluation, the patient also had a T315I mutation in BCR-ABL. What is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ponatinib

  • T315I mutation is a mutation in the critical BCR-ABL kinase in the ATP-binding pocket.
  • This prevents imatinib binding and hence leads to resistance to imatinib, nilotinib, bosutinib, and dasatinib.
  • The only drug effective for T315I mutation CML is ponatinib.
  • Otherwise, the drug of choice for CML is imatinib.
  • The drug of choice in case of failure of > 2 Tyrosine kinase inhibitor is Omacetaxine

Option A: Bosutinib

  • The drug of choice for imatinib-resistant CML is bosutinib

Option B: Tofacitinib

  • Tofacitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor; it works by blocking the action of the Janus kinase enzyme.
  • It is used to treat moderately active rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ulcerative colitis, ankylosing spondylitis and polyarticular course juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option D: Nilotinib

  • T315I mutation is a mutation in the critical BCR-ABL kinase in the ATP-binding pocket
  • This prevents imatinib binding and hence leads to resistance to nilotinib.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the community health center for antenatal care. During counseling, the healthcare provider discusses various government schemes. Among these, the provider mentions the "Prerna" initiative. Which among the following is not a characteristic of “Prerna”?

choices.text: It provides reward for specific parenthood
Rs. 1,50,000 was given for 100 cases. Rs 500 per case extra given if 30 cases at a time are done

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rs. 1,50,000 given for 100 cases. Rs 500 per case extra given if 30 cases at a time are done:

  • The statement given in option D is a characteristic of the Santushti scheme of Jansankhya Sthirata Kosh (JSK) which is given to the healthcare facility/doctor and not the patient.
  • Prerna, an innovative strategy seeks to reverse this trend to help push up the age of marriage of girls, delay the birth of the first child, and promote birth spacing.
  • It identifies and awards below-poverty line (BPL) couples in select districts with poor social and economic indicators of the country, who fulfill certain responsible parenthood criteria which include marriage at least on or after 19 years, first child on or after 21 years, spacing of three years between children and voluntary adoption of sterilization by either of the parent after two children.
  • Girl's marriage after 19 years – Rs 5000
  • First birth after 21 years – Rs 7000- girl and Rs 5000-boy
  • >3 years gap between first and second child with sterilization of 1 parent after the 2nd child (reward of Rs 7000/- if it is a girl child & Rs 5000/- if it is a boy
  • The couples who have broken the stereotype are felicitated at large public functions and promoted as role models for responsible parenthood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initiative for population control:

  • "Prerna" is indeed an initiative for population control. It aims to promote family planning and control population growth through various incentives and schemes.

Option B - It provides a reward for specific parenthood:

  • One of the characteristics of "Prerna" is providing rewards for specific parenthood. This typically includes incentives for sterilization or adoption of contraceptive methods.

Option C - Girl's marriage after 19 years – Rs 5000:

  • This statement is also true about the "Prerna" initiative. "Prerna" focuses on promoting responsible parenthood and family planning.

questions.text: A 4-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department with the complaint of vomiting for 2 weeks. According to the mother, vomitus consists of milk and is non bilious without blood. He has had small spit-ups since birth, but for the last few days, he has been vomiting forcefully after every feed and his condition is deteriorating . His appetite is normal and he always seems hungry. The infant was born to a 27-year-old primigravida via normal vaginal delivery who did not seek prenatal care. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 26/min. The baby appears dehydrated and abdominal examination reveals visible gastric peristaltic waves and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Which of the following is the surgery of choice for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy:

  • This patient's presentation, including forceful vomiting, feeling hungry despite vomiting, visible gastric peristaltic waves, and a palpable "olive-sized" mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, is consistent with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Pyloric stenosis is a thickening of the pylorus (the muscle between the stomach and the intestines) that causes severe and forceful vomiting in the first few months of life. It is also called infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Vomiting after feeding at 4-8 weeks of age. The baby may vomit forcefully, ejecting breast milk or formula up to several feet away (forceful projectile vomiting). Vomitus is usually nonbloody and nonbilious.
    • Persistent hunger: babies who have pyloric stenosis often want to eat soon after vomiting
    • Dehydration
    • Changes in bowel movements
    • Poor weight gain

 

Causes:

  • The causes of pyloric stenosis are unknown, but genetic and environmental factors might play a role.

Risk factors:

  • Risk factors for pyloric stenosis include:
    • Sex: more often in boys, especially firstborn boys , than in girls.
    • Race: more common in whites of Northern European ancestry, less common in black people and rare in Asians.
    • Premature birth: more common in babies born prematurely than in full-term babies.
    • Family history: Pyloric stenosis develops in about 20% of male descendants and 10% of female descendants of mothers who had the condition.
    • Smoking during pregnancy: doubles the risk of pyloric stenosis.
    • Early antibiotic use: Babies given certain antibiotics like erythromycin in the first weeks of life have an increased risk of pyloric stenosis. In addition, babies born to mothers who took certain antibiotics (like macrolides) in late pregnancy may have an increased risk of pyloric stenosis.
    • Bottle-feeding: Some studies suggest that bottle-feeding rather than breastfeeding increases the risk of pyloric stenosis. Most of the people who participated in these studies used formula feeds rather than breast milk, so it isn't clear whether the increased risk is related to formula feeds or the mechanism of bottle feeding.
  • Electrolyte abnormality seen: hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria in case of severe dehydration.
  • (Large amounts of vomitus lead to loss of HCl and K+ with the kidney in turn compensating by reabsorbing more Na+ and HCO3- in exchange of H+ to maintain the intravascular volume and pH causing the above mentioned abnormality.)

Diagnosis:

  • Abdominal ultrasound: It is the gold standard for diagnosing infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Management:

  • Resuscitation by I.V fluids along with correction of electrolyte levels, particularly potassium
  • Fluid of choice: Normal Saline
  • The treatment of choice after resuscitation is surgery. Surgery is needed to treat pyloric stenosis. The procedure (Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy) is often scheduled on the same day as the diagnosis. If the baby is dehydrated or has an electrolyte imbalance, he or she will have a fluid replacement before surgery.
  • A pyloromyotomy, or Ramstedt's procedure, is a procedure where the muscle of the pylorus of the stomach is divided to allow normal stomach emptying.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Duodenostomy:

  • Tube duodenostomy involves the insertion of a small feeding tube through the duodenal stump to encourage the formation of a controlled duodeno-cutaneous fistula. It is done for the management of difficult duodenal stumps in certain cases of partial gastrectomy or duodenal ulcers.

Option B - Billroth Type-I procedure:

  • The Billroth I operation is a type of reconstruction after a partial gastrectomy in which the pylorus of the stomach is anastomosed to the duodenum. It is most commonly performed in the management of peptic ulcers and gastric carcinoma.

Option C - KASAI operation:

  • The Kasai procedure involves removing the blocked bile ducts and gallbladder and replacing them with a segment of the child's own small intestine. This segment of the intestine is sewn to the liver and functions as a new extrahepatic biliary system. It is performed in biliary atresia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of redness, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity for the last 2.5 months. He gave his history of contact with cats. On his ocular examination, severe vitritis was associated with a focal necrotizing chorioretinitis on the posterior segment. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Toxoplasma Gondi:

  • The most likely cause of the condition described in the scenario is Toxoplasma. Toxoplasma is a parasitic infection caused by the Toxoplasma gondii parasite. It commonly affects the posterior segment of the eye and can present with symptoms such as redness, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity.
  • Toxoplasma chorioretinitis is characterized by severe vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous humor) and focal necrotizing chorioretinitis (inflammation and necrosis of the choroid and retina). The history of contact with cats is significant because cats are the definitive host for Toxoplasma gondii, and the infection can be acquired through contact with cat feces or ingestion of undercooked meat contaminated with the parasite.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Oncocerca: Onchocerca is a parasitic infection caused by the Onchocerca volvulus parasite and primarily affects the skin and eyes. It typically presents with symptoms such as itching, skin lesions, and visual impairment, but it does not cause severe vitritis or necrotizing chorioretinitis as described in the scenario.

Option C - Taenia solium: Taenia solium is a parasitic infection caused by the pork tapeworm. It primarily affects the gastrointestinal system and can lead to neurocysticercosis when the larvae invade the central nervous system. Ocular involvement in neurocysticercosis can occur but is rare and usually presents with cystic lesions rather than severe vitritis and necrotizing chorioretinitis.

Option D - Option Toxocara: Toxocara is a parasitic infection caused by the roundworms Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati. Ocular toxocariasis occurs when the larvae migrate to the eye. It can cause inflammation and visual impairment, but it typically presents with granulomas and peripheral retinal lesions rather than severe vitritis and necrotizing chorioretinitis seen in the scenario. It is most common in children.

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with sudden fever and rash, following a recent sore throat. Examination reveals febrile state, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes, circumoral pallor, red lines in antecubital fossae, diffuse sandpaper-like rash on trunk and extremities, and a strawberry-like tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Scarlet fever:

  • The clinical features described in this case are classic for scarlet fever, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus). 
  • Clinical features of scarlet fever:
    • Sore throat
    • Circumoral pallor
    • Antecubital fossa: pastia lines
    • Sandpaper rash
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Erythrogenic toxins (SPEs)
    • Strawberry Tongue

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Measles (Rubeola): Presents with a prodrome of high fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, followed by the characteristic erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward.

Option B - Kawasaki disease: Features prolonged fever, conjunctival injection, rash, erythema of the palms and soles, cervical lymphadenopathy, and changes in the lips and oral cavity.

Option C - Rocky Mountain spotted fever: Presents with fever, headache, myalgias, and a petechial rash that typically starts on the wrists and ankles and spreads centrally.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on her neck for 7 months. It is neither pruritic nor painful. She has tried using over-the-counter topical medications, but none have helped. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), her pulse is 80/min, her respirations are 15/min, and her blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-mm (0.2-in) nontender, indurated, nodular lesion with rolled-out edges on the anterolateral aspect of the neck. There is a central area of ulceration. In addition to dermoscopy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform a punch biopsy of the centre of the lesion
Perform an excisional biopsy of the entire lesion

questions.solution:
Option B: Perform an excisional biopsy of the entire lesion

  • This patient is most likely suffering from basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is characterized by a slow-growing, locally invasive malignant neoplasm of the skin that arises from basal epithelial cells.
  • It is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinoma develops in sun-exposed areas as a pearly, indurated, nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration, as illustrated in the image below:

  • The subtypes of basal cell carcinoma include nodular basal cell carcinoma and superficial basal cell carcinoma.
  • Nodular basal cell carcinoma mostly involves the face, especially the nose, as shown in the image below:

  • Whereas superficial basal cell carcinoma is characterized by the flat eczematous (scaly) plaque with a pearly border lesion.
  • The superficial basal cell carcinoma variant mostly involves the trunk. This variant is illustrated in the image below:

  • The patient with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) should undergo a full-thickness biopsy of the edge of the lesion for histopathological confirmation of BCC.
  • The standard treatment options include surgical excision with a safety margin and  Mohs micrographic surgery.

Option A: Perform a punch biopsy of the centre of the lesion

  • A biopsy of this patient's suspicious lesion facilitates histopathologic confirmation of the diagnosis and provides prognostic information based on the findings. A punch biopsy provides a sample of a portion of the patient's lesion through a relatively simple procedure. However, punch biopsies sample only a limited amount of tissue and thus rarely provide an assessment of tumour histology accurately enough to guide therapy.

Option C: Schedule external beam radiotherapy sessions

  • A treatment method where a machine delivers carefully targeted radiation beams from outside the body to destroy cancer cells, halt their growth, or offer palliative therapy of locally advanced unresectable or metastatic disease. It is the most commonly used form of radiation therapy.
  • External beam radiotherapy (XBRT) is a treatment option for BCC that is typically used for patients who are poor candidates for and opt against surgical removal, especially elderly patients for whom quality of life may take priority over definitive treatment. XBRT is noninvasive and avoids the cosmetic effects of tissue removal.
  • For this patient, who has a clinically suspicious lesion but has not yet been definitively diagnosed as BCC, XBRT could be a viable option in the further course of management. However, it is not appropriate until the diagnosis has been confirmed and treatment options have been fully considered.

Option D: Administer topical 5-fluorouracil to the lesion

  • Topical 5-fluorouracil treats superficial BCC and squamous cell carcinoma in situ. However, a diagnosis needs to be established before treatment. Furthermore, topical 5-FU has a relatively high rate of adverse effects, is dependent on patient adherence, and has lower clearance rates than other treatment modalities.
  • Therefore, its use is limited to patients with small tumours in low-risk locations (e.g., the trunk or extremities) and will not or cannot undergo treatment with surgery or other effective therapies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in patients suffering from Horner’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Retention of cilio-spinal reflex:

  • In Horner's syndrome, there is a loss of sympathetic innervation, leading to the loss of the cilio-spinal reflex. This reflex involves dilation of the pupil in response to noxious stimuli. Therefore, retention of the cilio-spinal reflex is not typically seen in Horner's syndrome.
  • This can be demonstrated by the absence of pupil dilatation in response to pinching on the nape or one side of the body, face, or upper trunk, and any trauma.
    • Horner's:
      • It is both congenital and acquired.
      • The presence of heterochromia iridis indicates it is congenital.

Incorrect Options:
Option A – Miosis:

  • Miosis, or constricted pupil, is a characteristic feature of Horner's syndrome. It results from the disruption of sympathetic innervation to the dilator pupillae muscle.

Option B – Ptosis:

  • Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, is another hallmark of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to the paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle, which is innervated by sympathetic fibers.

Option C – Enophthalmos:

  • Enophthalmos is an apparent enophthalmos i.e., the eye looks displaced due to the mild ptosis of the upper eyelid (paralysis of muller muscle).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency with a history of sudden left limb weakness. The physician notes forgetfulness, disorientation, confusion, and signs of ischemic stroke. A CT scan revealed a damaged area in the brain that processes short-term memory into long-term memory. Which of the following regions is involved in processing short-term memory into long-term memory?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hippocampus:

  • The hippocampus is responsible for processing short-term memory into long-term memory.
  • Memory consolidation involves neuroplasticity, including processes like synaptogenesis and synaptic strengthening (e.g., long-term potentiation).
  • The hippocampus collaborates with the neocortex to form and retrieve memories.
  • Damage to the hippocampus can lead to anterograde amnesia, where new memories cannot be formed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prefrontal cortex:

  • Involved in cognitive functions but not primarily responsible for memory consolidation.

Option C - Neocortex:

  • Involved in sensory perception and cognition but not primarily responsible for memory consolidation.

Option D - Amygdala:

  • Involved in emotional memory but not primarily responsible for memory consolidation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of road traffic accidents due to a motorcycle collision with a heavy vehicle. Vitals are within normal limits. On abdominal examination, no guarding or rigidity is found, although the patient has mild tenderness in the left hypochondrium. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is done, and the findings are shown in the image below:



Which of the following does it suggest?
questions.solution:
Option A: Positive FAST

  • In the given image there is Collection of fluid in the peri-splenic region is elicited in USG→ Positive FAST
  • FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)

 

 

Subxiphoid transverse view

Assess pericardial sac

Right upper quadrant (RUQ) longitudinal view

Assess the perihepatic region

Left upper quadrant (LUQ) longitudinal view

Assess perisplenic region

Suprapubic longitudinal & transverse view

Assess pelvis
  • e-FAST (extended FAST) has two additional views, right & left thoracic views, to rule out pneumothorax or hemothorax

Other options

Option B: Negative FAST

  • FAST is said to be negative when it does not illustrate any fluid collection

Option C: Equivocal FAST

  • It means that the result of the FAST is non-concordant, which is not true in this patient's case, as the FAST is significant for the presence of fluid.

Option D: Inconclusive FAST

  • If the FAST does not lead to any definite finding, it is said to be inconclusive.

questions.text: The image shows the uterine sutures in a woman with PPH. Identify.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • B-Lynch suture
  • Two sutures are applied longitudinally, which looks like a "brace-suspender,"
  • The b-Lynch suture is referred as the "brace suture."
  • It involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which appose the anterior and posterior wall of the uterus, which leads to compression of the fundus and lower uterine segment, thereby controlling hemorrhage

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Hayman suture

  • Hayman procedure is considered a uterine compression suture using two longitudinal threads and transfixing the entire uterine wall.
  • This suture is simpler than the B-Lynch suture, and is sometimes called the "simple brace."

Option C: Cho suture

  • The Cho suture, or Modified Cho suture, involves placing a series of vertical and horizontal sutures on the uterine fundus to achieve hemostasis.

Option D: Pereira suture

  • The Pereira suture is a type of uterine compression suture, involving placing horizontal and vertical sutures on the uterus.
  • It is different from Cho suture as there is no transfixion of the total uterine wall.

questions.text: Which structure is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Adenosine

  • The structure is of Adenosine.
  • Look at the nitrogenous base. It has two rings, so it is a purine.
  • The amino group is present, so it is adenine. (Guanosine also contains amino group on the ring but also has Oxo group)
  • Sugar is also attached, so it is a nucleoside (nitrogenous base + sugar).
  • In the case of adenine, a nucleoside is known as Adenosine.

Nucleotide= nitrogenous base + sugar + phosphate

Option A: Guanosine

  • Guanosine is a purine nucleoside.
  • It is composed of ribose sugar and a purine, guanine.
  • It is differentiated from Adenosine by the presence of the Oxo group on the ring

Option C: Pyrimidine

  • Pyrimidine has a single six-membered nitrogen-containing ring.

Option D: Purines

  • Purines have two rings.
  • One is six-membered, and the other one is five-membered.

questions.text: A professor is explaining about functions of different parts of the nephron to second-year medical students. He demonstrates that tubular reabsorption is the second major step in urine formation. Most of the reabsorption of solutes necessary for normal body function takes place in the proximal part of the tubule. Which of the following is not absorbed in proximal convoluted tubules?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hydrogen ions

  • 66% water, 100% glucose, amino acids, 65% potassium ions, 50% urea, and 85% phosphate ions are reabsorbed in the PCT, not hydrogen ions.
  • The PCT secretes H+; it is for the reabsorption of the filtered HCO3-.
  • Fluid at the end of the PCT is always Iso-osmotic to plasma.

Glomerulotubular balance in the proximal tubule: This phenomenon tends to minimize the effects of a fluctuating GFR on Na+ and water excretion, which promotes a constant plasma volume. It maintains Constant fractional reabsorption (about 67%) f the Filtered Na+ and water, even if the GFR varies.

 

Option A: Sodium

  • PCT reabsorbs the largest fraction (about 67%) of the filtered Na+, K+, Ca2+, Cl-, HCO3-, and water.

Option B: Glucose

  • PCT reabsorbs all of the filtered glucose and amino acids.

Option D: Amino acids

  • PCT reabsorbs all of the filtered glucose and amino acids.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has consulted the psychologist seeking help. He describes to the psychologist his excessive sexual desire and addiction to porn viewing. He decided to seek help after he found himself getting sexual gratification by hearing sounds of sexual intercourse that he hears from the neighboring room which is occupied by another tenant. What will the psychologist document the symptom as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ecoutage:

  • Getting sexual gratification by hearing sounds of sexual intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mixoscopia:

  • GA type of voyeurism in which sexual gratiﬁcation is obtained by the sight of others engaged in sex..

Option B - Scatologia:

  • Scatologia involves making obscene phone calls.

Option C - Sexual oralism:

  • Sexual oralism is referred to as fellatio or cunnilingus, which involves oral stimulation of a partner’s genitals or anus.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with a GCS of 7/15 arrives in the ER after a car accident. He has an open wound on his forehead, which is treated by washing and stitching. A CT scan shows a frontal extradural hematoma. The patient undergoes emergency surgery to remove the hematoma. Before anesthesia, a pre-anesthetic drug is administered to reduce secretions and prevent bronchospasm. Which drug was used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glycopyrrolate:

  • Glycopyrrolate is a commonly used pre-anesthetic medication to reduce secretions and prevent reflex bronchospasm.
  • It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that inhibits the action of acetylcholine, thereby reducing salivary, respiratory, and gastrointestinal secretions.
  • By decreasing secretions helps in maintaining clear airways during anesthesia induction and prevents bronchospasm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pipenzolate methyl bromide:

  • Primarily treats gastrointestinal issues like irritable bowel syndrome and ulcers, not typically used to reduce secretions before anesthesia.

Option C - Isopropamide:

  • An anticholinergic for gastrointestinal disorders like ulcers and gastritis, not typically given as pre-anesthetic medication.

Option D - Dicyclomine:

  • Primarily for gastrointestinal issues like irritable bowel syndrome, not typically used as pre-anesthetic to reduce secretions.

questions.text: Pregnancy involves an extensive change in vessels of the uterus and placenta by means of trophoblast invasion. Physiological changes include which of the following:

choices.text: Conversion of Low resistance to high resistance.
Conversion of High resistance to low resistance

questions.solution:
Option B : Remodeling converts narrow-lumen, muscular spiral arteries into dilated, low-resistance uteroplacental vessels by means of trophoblast invasion into spiral arteries.

Uteroplacental vasculature development proceeds in two waves or stages.

The first wave occurs before 12 weeks post fertilization and consists of invasion and modification of spiral arteries up to the border between the decidua and myometrium.

The second wave is between 12 and 16 weeks and involves some invasion of the intramyometrial segments of spiral arteries.

questions.text: What is the likely classification of an organism, whose cell wall lacks porins and lipopolysaccharides on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gram-positive bacteria:

  • The absence of lipopolysaccharides and porins indicates that the bacterial cells belong to the Gram-positive group. These features are characteristic of Gram-positive bacteria and help differentiate them from Gram-negative bacteria

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gram-negative bacteria:

  • Gram-negative bacteria typically have a cell wall with a thin layer of peptidoglycan surrounded by an outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides and porins.

Option C - Acid-fast bacteria:

  • Acid-fast bacteria, like Mycobacterium species, have a unique cell wall with mycolic acids.

Option D - Bacteria with atypical cell walls:

  • The term "bacteria with atypical cell walls" is not a standard classification in bacterial taxonomy. Bacteria are generally classified into gram-positive, gram-negative, and acid acid-fasteria based on their cell wall structure, as described earlier.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the emergency department with the complaint of excessive crying over the last 4 hours. On examination, there is a gap in the posterior spinal canal region, and something is coming out from this defect and meninges and parts of the spinal cord herniate through the vertebral bone defect. The neonate's respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute; the heart rate is 126 beats per minute. On further inquiring neonate’s mother reveals that she is a known case of diabetes and did not take folic acid tablets during pregnancy. Which of the following option best describe this condition of neonate?

choices.text: Most commonly involves the lumbosacral spine
Folic acid 200 µg/day is used for primary prevention
Folic acid should be started as soon as the pregnancy is diagnosed

questions.solution:
Option A: Most commonly involves the lumbosacral spine

  • Clinical signs: known cases of diabetes and folic acid deficiency suggest that this is most likely a case of meningomyelocele.
  • A meningomyelocele is called a neural tube defect in which the meninges and spinal cord herniate through an abnormal vertebral opening.
  • Associated with maternal diabetes and folate deficiency.
  • Meningomyelocele most commonly involves the lumbosacral spine.
  • Neurological symptoms depend on the area and extent of neuronal damage.
    • Motor loss
    • Sensory deficits
    • Bladder and bowel dysfunction
    • Additional symptoms are
      • Hydrocephalus
      • Club foot
      • Sacral dimpling
      • Joint contractures

Option B: Folic acid 200 µg/day is used for primary prevention

  • Folate supplementation in pregnancy-- 400–800 μg/day for all women planning or capable of pregnancy  

  • At least before four weeks of conception for women with a history of a previous pregnancy resulting in a neural tube defect.
  • 400–800 μg/day when no pregnancy is planned.
  • 4 mg/day when pregnancy is scheduled at least one month before conception.
  • Intake should be continued through the first trimester.

Option C: It cannot be diagnosed antenatally

  • Screening test 16–18 weeks' gestation reveals increased alpha-fetoprotein in maternal serum.
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein is only elevated in open NTDs.
  • MSAFP is not elevated in spina bifida occulta.
  • Usually part of the quad screen test.
  • Ultrasonography 18–20 week's gestation
  • Characteristic findings depend on the specific defect
    • Anencephaly
    • The cranial vault and brain tissue are absent
    • Disorganized cerebellar
    • Bulging eyes and underdeveloped forehead
    • Association with polyhydramnios
    • Amniocentesis

Option D: Folic acid should be started as soon as the pregnancy is diagnosed

  • Folic acid should be started at least one month before conception.
  • To prevent NTDs, it is recommended that all women of childbearing age.
  • Women who are capable of becoming pregnant should take 0.4 mg (400 μg) of folic acid daily.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents for a screening mammogram. The mammogram shows a well-defined oval mass with microcalcifications within the lesion. No architectural distortion is noted. The surrounding breast tissue appears normal, and there are no axillary lymphadenopathies. According to the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS), what is the most appropriate BIRADS category for this mammographic finding?

choices.text: BIRADS Category 5: Highly suggestive of malignancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: BIRADS Category 5

  • Highly suggestive of malignancy: This category is used for mammographic findings that have features highly indicative of malignancy. The  well-defined oval mass with microcalcifications fits the criteria of 5 category, as the presence of microcalcifications within a mass is a worrisome sign.

BIRADS 5 

  • A dense lesion generally
  •  It is white and microcalcification that is a feature of breast cancer less than 0.5 mm
  • There can be architectural distortions because of cancer causing desmoplastic reactions.
  • Focal asymmetry is also seen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BIRADS Category 2: Benign finding: This category is assigned to mammographic findings that have typical benign features with no suspicious features. It does not include any lesions with microcalcifications, as microcalcifications warrant further evaluation.

Option B - BIRADS Category 3: Probably benign finding: This category is used for mammographic findings with a high likelihood of being benign, but the radiologist recommends a short-term follow-up for further assessment. 

Option C - BIRADS Category 4: Probably Malignant: This category is used for mammographic findings that have suspicious features but are not highly suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 9-day-old neonate is brought to the outpatient clinic by parents with the complaint of ambiguous genitalia. Upon asking, they told the physician that delivery was done at home and that they thought the swelling, would resolve in its time. The doctor orders an ultrasound that reveals the presence of both uterus as well as vas deferens. This can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Ovotestis

  • The presence of both Mullerian and Wolffian structures is suggestive of true hermaphroditism.
  • Genotype: XX or XY or mosaic XX/XY genotypes
  • The phenotype can be male or female.
  • External genitalia is ambiguous, and breast development frequently occurs in these individuals.
  • Both male and female gonadal tissues are present: one ovary and one testis or bilateral ovotestes. Ovotestis is seen in true hermaphroditism. Both ovaries and testis are present. The internal structures depend on the degree of differentiation of the gonads.
  • Two-thirds of the patients menstruate, but menstruation is never reported in XY genotypes.
  • It is a rare condition that should be considered as a possible cause of amenorrhea

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Placental aromatase deficiency

  • This is a condition with the deficient aromatase enzyme, causing decreased conversion of testosterone to estrogen
  • Individuals with XX genotype will present with ambiguous genitalia or male genitalia, known as female pseudohermaphroditism.
  • Individuals with XY genotype will have normal male genitalia.

Option C: FSH receptor mutation

  • Individuals with FSH receptor mutation will either have Wolffian duct (males) or Mullerian duct derivatives (females). Never both. FSH receptor mutation causes infertility or subfertility in males or females.

Option D: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • AIS is a condition where individuals with a 46,XY karyotype have a complete or partial inability to respond to androgens. In complete AIS, the external genitalia may appear typically female, and internal structures such as the uterus and upper part of the vagina may be present. However, the vas deferens is typically absent or rudimentary.

questions.text: How the most commonly occurring malignant tumor of the submandibular gland is usually graded?

choices.text: Based on the number of Mucinous cells
Based on the nuclear: cytoplasmic ratio
It depends on the variation in epidermoid cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It depends on the variation in epidermoid cells:

  • The most common malignant submandibular gland tumor happens to be a mucoepidermoid tumor.
  • It has 2 components Mucinous cells and squamoid or epidermoid cells.
  • Of the two components, the more the epidermoid component in the tumor the higher the grade of the tumor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Based on the number of Mucinous cells: The more the number of mucinous cells the less cancerous and more the tendency of the gland to keep its functionality.

Option B - Based on the nuclear: cytoplasmic ratio: This is mostly used to describe leukemias, rather than Mucoepidermoid carcinoma.

Option D - Depends on the Perineural invasion: Perineural invasion is essentially a feature of Adenoid cystic carcinoma and it involves the painful progression of the tumor.

questions.text: In a rural community with limited healthcare resources, a community health center has been established to cater to the healthcare needs of the population. The health authorities are keen on monitoring the efficiency and utilization of healthcare services provided by the center. As part of their assessment, they evaluate various healthcare utilization indicators. Which of the following is NOT a healthcare utilization indicator?

choices.text: Average length of stay in hospital

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Doctor-nurse ratio:

  • The doctor-nurse ratio primarily focuses on staffing levels and the distribution of healthcare professionals within a facility, making it a healthcare delivery indicator rather than a utilization indicator.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bed occupancy rates: This indicator reflects the demand for inpatient services and the efficient utilization of hospital resources, making it a healthcare utilization indicator.

Option B - Bed turnover ratio: This ratio assesses the efficiency of bed utilization, indicating how effectively beds are being utilized, making it a healthcare utilization indicator.

Option C—Average length of stay in hospital: This indicator measures the average duration patients spend in the hospital. It provides insights into the efficiency of patient care and resource allocation, making it a healthcare utilization indicator.

questions.text: BERA is performed to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. Which wave in Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is typically the largest, most stable, and considered the most significant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Wave V

  • This wave is produced from the lateral lemniscus and is observed around 5.5 ms.
  • Wave V is typically the largest, tallest, most stable, and considered the most significant wave in BERA.
  • It represents the neural activity occurring at the level of the lateral lemniscus, which is involved in the transmission of auditory information to higher auditory centers in the brain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wave I:

  • This wave is produced by the distal part of the Eighth nerve and occurs at approximately 1.5 milliseconds (ms) after the auditory stimulus. It represents the initial electrical activity generated by the auditory nerve.

Option B - Wave III:

  • This wave is produced from the cochlear nucleus and appears at around 3.5 ms. It represents the processing of auditory information in the brainstem at the level of the cochlear nucleus.

Option C - Wave IV:

  • This wave is generated from the superior olivary complex and is typically observed at approximately 4.5 ms. It reflects the neural activity occurring at the level of the superior olivary complex, which plays a role in sound localization and binaural processing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe colicky flank pain on the right side. The pain radiates towards the groin, and the patient also complains of urinary urgency and frequency. An X-ray of the abdomen and pelvis is performed, revealing a radio-opaque stone in the right ureter at the level of the L3 vertebral body. A non-contrast CT scan is subsequently performed, which confirms the presence of a 5mm stone in the right ureter causing mild hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous fluids and analgesics, and observe for spontaneous passage of the stone
Immediate surgical intervention for stone removal

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Intravenous fluids and analgesics, and observe for spontaneous passage of the stone

  • This is the initial management approach for a patient with urolithiasis who is hemodynamically stable and does not have signs of infection or obstruction. The majority of ureteral stones smaller than 10mm have a good chance of passing spontaneously with conservative management.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Immediate surgical intervention for stone removal: Surgical intervention is not the first-line treatment for uncomplicated urolithiasis. It is typically reserved for cases of failed conservative management, large stones, presence of complications such as infection or obstructive uropathy, or inability to tolerate conservative management.

Option C - Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller fragments, making them easier to pass. It is commonly used for kidney stones, but it may not be the first choice for stones located in the ureter.

Option D - Ureteroscopy with stone retrieval: Ureteroscopy involves the insertion of a thin tube with a camera (ureteroscope) into the ureter to visualize the stone. It allows for direct visualization and removal of the stone using various techniques. Ureteroscopy may be considered if conservative management fails or for larger or obstructing stones.

questions.text: In a patient with optic nerve disease and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), when light is thrown into the eye with RAPD, what will be the observed response of the pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Paradoxical dilation:

  • In a patient with optic nerve disease and RAPD, the affected eye demonstrates a paradoxical dilation instead of the normal constriction when exposed to light. This abnormal pupillary response is a characteristic feature of RAPD and is indicative of dysfunction in the afferent pathway of the optic nerve.

Incorrect Options:
Option A – Normal constriction:

  • This option describes the expected response of a healthy eye to light. When light is shone into the eye, the normal response is pupillary constriction, known as the pupillary light reflex.

Option C – No change in pupil size:

  • This option is not correct in the context of RAPD. RAPD is characterized by an abnormal response, and the affected pupil typically shows a paradoxical dilation in the presence of light.

Option D – Rapid oscillation of pupil size:

  • Rapid oscillation of pupil size is not a characteristic finding in the context of RAPD. RAPD is specifically associated with a lack of normal constriction in response to light.

questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old gravida 2 para 1 at 38 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labour. Shortly after hospital admission, epidural analgesia is initiated at the patient's request. Three hours later, she was fully dilated and gave birth via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery to a healthy baby boy. The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of birth. What is the advantage of delayed cord clamping?

choices.text: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood

questions.solution:
Option C: Lesser chances of shock

  • The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of the delivery; this is termed delayed cord clamping
  • In delayed cord clamping, transitional circulation is improved.
  • It helps in the formation of more red blood cell volumes.
  • It decreases the need for blood transfusion.
  • It lowers the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • It decreases the risk of interventricular hemorrhage.
  • It decreases the risk of shock.
  • As more blood is supplied to the muscles and tissues
  • Good tissue perfusion.
  • Better supply to the tissues will decrease the risk of ischemia
  • Advantages of delayed cord clamping:
    • Lesser chances of anaemia
    • Higher blood pressure
    • Lesser chances of shock
    • Lesser intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Immediate resuscitation of the newborn can save the baby from lifetime disability or death.

Option A: Early hemolysis of RBC

  • Hemolysis of RBCs will lead to hemodilution.
  • Hemodilution will lead to anaemia.

Option B: Release of bilirubin

  • Bilirubin is a product of RBC breakdown.
  • Bilirubin is released when RBCs undergo hemolysis.
  • It may also be elevated in case of liver disorders or defective hepatic metabolism.

Option D: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood 

  • In delayed cord clamping, the clamped RBCs are broken down in the circulation.
  • RBC breakdown causes the release of excessive bilirubin.
  • Levels of bilirubin are thus elevated in the bloodstream.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents to the ED with complaints of 2 episodes of unprovoked seizures within the last 2 days. While he is in the hospital, he starts seizing, IV access is not yet obtained. What can be given to control his seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rectal diazepam:

  • Rectal administration of diazepam is a well-established approach for terminating acute seizures, especially when IV access is unavailable or delayed.
  • Diazepam rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier, exerting its antiepileptic effects within minutes. This route bypasses the need for IV access, making it ideal for urgent seizure management.

Incorrect Options

Option A - IM Lorazepam:

  • Intramuscular lorazepam is not typically recommended for acute seizure management due to its slower onset of action compared to other routes like intravenous or rectal administration.IV Lorazepam is the ideal choice to terminate active seizures,

Option B - Subcutaneous Phenytoin:

  • While phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug used for seizure control, subcutaneous administration is not a common route for acute seizure management.

Option D - Intranasal midazolam:

  • Intranasal midazolam is a choice for status epilepticus not GTCS

questions.text: What structure is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Lecithin

  • The molecule in the image is phosphatidylcholine (lecithin), a type of phospholipid that is a crucial component of cell membranes.

  • Structure and Composition:

    • Phosphatidylcholine consists of a glycerol backbone linked to two fatty acid chains and a phosphate group, esterified to choline.
    • The fatty acid chains can vary in length and saturation, influencing the physical properties of the phospholipid.
    • Choline, derived from phosphatidylcholine, is an essential nutrient and precursor for the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, which is involved in nervous transmission.
    • Dipalmitoyl lecithin, a specific form of phosphatidylcholine with two palmitoyl (saturated) fatty acid chains, is a major constituent of pulmonary surfactant, which prevents the collapse of alveoli by reducing surface tension in the lungs.

  • Function:

    • Cell Membrane Structure: Phosphatidylcholine is a fundamental component of cell membranes, contributing to their integrity and fluidity. Its amphipathic nature allows it to form the lipid bilayer structure, with hydrophobic fatty acid tails facing inward and hydrophilic phosphate-choline heads facing outward.
    • Nervous Transmission: Choline, derived from phosphatidylcholine, is a precursor for acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter critical for nervous system function. Adequate choline intake is essential for maintaining optimal neurotransmission.
    • Surfactant in Lungs: Dipalmitoyl lecithin serves as a major component of pulmonary surfactant, reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs. This prevents alveolar collapse during exhalation and helps maintain lung expansion, facilitating efficient gas exchange.

  • Clinical Significance:

    • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): In premature infants, the lungs may lack sufficient amounts of dipalmitoyl lecithin, leading to respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). This condition occurs due to inadequate surfactant production, resulting in difficulty in breathing and potential lung collapse.

Incorrect options

Option A: Cephalin

  • Cephalin is a phosphatidyl-ethanolamine.
  • It is bactericidal.
  • It is found in cell membranes, especially in the brain tissues.
  • Cephalin is important for blood clotting.
  • It contains serin or ethanolamine.

​​​​​​

Option C: Sphingomyelin

  • Sphingomyelin is found in the plasma cell membrane.
  • It is composed of large chain sphingosine, phosphocholine, and fatty acid.

​​​​​​

Option D: Glucocerebroside

  • Glucocerebroside is a sphingolipid that is found in the cell membrane.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: Marimuthu is a 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes. His primary care physician refers him to you for an evaluation of his obesity and treatment options, including weight-loss surgery. He weighs 156 kg and is 182cm tall, with a BMI of 47.1 kg/m2. Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) surgery is recommended. The patient’s blood glucose level on post-op day 2 is 156 mg/dl. Two months post-surgery, the patient is recovering well, and his fasting and pre-dinner blood glucose levels are consistently < 120 mg/dl, without oral hypoglycemic agents. In addition to the effects of weight loss, the resolution of type 2 diabetes mellitus after the RYGB is thought to be contributed by which of the following?

choices.text: Increased activity of beta cells of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Option C: Increased activity of beta cells of the pancreas

  • After RYGB, there is a marked increase in the activity of beta cells in the pancreas. This is thought to be due to increased secretion of GLP-1 (Glucagon like peptide- 1). Hence type-2 Diabetes Mellitus improves after the procedure.

Option A: Increased ghrelin production

  • Ghrelin is a hormone that stimulates hunger and increases the drive to eat.
  • Gastrectomy removes much of the ghrelin-producing portion of the stomach, leading to weight loss after both sleeve gastrectomy and RYGB procedures. So there is a decrease in ghrelin production.

Option B: Decreased secretion of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1)

  • GLP-1 is dramatically increased after RYGB and sleeve gastrectomy.
  • GLP-1 helps stimulate beta cell proliferation and upregulation of genes involved in insulin secretion.
  • It also inhibits glucagon secretion and reduces appetite and gastric motility.

Option D: Decreased level of peptide YY

  • There is an increase in peptide YY (PYY) levels after RYGB. Peptide YY is thought to contribute towards appetite suppression and therefore, helps with weight loss and improvement in diabetes mellitus type 2.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presents to the ESIS hospital with complaints of progressive shortness of breath and chronic dry cough. He has worked as a stone cutter in a quarry for the past 20 years. He is known hypertensive and on regular medication. On examination, he has bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Pulmonary function testing reveals a restrictive pattern. A chest X-ray is ordered. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on his chest X-ray?

choices.text: Nodules along septal lines without hilar adenopathy
Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes:

  • Silicosis is a form of occupational lung disease caused by prolonged inhalation of crystalline quartz or silica dust. It is commonly found in miners, stone cutters, quarry workers, and sandblasters
  • It is characterized by the formation of nodular fibrotic lesions in the lungs, causing restrictive lung disease.
  • Nature of respiratory responses in silicosis include:
    • Fibrosis (silicosis)
    • Progressive massive fibrosis
    • Lung cancer
    • Increased risk of tuberculosis
    • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Silicosis occurs in a dose-response fashion after many years of exposure.
  • Chest X-ray findings seen in silicosis:
    • With long-term, less intense exposure, small rounded opacities in the upper lobes
    • Calcification of hilar lymph nodes in a characteristic eggshell pattern
    • In complicated silicosis, large symmetric bilateral opacities with irregular margin

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subdiaphragmatic and pleural plaques:

  • This finding is more commonly associated with asbestos exposure rather than silicosis.
  • Asbestos exposure leads to the formation of pleural plaques, which are discrete fibrous or calcified thickened areas involving the parietal pleura.
  • Asbestos exposure occurs in mining, processing, construction, and ship repair industries.

Option B - Nodules along septal lines without hilar adenopathy:

  • This finding is characteristic of chronic beryllium disease.
  • Chest imaging findings are similar to those of sarcoidosis (nodules along septal lines) except that hilar adenopathy is infrequent.
  • Beryllium exposure occurs in workers involved in processing alloys for high-tech industries.

Option C - Lung hyperinflation with flattened hemidiaphragm:

  • This finding is typically seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to air trapping and hyperinflation.
  • Although silicosis can lead to COPD, these findings are not characteristic of silicosis itself.

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant is brought to the hospital due to respiratory distress and cyanosis. On examination, sensorineural hearing loss, and cataracts are present. A continuous machinery murmur is heard on cardiac auscultation. Which among the following is the most preferred method for the diagnosis of the condition?

choices.text: Demonstration of the rise in antibody titer

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemagglutination inhibition test:

  • This neonate presents with the classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome - deafness, cardiac malformation, and cataracts.
  • The hemagglutination inhibition test detects antibodies against the rubella virus by measuring the ability of patient sera to inhibit the agglutination of red blood cells coated with the virus.
  • This test can be used to detect rubella-specific antibodies and is the most preferred method for diagnosing congenital rubella syndrome(CRS).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ELISA test:

  • Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a sensitive and specific serological test used to detect rubella-specific IgM antibodies in the infant's serum.
  • IgM antibodies indicate recent rubella infection, suggesting congenital rubella syndrome.
  • However, ELISA is not the most preferred method for diagnosing CRS.

Option C - Virus isolation:

  • This method involves isolating and culturing rubella virus from clinical specimens such as throat swabs or urine.
  • While virus isolation can confirm the presence of the rubella virus, it may not always be feasible or practical, especially in resource-limited settings, making it less preferred for diagnosing CRS compared to serological tests.

Option D - Demonstration of the rise in antibody titer:

  • This method involves serially testing the infant's serum for rubella-specific antibodies over time to observe a significant increase in antibody titer, indicating recent rubella infection.
  • While demonstrating a rise in antibody titer can support the diagnosis of CRS, it may not always be practical or timely, especially in cases requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with varicose veins in the lower limbs has developed itching and ulceration around the ankle and calf region for a few days. Which type of ulcer is likely to develop in a long-standing chronic venous ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Marjolin’s ulcer:

  • Chronic leg ulcers usually develop in varicose veins, venous hypertension, chronic infections, and long-standing vasculitis.
  • Marjolin’s ulcer arises from a long-standing ulcer or burn scar. It is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma.
  • It destroys nerves and is painless, slow-growing, and radio-resistant.
  • There is no distant metastasis.
  • It is a diagnosis by skin biopsy and treated by wide local excision with flap closure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aphthous ulcer:

  • Aphthous ulcer is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease.
  • It is characterized by an irregular, ulcerated, erythematous area with normal colonic mucosa.

Option C - Pressure sores:

  • Pressure sores are areas of tissue necrosis with ulceration under prolonged pressure along bony prominences
  • Sites of pressure sore are the occiput, sacrum, ischium, and greater trochanter.

Option D - Necrotizing fasciitis:

  • Necrotizing fasciitis is a polymicrobial infection of soft tissues with gram-positive aerobes, gram-negative anaerobes, and beta-hemolytic.
  • It is characterized by pain, edema, crepitus, blistering, fever, and greyish pus.
  • It can lead to shock and multi-organ failure in the advanced stage.
  • Treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgical excision.

questions.text: A healthy 35-year-old woman delivers a baby girl by a cesarean section. The pediatrician notes pallor, peripheral cyanosis, and cold extremities on immediate examination. The baby is placed under a radiant warmer to address hypothermia. What is the mechanism of maximum heat production in babies placed in this warmer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - :Radiation

  • Radiant warmer: It is an open care system and there is an overhead heating unit which consists of quartz crystal.
