  • It is readily available, less expensive and should be used in care of all babies with hypothermia.
  • Most important mode of heating: Radiation
  • Heat loss mainly takes place through Convection

Incorrect Options:

Option A, D & C - Evaporation / Convection & Conduction: These are not mechanisms of a radiant warmer for production of maximum heat in a baby placed in it

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who was hit by a car while riding her bike presents to the emergency department with a pulse of 100 and a BP of 90/75. She is complaining of pain in the left shoulder and wrist, with the latter showing an obvious deformity. A FAST scan is positive for free fluid in the abdomen. Which of the following organs is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Option A: Spleen

  • Splenic injuries are the most common injuries resulting from accidents involving blunt trauma to the abdomen.
  • In blunt trauma, the spleen is the most common intra-abdominal viscera injured. In this patient, one indication of a splenic injury is shoulder pain, which is a classic site of referred pain from the damaged spleen irritating the diaphragm.

Option B: Liver

  • The liver is the second most common organ injured in abdominal trauma, behind the spleen. Splenic and liver injuries account for 75% of all blunt abdominal injuries. However, left-sided injuries make the spleen more likely.

Option C: Pancreas

  • Possible but not as likely as the spleen for similar reasons to the kidneys.

Option D: Kidney

  • Possible but not as likely as the spleen because the kidneys sit in the retroperitoneum and are less susceptible to shear force than the spleen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent abortions and absent fetal movements in her previous pregnancy. Workup reveals a positive VDRL test. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and which antibody is the most specific for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) - Lupus anticoagulant:

  • The clinical scenario described, including recurrent abortions, absent fetal movements, and a positive VDRL test, is highly suggestive of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS).
  • Patients who have certain antiphospholipid antibodies may have false positive VDRL test. This occurs because the aPL bind to the lipids in the test and make it come out positive.
  • APS is characterized by the presence of lupus anticoagulant, along with other antibodies such as anti-cardiolipin antibody and anti-β2-glycoprotein antibody.
  • The lupus anticoagulant is associated with an increased risk of thrombotic events and pregnancy complications. 

Clinical Criteria

Lab Criteria

1. Vascular thrombosis

1. Anti-Cardiolipin IgG/IgM

2. Pregnancy Morbidity

2. Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein 1 (GP1)

3. Death of normal fetus at 3-10 weeks

3. Lupus anticoagulant (LAC)

4. Premature birth at ≤34 weeks due to preeclampsia

4. Medium to high titer

5. 3 consecutive abortions at <10 weeks

5. At least 2 times, 12 weeks apart

6. Placental insufficiency at <34 weeks

 

Based on these classification criteria, patients who have at least one positive clinical and one positive laboratory criteria are considered to have a diagnosis of APS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) - Anti-dsDNA antibody: SLE is an autoimmune disease characterized by various manifestations, including lupus nephritis and lupus cerebritis. The presence of anti-dsDNA antibody is highly specific for SLE and correlates with disease activity.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis - Rheumatoid factor: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. Rheumatoid factor is an antibody commonly found in the blood of individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not specific to this condition.

Option D - Sjogren's syndrome - Anti-SSA/Ro antibody: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the salivary glands and tear ducts. Anti-SSA/Ro antibody is commonly found in individuals with Sjogren's syndrome but is not as specific as lupus anticoagulant in the diagnosis of APS.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency room after he sustained a road traffic accident. His blood pressure is 88/76 mm Hg, and his pulse rate is 126 per minute. On examination, he appears pale and somnolent. Which of the following correctly represents the formula of the Modified Shock Index (MSI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Heart rate / Mean arterial pressure

  • Modified shock index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • High MSI indicates a value of stroke volume and low systemic vascular resistance, a sign of hypodynamic circulation.
  • Low MSI indicates hyperdynamic circulation.
  • MSI is a better marker than stroke index for mortality rate prediction

Option A: Heart rate / systolic BP

  • The heart rate divided by systolic BP is called the shock index.
  • It is a better marker for assessing the severity of shock than heart rate & blood pressure alone.

Option B: Heart rate / diastolic BP

  • Modified Stroke Index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Pulse rate / Systolic BP

  • Modified Stroke Index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents to the Gambat transplant center for the sake of liver transplantation. He has a history of chronic hepatitis with recurrent ascites. He has been an alcoholic for fifteen years. On examination, the stigmata of chronic liver disease are evident. Which of the following is most relevant about liver transplantation?

choices.text: Most common indication of liver transplant is hepatitis B-induced cirrhosis
Three recipients benefit from split liver transplantation
Sequence of anastomosis: 1. Supra hepatic IVC 2. Infra hepatic IVC 3. Portal vein 4. Hepatic artery 5. Bile duct

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sequence of anastomosis: 1. Supra hepatic IVC 2. Infra hepatic IVC 3. Portal vein 4. Hepatic artery 5. Bile duct:

  • The sequence of anastomosis in liver transplant is supra hepatic IVC, infra hepatic IVC, hepatic artery, portal vein and bile duct anastomosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most common indication for liver transplant is hepatitis B-induced liver cirrhosis:

  • The indications for liver transplantation fall into four groups:
    • Cirrhosis
    • Acute fulminant liver failure
    • Metabolic liver disease
    • Primary hepatic malignancy
    • The most common indication for liver transplant : HCV-induced cirrhosis > alcoholic liver disease
    • The most common indication for pediatric liver transplant is biliary atresia.

Adults

%

Non cholestatic cirrhosis

  • Viral hepatitis B and C
  • Alcoholic
  • Cryptogenic

  65

Cholestatic

  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

  14

Autoimmune

   5
  • Malignant neoplasm

(Hepatocellular carcinoma, Neuroendocrine tumors metastatic to liver)

   2

Miscellaneous (Fulminant hepatic failure)

  14

Children

   %

Biliary atresia

   58
  • Inborn errors of metabolism

(α1Antitrypsin deficiency, cystic fibrosis, hemochromatosis, primary hyperoxaluria, tyrosinemia, Wilson’s disease)

   11

Cholestatic

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Alagille syndrome

   9

Autoimmune

   4

Viral hepatitis

   2

Miscellaneous

 16
  • Other indications include Cryptogenic cirrhosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, Polycystic liver disease, and Amyloidosis.

Option B - Three recipients are benefitted from split liver transplantation:

  • Split Liver transplantation: 
    • The identification of separate units within the liver with unique blood supply, venous drainage and biliary drainage makes using a single deceased donor liver applicable for two recipients.
    • From brain dead cadaver, transplant the right lobe for the adult and the left lobe for the child. i.e. two recipients benefited.
    • The right lobe most commonly includes the donor vena cava and the right hepatic artery.
    • The pediatric graft is based on the celiac trunk providing the left hepatic artery, left portal vein and left hepatic vein.

Option C - Choledochojejunostomy is preferred over choledocho-choledochostomy:

  • Donor’s bile duct is anastomosed with recipient’s bile duct by choledochocholedochostomy (preferred)
  • If the recipient’s bile duct is diseased or cannot be used, the donor bile duct is attached to the jejunum (choledochojejunostomy).

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of worsening vision, redness, pain, light sensitivity, and discharge from his right eye. He reports undergoing a cataract operation in the same eye 7 months ago. Upon examination, the patient demonstrates the ability to perceive hand movements, along with lid swelling, chemosis, corneal edema, and hypopyon. Vitritis is observed along with the presence of inflammatory cells and exudates in the vitreous. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intravitreal antibiotic injections:

  • The clinical scenario described is suggestive of endophthalmitis, an acute postoperative complication of cataract surgery, which is a purulent inflammation of intraocular fluids usually due to infection. The hallmark feature of endophthalmitis is progressive vitritis, along with other signs and symptoms such as worsening vision, redness, pain, photophobia, blepharospasm, and discharge. On examination, findings such as lid swelling, chemosis, corneal edema, hypopyon, and vitritis further support the diagnosis.
  • The treatment of choice for endophthalmitis with the ability to perceive hand movements is intravitreal antibiotic injections, typically including ceftazidime and vancomycin. These antibiotics are effective in targeting the infection within the eye. Systemic antibiotics, such as quinolones, may be given for their higher ocular penetration. Pars plana vitrectomy is indicated when there is no hand movement vision.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pars plana vitrectomy: Pars plana vitrectomy is not the treatment of choice for endophthalmitis. It is indicated only when there is no hand movement vision, and the patient described in the scenario has worsening vision but still retains hand movement or better vision.

Option C - Systemic antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics, such as quinolones, may be given in cases of endophthalmitis to provide additional coverage. However, they are not the primary treatment of choice for this condition. Intravitreal antibiotic injections are preferred for targeted delivery and higher efficacy.

Option D - Cycloplegics and topical steroids: Cycloplegics and topical steroids are used in the management of associated uveitis, which can occur in conjunction with endophthalmitis. However, they are not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis itself.

questions.text: In which of the following phase of the cell cycle does the proofreading occur?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: S

  • The mismatched base pair's proofreading and repair occur in the S phase
  • The S phase of the cell cycle also involves duplication of the DNA.
  • DNA replication is carried out by DNA polymerase(I, III) and other enzymes(primase, ligase, helicase).
  • DNA polymerases have an intrinsic proofreading function that repairs the mistakes in DNA replication as they occur, but this process is not perfect.
  • The most common mistake involves mismatches in the pairing of DNA bases (instead of AT, GC pairing). This mistake is corrected after the duplication process by slicing the part of mismatched daughter DNA and repairing it by correctly copying the parent strand.
  • Mismatch repair occurs only in the S phase.
  • Defect in this mismatch repair process leads to Lynch (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) syndrome.

Incorrect options

Option A: G1

  • The G1 phase of the cell cycle involves preparing for the replication of DNA, but no duplication of DNA, and involves increasing the energy resources and replication machinery.
  • The G1 phase involves repairing DNA damage before DNA duplication by nucleotide and base excision repair.

Option C: G2

  • The G2 phase of the cell cycle involves the preparation of the cellular machinery and duplicated DNA for entering the M phase and the division of the nuclear and cytoplasmic material to form two cells.
  • Only base excision repair occurs in the G2 phase of the cell cycle.

Option D: M

  • M phase involves the division of nuclear material (karyokinesis) and cytoplasmic material (cytokinesis).
  • No repair can occur during the M phase.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate is presented to the emergency room with complaints of shortness of breath and respiratory distress. A plain erect chest X-ray is shown below. He is diagnosed as having a Bochdalek hernia. Which of the statements is most appropriate regarding this condition?

choices.text: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign
The contents of the hernial sac commonly includes the stomach or the small intestine
The condition is diagnosed prenatally by a CT scan
Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis

questions.solution:
Option D: Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis

  • Bochdalek hernia is a developmental defect in the posterolateral diaphragm that allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thorax, causing mechanical compression of the developing lung parenchyma and, in some cases, resulting in lung hypoplasia.
  • As a result, symptoms typically manifest in the paediatric age group and are respiratory
  • Adults with symptoms are diagnosed infrequently, with the vast majority of cases discovered by chance.
  • Although the exact cause is unknown, environmental and genetic factors are considered involved.
  • Multiple chronic conditions necessitate with Bochdalek hernia and congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) necessitate clinical surveillance and long-term follow-up.
  • A pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis.

Option A: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign

  • Abdominal contents herniate into the thorax, causing mechanical compression of the developing lung parenchyma and, in some cases, resulting in lung hypoplasia.
  • Therefore, early respiratory distress is a bad prognostic sign.

Option B: The contents of the hernial sac commonly includes the stomach or the small intestine

  • The contents of the hernial sac commonly include retroperitoneal fat, left kidney or spleen.

Option C: The condition is diagnosed prenatally by a CT scan

  • The condition is diagnosed prenatally by ultrasonography.
  • Exposure to ionizing radiation in utero, such as X-ray and CT scans, can lead to congenital malformations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a pruritic rash that developed over the past week. Physical examination reveals multiple tense bullae with surrounding erythema on her trunk, extremities, and mucosal surfaces. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) studies demonstrate a linear deposition of IgA along the basement membrane zone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Linear IgA disease:

  • Linear IgA disease is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the linear deposition of IgA along the basement membrane zone on DIF studies. It typically presents with a pruritic rash consisting of tense bullae with surrounding erythema, involving the trunk, extremities, and mucosal surfaces. Although the clinical presentation may overlap with other blistering diseases, such as bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris, the linear pattern of IgA deposition is characteristic of Linear IgA disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bullous pemphigoid: Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by sub-epidermal blistering. In bullous pemphigoid, direct immunofluorescence (DIF) studies show the deposition of IgG and/or C3 along the basement membrane zone, not IgA. This distinguishes it from Linear IgA disease, where IgA is specifically deposited in a linear pattern.

Option B - Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris is a potentially life-threatening autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by intraepidermal blistering. The DIF studies in pemphigus vulgaris reveal the deposition of IgG, not IgA, within the epidermis. In Linear IgA disease, the deposition of IgA is observed along the basement membrane zone.

Option C - Dermatitis herpetiformis: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic skin condition associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy, also known as celiac disease. DIF studies in dermatitis herpetiformis show granular deposition of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear pattern observed in Linear IgA disease. The characteristic histological finding in dermatitis herpetiformis is the presence of neutrophilic micro abscesses within the dermal papillae.

questions.text: A public health conference is being organized in a rural community to address various health issues prevalent in the region. As a community medicine healthcare provider, you are tasked with educating local healthcare workers about effective communication strategies for health promotion. During your session, you discuss different communication methods, including Socratic communication, to engage the audience and facilitate learning. Which among the following is not an example of Socratic communication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lecture:

  • Lectures primarily involve one-way communication where the speaker imparts knowledge without much interaction or engagement from the audience.
  • It is a form of didactic communication.
  • Socratic communication, on the other hand, emphasizes dialogue, questioning, and critical thinking to stimulate learning and understanding.
  • Example: Suppose there is a community, where there is a problem of domestic violence. To find out why this is happening, one can either do quantitative study design or qualitative.
    • Meaning, one can frame a questionnaire, where they can put 20 close ended questions such as are you a victim of domestic abuse, what is the reason, why is it happening, etc.
    • So, as an answer one will get it in numbers like 20 women say that husband drinks and beats them, 30 women say that family has expectations. So, this way one gets an answer in numbers.
  • Therefore, a lecture is NOT an example of Socratic communication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Panel discussion:

  • A panel discussion involves a group of experts who discuss a particular topic in front of an audience.
  • In a panel discussion, the moderator typically poses questions to the panelists, who then engage in dialogue, exchange ideas, and provide insights based on their expertise.
  • It is a form of two-way communication.
  • This format encourages interactive communication and critical thinking, making it an example of Socratic communication.

Option B - Symposium:

  • A symposium is a formal gathering where experts present their research or ideas on a specific topic.
  • It often includes a series of presentations followed by discussions or Q&A sessions.
  • While symposiums can vary in format, they typically promote dialogue and exchange of ideas among participants, resembling the principles of Socratic communication.

Option D - Workshop:

  • A workshop is an interactive session where participants engage in hands-on activities, discussions, and exercises to learn new skills or concepts.
  • Workshops often encourage active participation, problem-solving, and collaboration among participants, which are consistent with the principles of Socratic communication.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristic triad of symptoms seen in Miller Fisher Syndrome?

choices.text: Facial weakness, sensory loss, and autonomic dysfunction

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and areflexia:

  • Miller Fisher Syndrome (MFS) is characterized by a triad of symptoms, including ptosis , ophthalmoplegia), and areflexia . These features distinguish MFS from other neurological disorders. The presence of all three components of the triad is highly suggestive of MFS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diplopia, dysarthria, and ataxia: This combination of symptoms is not characteristic of Miller-Fisher Syndrome.

Option C - Facial weakness, sensory loss, and autonomic dysfunction: These symptoms are not typically part of the triad seen in MFS.

Option D - Tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia: These features are more consistent with Parkinson's disease and are not typical of MFS.

questions.text: In a busy metropolitan city, residents have been experiencing a surge in respiratory illnesses and complaints about poor air quality. As a community medicine practitioner, you are tasked with assessing the extent of air pollution and its potential health implications in the locality. During your investigation, you decide to utilize various indicators to evaluate the severity of air pollution. Which of the following is the best indicator of air pollution?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sulfur dioxide:

  • Sulfur dioxide is the best indicator of air pollution.
  • SO2 is a significant air pollutant primarily generated by the combustion of fossil fuels containing sulfur compounds, such as coal and oil, in power plants, industrial facilities, and vehicles.
  • Contribution of SO2 to air pollution:
    • Combustion Processes
    • Industrial Processes
    • Vehicle Emissions
  • Once sulfur dioxide is released into the atmosphere, it can undergo various chemical reactions to form secondary pollutants such as sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and sulfate (SO4) aerosols.
  • Other indicators of air pollution:
    • Smoke or soiling index: A specific amount of filtered air is filtered through a filter paper, and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter.
    • Grit and dust measurement: It checks the dust, grit deposits, and small particulate matter present in the air
    • Coefficient of haze: Measures smoke and other aerosols in air.
    • Air pollution index: A combined index that takes multiple air pollutants with upper limits into consideration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Carbon dioxide:

  • CO2 is the most commonly and widely distributed air pollutant.
  • It is, however, not an indicator of air pollution.

Option C - Carbon monoxide:

  • It is a primary air pollutant that is directly released into the air.
  • It is not an indicator of pollution.

Option D - Nitrogen dioxide:

  • NO2 and other nitrogen oxides in the outdoor air contribute to particle pollution.
  • It is also a primary air pollutant but is not an indicator of air pollution.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with unstable angina is referred to the cardiologist for further management. A review of medical records reveals that the patient's father and elder brother died at a young age due to complications of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Physical examination reveals the findings shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Familial hypercholesterolemia

  • The diagnosis in the above-given case with a positive family history of premature cardiovascular disease and Achilles tendon xanthoma is familial hypercholesterolemia type-IIa.
  • It is an autosomal dominant disease with defective or absent LDL receptors.
  • There is a high risk of premature atherosclerosis, which eventually leads to ischemic heart disease or myocardial infarction at a very early age.
  • It leads to arcus lipoides in the cornea, tuberous tendons xanthoma, and Achilles tendon xanthoma.
  • On lab investigation, patients presentswith massively increased cholesterol, VLDL, and LDL.

Important information on clinical features recognition to tackle hyperlipoproteinemia-related clinical questions

Clinical Feature Lipoprotein in plasma
Tendon xanthoma ↑ Cholesterol
Eruptive xanthoma ↑ TG
Palmar & Tubero eruptive xanthoma ↑ Chylo-remnant & ↑ VLDL remnant
Milky Plasma ↑ Chylomicrons
Acute pain in abdomen [Acute pancreatitis] ↑ TG

Incorrect options

Option B: Familial hyperchylomicronemia

  • LPL deficiency causes the elevation of TGs, chylomicron, and VLDL.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease that is caused by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Option C: Wolman's disease

  • Wolman's disease is a congenital disease that causes impaired metabolism of lipids.
  • It is caused by lysosomal acid lipase deficiency.
  • It can cause hepatosplenomegaly, steatorrhea, adrenal calcification, and abdominal distension.

Option D: Dysbeta-lipoproteinemia

  • It can cause cardiovascular disease.
  • It is caused by elevated serum cholesterol and triglycerides due to lipoprotein accumulation in apolipoprotein homozygotes.
  • It causes calve cramping, chest pain, toe sores, and stroke-like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is the best drug for a patient with infective endocarditis (due to Enterococcus spp) who is allergic to beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vancomycin:

  • Effective against Enterococci, especially Enterococcus faecalis, a common cause of infective endocarditis.
  • Optimal treatment includes a combination of Vancomycin with Streptomycin or Gentamicin for a 4-week course.
  • Penicillin allergy necessitates Vancomycin due to contraindications of Penicillin G and Ampicillin.
  • Mechanism: Inhibits cell wall synthesis by attaching to D-ala residues, preventing cross-linking of polymers.
  • Highly effective against MRSA and Enterococcal infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:

  • Contraindicated due to beta-lactam structure and risk of anaphylaxis.

Option B - Aztreonam:

  • Safe from allergic reactions but ineffective against Enterococci.

Option C - Cefazolin plus gentamicin:

  • Cefazolin contraindicated due to beta-lactam structure and risk of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the contraceptive efficacy of a new method among women aged 18-35 years in a rural community. The researchers followed up with the participants for  2.5 years. During this period, there were 23 accidental pregnancies recorded among 390 women who used the new method. Which among the following is the correct representation of the Pearl Index?

choices.text: Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1400
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1400

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200:

  • This is the correct representation of the Pearl Index.
  • The Pearl Index is a measure of contraceptive efficacy that indicates the number of pregnancies that occur per 100 woman-years of exposure while using a particular contraceptive method.
  • It is often used to compare the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods.
  • It is the most commonly used technique to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptives.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, D: These formulae are inaccurate regarding the Pearl index.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, revealing dilatation of the oesophagus with a narrowed distal oesophageal segment as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Achalasia cardia

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by impaired lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and absent peristalsis in the esophagus. The classic radiographic finding in achalasia is the "bird's beak" appearance, which represents the narrowed and tapered distal esophagus on a barium swallow study.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): GERD refers to the backward flow of gastric contents into the esophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn and regurgitation. It does not typically present with the "bird's beak" appearance seen in achalasia.It can lead to feline esophagus

Option C - Esophageal carcinoma: Apple core appearance is seen on a barium swallow study. Most common in the middle third.

Option D - Esophageal stricture: Eesophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the oesophageal lumen, usually due to chronic inflammation or scarring.

questions.text: A 25-year-old laboratory technician accidentally spilled a corrosive chemical over his arm while working. He immediately experiences pain and redness in the affected area. The chemical is identified as phenol. The patient seeks medical attention promptly. What is the most appropriate course of action for the management of the chemical burn caused by phenol exposure?

choices.text: Immediately neutralize the chemical with a base
Perform copious irrigation with water or saline for at least 20 minutes.
Apply a neutralizing agent directly to the burn site.
Remove contaminated clothing but keep jewelry on the affected area.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Perform copious irrigation with water or saline for at least 20 minutes:

  • In cases of chemical burns, copious irrigation with water or saline is the recommended initial step to dilute and remove the chemical from the affected area.
  • Immediately flush away the chemical with large amounts of warmed water, for at least 20 to 30 minutes, using a shower or hose. Alkali burns require longer irrigation. Alkali burns to the eye require continuous irrigation during the first 8 hours after the burn.
  • Low molecular weight polyethylene glycol (PEG) is the currently accepted decontamination fluid for phenol burns.  When LMW PEG is not available, flushing the exposed area with copious amounts of water for 20-30 minutes may be effective.
  • For phenol burns, which can lead to deeper tissue infiltration, proper and thorough irrigation is especially important. While the instinct might be to neutralize the chemical, this is not advised as it can lead to exothermic reactions and worsen the injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A-Immediately neutralize the chemical with water or saline: This choice is not recommended for chemical burns. Attempting to neutralize the chemical immediately can cause exothermic reactions, which can lead to further tissue damage and injury.

Option C-Apply a neutralizing agent directly to the burn site: Applying a neutralizing agent directly to the burn site is not advised. It can lead to exothermic reactions and further injury. Copious irrigation with water or saline is the preferred method to remove the chemical.

Option D-Remove contaminated clothing but keep jewelry on the affected area: Contaminated clothing should be promptly removed from the burn area to prevent further chemical exposure. Jewelry should also be removed to allow thorough irrigation and assessment of the burn.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high-grade fever and neck pain. He was suffering from an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, his thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and tender. Laboratory analysis shows elevated leukocytes and ESR. After a thorough clinical evaluation, de Quervain's thyroiditis is diagnosed. Which of the following is the feature of de-Quervain thyroiditis?

choices.text: In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses
Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology
Bacterial infection is a trigger in most patients
It is the most common cause of painful, multinodular thyroid

questions.solution:
Correct Option :

Option A. In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses

De Quervain's thyroiditis, also known as subacute granulomatous thyroiditis or giant cell thyroiditis, is a self-limiting inflammatory disorder of the thyroid gland. In the early phase of the disease, there is disruption of thyroid follicles, which are replaced by neutrophils, forming microabscesses. This acute inflammatory process is responsible for the symptoms of fever, neck pain, and tenderness in patients with de Quervain's thyroiditis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology (Incorrect): Orphan Annie nuclei are associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, not De Quervain's thyroiditis.

Option C: Bacterial infection is a trigger in most patients (Incorrect): De Quervain's thyroiditis is usually preceded by a viral upper respiratory tract infection, not a bacterial infection.

Option D: It is the most common cause of painful, multinodular thyroid (Incorrect): De Quervain's thyroiditis typically presents with a diffuse, tender thyroid gland rather than a multinodular thyroid. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an example of a condition that can lead to a painful, multinodular thyroid.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male known case of hypertension and diabetes for the past 25 years comes to the emergency department with a complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath. Despite acute management, the patient dies soon of congestive heart failure. The cause of this condition is an atheromatous plaque that ruptured, leading to acute thrombosis. Which among the following is a component of such plaque?
questions.solution:
Option A: Macrophages

  • Atherosclerosis is characterised by the increasing buildup of inflammatory cells, hyperplastic smooth muscle cells, lipids, and connective tissue in the intima of large and medium-sized elastic and muscular arteries.
  • The lipid plaque (atheroma), the ensuing distinctive lesion, is composed of many lipid-filled macrophages (foam cells) and extracellular lipid pools.
  • It is not an immediate inflammatory process or an infectious one.
  • Four main elements make up atherosclerotic plaques: cells, including varying numbers of smooth muscle cells, macrophages, and T lymphocytes; extracellular matrix (ECM), which contains collagen, elastic fibres, and proteoglycans; intracellular and extracellular lipids; and, in later stages of plaque development, calcifications.

Option B: Eosinophils

  • A unique vasculitis of small dermal arteries heavily infiltrated with eosinophils is known as cutaneous necrotising eosinophilic vasculitis with hypocomplementemia and eosinophilia. Connective tissue disease patients may develop this type of vasculitis.
  • However, eosinophils are not a component of atherosclerosis plaques.

Option C: Magnesium

  • Atherosclerosis is the buildup of plaque in and on your artery walls, which can restrict blood flow. Soft plaques change and eventually calcify due to calcium deposition, becoming hard plaques.
  • Magnesium is not involved in the formation of atherosclerosis plaques.

Option D: IgA

  • Granular deposition of IgA in vessels due to an aberrant immune response results in IgA vasculitis. Inflammation in the skin's tiny blood vessels is the outcome.
  • Additionally, impacted blood arteries maybe those in the bowels, kidneys, or joints. It's not obvious why this happens.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with watery eyes accompanied by mild discomfort with a gritty feeling for the past 3 days. The patient recently had a respiratory tract infection. The Ophthalmologist performs syringing and says that the patient's lacrimal drainage system is normal. Which etiology is commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Viral conjunctivitis:

  • In this clinical scenario, a patient presents with watery eyes and mild discomfort, accompanied by a recent respiratory tract infection, and normal lacrimal drainage. The commonly associated etiology is viral conjunctivitis. 
  • The fact that the patient recently had a respiratory tract infection is a clue pointing toward a viral etiology.
  • Viral conjunctivitis, often caused by adenoviruses, can manifest with symptoms such as redness, tearing, irritation, and discharge. It may occur in isolation or as part of a viral prodrome, with concurrent systemic symptoms like fever and upper respiratory symptoms.
  • It is highly contagious and can be transmitted through direct contact with the patient and their secretions. It presents with watery or mucoserous discharge and a burning, gritty or sandy sensation. It can start as a unilateral infection but eventually affects the other eye.
  • On examination, the tarsal conjunctiva may have a follicular appearance. It is mostly self-limiting and will take around 2-3 weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bacterial conjunctivitis: Bacterial conjunctivitis typically presents with a purulent or mucopurulent discharge, which is inconsistent with the watery discharge described in the scenario.

Option B - Chlamydial conjunctivitis: Chlamydial conjunctivitis is more commonly associated with a mucopurulent discharge rather than a watery discharge. It is often seen in individuals with a history of sexual exposure or genital infections.

Option D - Allergic conjunctivitis: Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by a watery discharge, which aligns with the symptom described in the scenario. However, the association with a recent respiratory tract infection suggests a viral etiology rather than an allergic one.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with a high risk of pseudomembranous colitis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clindamycin

  • Clindamycin can cause psuedomembranous enterocolitis(Clostridium difficile)
  • Clindamycin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis (via inhibition of translocation).
  • It is effective against anaerobic organisms.
  • It is secreted in bile, therefore, can be used safely in patients with renal dysfunction.

Option A: Clarithromycin

  • The risk of pseudomembranous colitis with clarithromycin is very less as compared to clindamycin.

Option C: Minocycline

  • The risk of pseudomembranous colitis with minocycline is very less as compared to clindamycin.

Option D: Fidaxomicin

  • Oral Fidaxomicin is a first line agent for treating pseudomembranous colitis

questions.text: A 43-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with a headache and muscle weakness. She has had such symptoms for the past 3 months. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg, her temperature is 98°F, pulse rate is 90 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 17 per minute. On abdominal examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. The laboratory finding shows hypokalemia. Measurement of her arterial blood gases reveals a pH of 7.5 and bicarbonate of 32 mmHg. Her serum cortisol and urinary Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) are normal, but her serum aldosterone is increased. Her plasma renin activity is also decreased. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hypertension?
questions.solution:
Option C: Conn syndrome

  • This female patient, who mainly presented with hypertension, elevated aldosterone, and hypokalemia, has most likely Conn syndrome.
  • Laboratory findings show metabolic alkalosis, elevated serum aldosterone, and decreased plasma renin activity. These all are consistent with conn syndrome.
  • Conn syndrome is also called primary hyperaldosteronism. In this syndrome, there are very high levels of aldosterone, which causes increased sodium absorption, leading to increased blood pressure.
  • Due to higher levels of aldosterone, there is increased secretion of potassium which leads to hypokalemia, which plays an important role in muscle weakness.
  • Due to higher levels of aldosterone, there is an increased hydrogen ion secretion, which leads to metabolic alkalosis.
  • Due to increased blood pressure, there would be decreased renin secretion due to increased renal perfusion pressure.

 Option A: Cushing syndrome

  • Cushing syndrome is ruled out because serum cortisol is normal in the patient. Because serum cortisol and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) should be increased in Cushing syndrome and Cushing disease.

Option B: Renal artery stenosis

  • In renal artery stenosis, hypertension occurs due to decreased caliber of renal arteries.
  • Due to decreased renal perfusion, there would be increased secretion of plasma renin activity, but in this patient, plasma renin activities decreased, so this option is ruled out easily.

Option D: Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytoma is characterized by episodic hypertension and episodic headache.
  • The patient can also complain of muscle weakness, but the patient should have increased urinary excretion of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) versus this patient having normal urinary excretion of VMA.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a complaint of recurrent folliculitis on the scalp. The folliculitis is characterized by the presence of small, red, tender papules and pustules with surrounding erythema. On further examination, head lice infestation is detected. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism by which head lice infestation can lead to recurrent folliculitis?

choices.text: Direct bacterial infection from head lice
Allergic reaction to head lice saliva
Obstruction of hair follicles by head lice eggs (nits)
Inflammatory response to head lice feces

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Obstruction of hair follicles by head lice eggs (nits):

  • Head lice infestation can lead to recurrent folliculitis on the scalp. The presence of head lice eggs (nits) can obstruct the hair follicles, leading to inflammation and recurrent infection. The papules, pustules, and surrounding erythema seen in folliculitis are a result of this obstruction and subsequent bacterial infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D:Direct bacterial infection from head lice, an allergic reaction to head lice saliva, and the inflammatory response to head lice feces are not the primary mechanisms leading to recurrent folliculitis in head lice infestation. Therefore, option C is the most likely mechanism in this scenario.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with multiple bruises and weight loss, with palpable spleen and liver. The physician observed decreased hemoglobin, platelets, and fibrinogen levels, along with increased white blood cells. Cytogenetic analysis revealed a reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17. The patient was later prescribed 6-mercaptopurine. Which of the following is true about this drug

choices.text: It is metabolized by xanthine oxidase
Its dose should be increased when allopurinol is given concurrently
It is converted into an active metabolite by xanthine oxidase

questions.solution:
Option A: It is metabolized by xanthine oxidase

  • 6-mercaptopurine is a purine antagonist that inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by substituting DNA/RNA purines with itself.
  • It is a purine and is metabolized by xanthine oxidase

Incorrect Options:

Option B: It does not cause hyperuricemia

  • 6-mercaptopurine is an anticancer drug.
  • All anti-cancer drugs can result in hyperuricemia by causing the destruction of cells and the release of purines.

Option C: Its dose should be increased when allopurinol is given concurrently

  • Since 6-MP is metabolized by xanthine oxidase, allopurinol (being a xanthine oxidase inhibitor) would lead to a buildup of 6-MP. This would require a decrease in 6-MP dosage to prevent toxicity
  • Thus the dose of oral 6-MP is to be reduced by 75% when allopurinol is given concurrently.

Option D: It is converted into an active metabolite by xanthine oxidase

  • Xanthine oxidase converts it into an inactive metabolite.

questions.text: Which of the following periods of development is termed the embryonic stage?
questions.solution:
Option D: 3rd week up to 8 weeks

  • The embryonic stage is from 3-8 weeks
  • The embryonic period extends from the beginning of the third week to the end of the eighth week of intrauterine life.

Stages of prenatal development

  • Germinal stage (02 weeks):
    • Fertilization to differentiation of germ layers
    • The germinal stage is the gestation period from fertilization or conception, when the egg cell meets the sperm, to the embryo implantation in the uterus
  • Embryonic stage (3-8 weeks):
    • Changes in shape/external appearance of embryo
    • Individual differentiation of germ layers
    • Formation of tissues and organs
    • The embryonic period extends from the beginning of the third week to the end of the eighth week of intrauterine life.
  • Fetal stage (9 weeks to birth):
    • Rapid growth of fetus and complete development of placenta
    • As soon as cell differentiation is complete, the embryo enters the next stage and is called the fetus. The fetal phase of prenatal development marks more essential changes in the brain. This development phase begins. In the ninth week and lasts until birth.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complains of difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds, such as birds chirping or the ringing of a phone. Which part of the auditory pathway is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Superior olivary complex

  • The superior olivary complex is an important structure in the auditory pathway involved in sound localization and processing of auditory signals.
  • It receives information from both ears and helps in comparing and integrating sound inputs to determine the location of the sound source.
  • Difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds can be attributed to a problem in the superior olivary complex since it plays a role in analyzing different frequency components of sound.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cochlear Nucleus:

  • The cochlear nucleus is one of the early stages in the auditory pathway where the signals from the cochlea are first processed. It is responsible for receiving and processing auditory information from the cochlea.
  • However, difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds is unlikely to be directly related to a problem in the cochlear nucleus.

Option C - Inferior colliculus:

  • The inferior colliculus is another important structure in the auditory pathway located in the midbrain.
  • It receives auditory information from the superior olivary complex and is involved in further processing and routing of sound signals to higher auditory centers.
  • While the inferior colliculus is important for sound processing, it is less likely to be the primary site of difficulty in understanding high-frequency sounds.

Option D - Medial geniculate body:

  • The medial geniculate body is part of the thalamus and serves as a relay station for auditory information between the inferior colliculus and the auditory cortex. It helps in processing and transmitting auditory signals to the auditory cortex for further analysis and perception.
  • Difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds is less likely to be directly associated with a problem in the medial geniculate body.

questions.text: Which of the following is the neurotransmitter released by inner hair cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glutamate:

  • Glutamate is the neurotransmitter released by inner hair cells. When the inner hair cells depolarize in response to sound, voltage-gated calcium channels open, allowing calcium to enter the cell. This influx of calcium triggers the release of glutamate, which excites the auditory nerve fibers connected to the inner hair cells, initiating the transmission of auditory information to the brain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GABA:

  • GABA is not released by inner hair cells. It is a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, acting to decrease neuronal excitability.

Option C - Glycine:

  • Glycine is not released by inner hair cells. It serves as both an inhibitory and excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, mainly inhibiting neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.

Option D - Acetylcholine:

  • Acetylcholine is not released by inner hair cells. It functions as a neurotransmitter in various parts of the nervous system, including the neuromuscular junction and autonomic nervous system, but not in the auditory pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most appropriate to sterilize devices that come in contact with mucous membranes according to the Spaulding Classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - High-Level Disinfection (HLD):

  • The Spaulding classification stratifies the risk of infection transmission based on the patient tissue the device contacts during use. Devices that come in contact with mucous membranes are semi-critical devices.
  • Semi-critical devices require a high level of disinfection to ensure the elimination of all vegetative bacteria, mycobacteria, fungi, and most viruses, but not necessarily bacterial spores. High-level disinfection (HLD) is a reprocessing method sterilizing using heat if the device is heat stable or chemical (glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, and chlorine) if heat sensitive that achieves this level of disinfection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intermediate-Level Disinfection (ILD): Intermediate-Level Disinfection is used for non-critical devices 

Option C - Low-Level Disinfection (LLD): Low-Level Disinfection is used for Non-Critical Devices that come in contact with the skin. LLD aims to reduce the number of viable microorganisms on these devices but does not achieve the same level of disinfection as HLD.

Option D - Dry Heat Sterilization: Dry Heat Sterilization is a method used for Critical Devices that can withstand high temperatures. It is not commonly used for Semi-Critical Devices, as it is generally reserved for devices that require complete sterilization.

questions.text: What is the name of this instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube:

  • The image shows the Sengstaken-Blakemore (SB) tube.
  • The Sengstaken-Blakemore (SB) tube is used to halt or delay esophageal and stomach bleeding.
  • The bleeding is usually caused by stomach or esophageal varices and enlarged veins produced by restricted blood flow.
  • The SB tube includes three ports at one end, each with a different function: esophageal balloon port, which inflates a tiny balloon in the esophagus; gastric aspiration port, which takes fluid and air from the stomach; gastric balloon port, which inflates a balloon in the stomach.
  • Two balloons are attached to the other end of the SB tube. These balloons are inflated, applying pressure to the bleeding sites to stop bleeding
  • To reach the stomach, the tube is usually placed by the mouth, but it can also be inserted through the nose. Once the bleeding has stopped, it can be removed.
  • The use of the SB tube comes with some dangers. The treatment may cause discomfort, especially if the tube is put in through the mouth, which could cause a sore throat.
  • The SB tube's placement could impair the ability to breathe.

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ryle’s tube:

  • Ryle’s (Nasogastric) tube is a single-use polyvinyl chloride tube that can be used for treatment and diagnosis.
  • It is used to aspirate gastric contents in hematemesis, intestinal obstruction, post-surgery, and gastric acid aspiration for gastric function tests.
  • It is used for barium examinations in the radiology division. For giardiasis diagnosis, it may pass in the duodenum.

 

 

Option B - Red rubber catheter:

  • Red rubber catheters are a form of intermittent catheter used to treat urine retention.
  • They work similarly to straight catheters, except they are constructed of red rubber latex rather than plastic.
  • It makes the red rubber catheter more flexible, which some individuals prefers.

 

 

Option D - Nelaton’s catheter:

  • Nelaton catheters are straight tube-like catheters with one hole at the tip and a connector at the other end for drainage.
  • The proximal end has a connector in the shape of a funnel for a secure connection to the urine bag.
  • These single-use male Nelaton catheters are designed for men who prefer the straight Nelaton tip and are intended for intermittent catheterization.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath for the last three months. Her chest auscultation reveals a " blowing murmur" of relatively high pitch and is heard maximally over the left ventricle. An X-ray chest shows an enlarged heart, and arterial pressure in the aorta is 140/50 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Aortic valve regurgitation

  • Based on the symptoms of shortness of breath for the last three months, blowing murmur of relatively high pitch over the left ventricle, and enlarged heart on x-ray point towards aortic valve regurgitation.
  • Blowing murmurs of relatively high pitch are usually heard in valvular insufficiency.
  • Aortic valve regurgitation has a high pulse pressure (SBP - DBP), as seen in this case (90 mmHg).
  • Due to leakage of blood back into the left ventricle during diastole, the diastolic pressure decreases to a very low value (50 mmHg).
  • The aortic valve regurgitation is shown below:

Option A: Pulmonary valve stenosis

  • Mild pulmonary stenosis is asymptomatic.
  • Severe pulmonary stenosis may experience symptoms during exercise. A  whooshing sound (murmur) could be heard with a stethoscope.

Option B: Aortic valve stenosis

  • The murmur of aortic stenosis is a high-pitched, "diamond-shaped" crescendo-decrescendo, midsystolic ejection murmur.
  • It is best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the neck and carotid arteries.

Option C: Mitral valve stenosis

  • A pan systolic murmur could be heard in mitral valve stenosis.

questions.text: What is the initial visible pubertal change in females?
questions.solution:
Option A : Thelarche

  • The first pubertal sign in females is a growth spurt.
  • The puberty-specific event which comes in first is thelarche & then pubarche, peak growth velocity and menarche.
  • The pubertal development in girls typically takes place over 4.5 years.
  • The breast budding (called thelarche) is usually the first visible pubertal change, then after that, the peak growth velocity, appearance of pubic hair, and menarche.
  • Initially, the stages described by Marshall and Tanner are used to describe pubic hair development and breast.
  • NOTE : This is from Novak’s gynaecology, and hence we should see what is asked in the question. Mostly, the questions are asked for the 'first specific sign' of puberty, and breast budding is the answer, but if “growth spurt’ is given and the question is non-specific, then that’s the option.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Menarche

  • The occurrence of the first menstrual cycle in females is called menarche.
  • It occurs between the ages of 10-16 years and appears last in the signs of puberty.

Option C: Adrenarche

  • It happens before menarche.
  • It causes the development of pubic and axillary hair

Option D: Peak growth velocity

  • The first pubertal sign in females is a growth spurt.
  • The puberty-specific event that comes in first is thelarche & then pubarche, peak growth velocity, and menarche.

questions.text:
A recent outbreak of dengue fever has been reported in a densely populated urban area. As part of the public health response, vector control measures are being implemented. Match the following mosquitoes with their most likely breeding sites.


	
		
			
			Insects
			
			
			Breeding places
			
		
		
			
			1. Anopheles
			
			
			a. Dirty, polluted water
			
		
		
			
			2. Culex
			
			
			b. Artificially collected water
			
		
		
			
			3. Aedes
			
			
			c. Clean, stagnant water
			
		
		
			
			4. Mansonia
			
			
			d. Large water bodies with aquatic plantations
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-c,2-a,3-b,4-d:

  1. Anopheles, the primary vector for malaria, prefers breeding sites with stagnant water bodies, such as ponds and marshes.
  2. Culex, the vector for diseases like West Nile virus, Japanese encephalitis, and lymphatic filariasis, commonly breeds in dirty and polluted water sources such as drains, septic tanks, and sewage systems.
  3. Aedes aegypti, the primary vector for dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever, typically breeds in artificially collected water like flower pots, buckets, and discarded tires.
  4. Mansonia, the vector for Brugia malayi, prefers large water bodies with aquatic plants such as lakes.

Incorrect Options

Option B - 1-a,2-c,3-d,4-b

Option C - 1-d,2-a,3-b,4-c

Option D - 1-c,2-d,3-a,4-b

  • These do not indicate the correct matches between the mosquitoes and their breeding sites.

questions.text:
Match the following appropriately


	
		
			
			1. Acute monoblastic leukaemia
			
			
			A. M0
			
		
		
			
			2. AML without maturation
			
			
			B. M2
			
		
		
			
			3. Acute myelomonocytic Leukaemia
			
			
			C. M5
			
		
		
			
			4. AML with minimal diﬀerentiation
			
			
			D. M4
			
		
		
			 
			
			E. M1
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-C, 2-E,3-D,4-A:

  • Acute monoblastic leukaemia: M5
  • AML without maturation: M1
  • Acute myelomonocytic Leukaemia: M4
  • AML with minimal diﬀerentiation: M0

Incorrect Options:

Option B,C,D are incorrect match

questions.text: Which one of the following toxins and their respective mode of action are correctly matched with corresponding food poisoning type?

choices.text: Nhe toxins → secretory diarrhea → Emetic type
Nhe toxins → Vagomimetic action → Diarrheal type

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cereulide → Vagomimetic action → Emetic type:

  • Cereulide is produced by certain strains of Bacillus cereus and is associated with emetic-type food poisoning, which leads to vomiting. Cereulide exerts its emetic (vomiting) effect through its vagomimetic action, affecting the vagus nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cereulide → Vagomimetic action → Diarrheal type:

  • This option incorrectly matches cereulide with diarrheal type of food poisoning, which is associated with emetic-type food poisoning (vomiting)

ion C - Nhe toxins → secretory diarrhea → Emetic type:

  • This option incorrectly matches Nhe toxins with the emetic type of food poisoning. Nhe toxins are indeed associated with the diarrheal type of food poisoning, not emetic, and they cause watery diarrhea rather than emetic symptoms.

Option D - Nhe toxins → Vagomimetic action → Diarrheal type:

  • This option incorrectly matches Nhe toxins with vagomimetic action and associates it with the diarrheal type of food poisoning. While Nhe toxins do cause diarrhea, their mode of action is not vagomimetic; instead, they lead to secretory diarrhea by affecting the small intestine.

questions.text: In which of the followingphase of spermatogenesis does reduction in the chromosomal number to half the original number occur?
questions.solution:
Option B: Meiosis - I

  • Meiosis is a process where a single cell divides twice to produce four cells containing half the original amount of genetic information.
  • The first meiotic division is the reduction division, and each primary spermatocyte yields two secondary spermatocytes.
  • Each secondary spermatocyte contains 23 (Haploid) chromosomes consisting of two varieties, 22+X and 22+Y. Here 22 are autosomes, and X & Y are sex chromosomes.

Option A: During mitosis

  • Mitosis is a process in which the cell undergoes division to produce offspring.
  • In mitosis, daughter cells have the same chromosomes as the parent (diploid).
  • During the initial phase of spermatogenesis, the spermatogonia undergoes continuous mitosis division until the formation of the primary spermatocyte.

Option C: Meiosis - II

  • During spermatogenesis, the PGCs (Primordial germ cells or spermatogonia) undergo several mitotic divisions to form primary spermatocytes.
  • Primary spermatocyte after meiosis I →  two secondary spermatocytes (with 4 haploid chromosomes) → Meiosis II→ four haploid daughter cells.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents a 6-week history of fever, weight loss, and fatigue. Her temperature is 38.7° C (103° F), her pulse rate is 110 per minute, and her blood pressure is 144/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals petechiae and clubbing of fingers. The patient develops mental changes, suffers a massive stroke and dies. The mitral valve is examined during the autopsy (shown in the picture). Which of the following pathological diagnosis is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bacterial endocarditis

  • In this case, the mitral valve has destructive vegetation that has been eroded through the free edges of the valve leaflets.
  • Vegetations in bacterial endocarditis form on the atrial side of the atrioventricular valves and the ventricular side of the semilunar valves, often at the occlusion points of the cusps or cusps.
  • They are made up of platelets, fibrin, cell debris and masses of organisms.
  • The underlying valve tissue is damaged, so the leaflet is perforated and regurgitated.
  • The disease begins with nonspecific symptoms such as low fever, fatigue, anorexia, and weight loss.

Option B:Carcinoid heart disease

  • Carcinoid heart disease affects the right side of the heart and causes tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary stenosis.
  • It occurs in the advanced form of carcinoid syndrome.
  • This syndrome occurs due to a carcinoid tumor that secretes serotonin and other chemicals into the bloodstream.
  • It involves the right-sided heart walls and eventually leads to right heart failure.

Option C: Libman-Sacks endocarditis

  • Libman-sacks endocarditis is a form of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis.
  • It most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves.
  • The vegetation has the following characteristics:
  • Small and firm
  • Friable
  • Tan masses
  • Broad base
  • The lesions are small (1 to 4 mm in diameter), single or multiple, sterile, pink vegetations with a warty (verrucous) appearance.
  • They may be located on the undersurfaces of the atrioventricular valves, on the valvular endocardium, on the chords, or on the mural endocardium of atria or ventricles.
  • Vegetations are small, sterile, and firm and commonly affect the valve's lower surface.
  • Hypercoagulable states are the usual precursor to NBTE.
  • These include APLA syndrome, SLE, chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy, particularly mucinous adenocarcinomas.

Option D: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse and congenital heart defects are the most common causes of bacterial endocarditis in adults today.
  • It is a type of valvular heart disease in which the valve between the left atrium and left ventricle does not close completely, resulting in a backward blood flow.
  • Mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation.
  • It results in the following:
  • Arrhythmia
  • Heart murmur
  • Dyspnea
  • Palpitations
  • Oedema

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old patient presenting with sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and vomiting without hearing loss or tinnitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vestibular neuronitis:

  • Vestibular neuronitis is characterized by sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and vomiting without associated hearing loss or tinnitus. It is caused by inflammation of the vestibular nerve and usually lasts for a few days to weeks. The absence of hearing loss distinguishes it from other inner ear disorders.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV):

  • BPPV is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by certain head movements. It is often associated with a dislodged otolith (calcium carbonate crystals) in the inner ear. Unlike vestibular neuronitis, BPPV typically involves positional vertigo and may be accompanied by transient hearing loss or tinnitus.

Option B - Ménière's disease:

  • Ménière's disease is a chronic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Unlike vestibular neuronitis, Ménière's disease typically presents with hearing loss and tinnitus along with vertigo.

Option D - Labyrinthitis:

  • Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the labyrinth, which includes the cochlea (involved in hearing) and the vestibular system (involved in balance). It typically presents with vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Unlike vestibular neuronitis, labyrinthitis is associated with hearing loss.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with bilateral parotitis and unilateral orchitis. Suspected to be a viral infection, when is this infection most communicable?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1 week before symptom onset:

  • The provided information is characteristic of mumps virus infection. Mumps is known for its clinical features, including bilateral parotitis (the most common manifestation) and unilateral orchitis (the most common complication, which does not lead to sterility). The infection can also lead to complications such as oophoritis in females, pancreatitis, aseptic meningitis, and even atypical cases that directly present as meningitis without parotid involvement.
  • Mumps virus is most communicable during the period of 1 week before symptom onset to 1 week after the symptoms appear. This is when the virus is shed in respiratory secretions and is most likely to be transmitted to others.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis where slit lamp examination reveals bilateral corneal deposits arranged in a whorl-like pattern in a female with a history of long-term usage of indomethacin for rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vortex keratopathy:

  • Vortex keratopathy, also known as corneal verticillata or whorl keratopathy, is characterized by the deposition of medications(drugs) or other substances in a vortex or whorl-like pattern on the corneal epithelium. It is commonly associated with the long-term use of certain medications, such as indomethacin, amiodarone, chloroquine, and tamoxifen. The corneal deposits in vortex keratopathy are usually asymptomatic but can cause blurred vision and sensitivity to light in some case

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a viral infection caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. It typically presents with a painful rash, vesicles, and redness in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Corneal involvement in herpes zoster ophthalmicus can manifest as dendritic ulcers or geographic lesions, rather than the characteristic whorl-like pattern seen in vortex keratopathy. Therefore, this is not the most likely diagnosis in the given scenario.

Option C - Keratoconjunctivitis sicca: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye syndrome, is a condition characterized by inadequate production of aqueous layer of tear film, leading to ocular surface dryness and irritation. It commonly presents with symptoms of dryness, grittiness, and blurred vision. Although dry eye syndrome can cause corneal changes and opacities, they do not typically exhibit the specific whorl-like pattern observed in vortex keratopathy. Therefore, this is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Option D - Band keratopathy: Band keratopathy is a condition characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the cornea, typically in a horizontal band-like pattern. It commonly occurs in conditions associated with hypercalcemia or long-standing uveitis. The corneal deposits in band keratopathy are usually seen in the mid-peripheral or peripheral cornea, rather than the characteristic whorl-like pattern seen in vortex keratopathy. Hence, this is not the most likely diagnosis in the given scenario.

questions.text: A 4-month-old female infant presents to the surgical outpatient department with a bilateral cleft lip deformity known before birth by 3D ultrasound. She is ready for her initial cleft repair as she is four months old. Subsequently, complete cleft lip repair surgery has been scheduled under general anaesthesia. Which surgical technique can be used for bilateral cleft lip repair?
questions.solution:
Option C: Millard method

  • A bilateral cleft lip is a common congenital disability in which a baby's lip does not form properly, resulting in splits (clefts) on both sides of the lip.

  • Bilateral complete cleft lip, previously treated with nasoalveolar molding, is repaired with the Millard-Mulliken technique, which employs the orbicularis oris muscle reconstruction by advancing bilateral muscular segments.
  • The Millard bilateral cleft lip repair technique provides a philtrum of proper width, a lip of appropriate height, a full-depth labial sulcus, and complete muscle continuity.
  • Transposition of pro-labium is not required in the definitive lip repair into the nose floor and permits subsequent columellar construction.
  • The operation meets all the requirements of a good technique for lip repair and has become popular for repairing primary clefts of the lip.

Option A: Bardach's Method

  • This is a modification of the von Langenbeck technique in which the incision is made along the cleft and alveolar margins.
  • These are joined anteriorly to free the mucoperiosteal flaps.
  • These flaps are based on the greater palatine vessels.
  • The soft palate is repaired in a straight line.
  • The levator palatini muscle dissection and reconstruction of the muscle sling are performed as in intravelar veloplasty.

Option B:  Langenbeck Method

  • It is a palatoplasty method using mucoperiosteal flaps to repair the hard palate region.

Option D: Wardill Method

  • Wardill's method is used in cleft palate surgery.
  • Until a few years back, this procedure was the commonest palatoplasty technique. 
  • In this technique, the V-Y procedure is performed so that the whole mucoperiosteal flap and the soft palate are retroposed and the palate is lengthened.
  • However, it leaves an extensive raw area anteriorly and laterally along the alveolar margin with exposed bare membranous bone.
  • The raw area heals with secondary intention. 
  • This causes shortening of the palate and results in velopharyngeal incompetence. 
  • The raw area adjacent to the alveolar margin also results in alveolar arch deformity and dental malalignment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, has been experiencing joint pain, stiffness, and swelling in her hands and feet for several months. She finds it challenging to perform her daily activities due to the discomfort and decreased range of motion in her joints. She visits her rheumatologist, who suspects an autoimmune disorder based on her symptoms and physical examination. After careful evaluation, the rheumatologist prescribes a medication that inhibits the enzyme Dehydro Orotate Dehydrogenase. Based on the information provided, which drug has the rheumatologist prescribed for this patients condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Leflunomide:

  • This option is the correct answer. Leflunomide is a DMARD that inhibits Dehydro Orotate Dehydrogenase, an enzyme responsible for de-novo pyrimidine synthesis. By inhibiting this enzyme, Leflunomide decreases T and B cell proliferation and exhibits immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory effects, making it effective in managing Rheumatoid Arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Methotrexate: This option is not the correct answer. While Methotrexate is a DMARD used in the treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis, its mechanism of action involves inhibiting Dihydrofolate Reductase, not Dehydro Orotate Dehydrogenase.

Option B - Sulfasalazine: This option is not the correct answer. Sulfasalazine is another conventional DMARD used in the treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis, but it does not inhibit Dehydro Orotate Dehydrogenase. Sulfasalazine splits into 5-ASA and Sulfapyridine, which have anti-inflammatory properties.

Option D - Hydroxychloroquine: This option is not the correct answer. Hydroxychloroquine has anti-inflammatory effects but contains lower efficacy compared to other DMARDs. While it may be used in Rheumatoid Arthritis treatment, it does not inhibit Dehydro Orotate Dehydrogenase like Leflunomide.

questions.text: A pilot comes to the outpatient department with complaints of headache and blurred vision from the last six months. In history, he says that he has just started flying the aircraft a few months back; afterward, he has a blurring of vision. He also has a history of one episode of unconsciousness. The doctor suspects that it could be due to the high altitude. Which of the following is the manifestation/feature of a "negative G" in the human body?

choices.text: The hydrostatic pressure in the veins of the lower limb increases

questions.solution:
Option D: The cerebral arterial pressure rises

  • In this case, the patient is a pilot with symptoms due to high altitude.
  • Gravitational force (Positive G) would cause the pooling of blood in the veins of the lower extremities, causing an increase in hydrostatic pressure in the inferior limb veins.
  • Also, this pooling will decrease the venous return to the heart, and the Cardiac output will decrease.
  • It will lead to a decrease in the blood flow and perfusion pressure in the cerebral vessels, resulting in a "blackout" (failure of vision followed by unconsciousness).
  • Negative (-) "G" will have the opposite effect.
  • Blood will be shifted towards the head; there will be an increased cardiac output and a rise in cerebral arterial pressure.
  • Congestion of retinal blood vessels and mental confusion will cause a “red-out”.

Option A: The hydrostatic pressure in the veins of the lower limb increases

  • Gravitational force (Positive(+) G) would cause the pooling of blood in the veins of the lower extremities, causing an increase in hydrostatic pressure in the inferior limb veins.
  • This is the feature of Positive G.

Option B: The cardiac output decreases

  • Gravitational force will cause the pooling of blood in veins.
  • This pooling will decrease the venous return to the heart, and the cardiac output will decrease.

Option C: Blackout occurs

  • Gravitational force can decrease blood flow and perfusion pressure in the cerebral vessels, resulting in a "blackout" (failure of vision followed by unconsciousness).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology department complaining of a miscarriage in her previous pregnancy 4 months back. She needs help regarding preconception counselling. She has been married for 1 year and wishes to conceive again. However, her pelvic ultrasound confirms a congenital uterine abnormality. Which of the following is the most likely one?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. Septate uterus

Explanation:

A septate uterus is a congenital uterine abnormality where the uterine cavity is divided by a septum, resulting in a shape resembling a heart or two separate cavities. This condition can lead to recurrent miscarriages and preterm births due to poor implantation of the embryo. Surgical intervention in the form of hysteroscopic septum resection can improve reproductive outcomes for women with a septate uterus.

 

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH): This condition involves the absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. It is not characterized by a septum within the uterus.

Option B. Unicornuate uterus: In a unicornuate uterus, one side of the uterus is absent or underdeveloped, leading to a smaller uterus. It is not characterized by a septum.

Option C. Bicornuate uterus: A bicornuate uterus has a heart-shaped appearance due to a partial fusion defect during embryogenesis. It is not typically associated with a complete septum dividing the uterine cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the use of the class of drugs that includes Leuprolide?

choices.text: Drug of choice for precocious puberty
Can be used for Controlled Ovarian Hyperstimulation for IVF

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: First-line management of menorrhagia

  • While GnRH agonists like Leuprolide can be used for the short-term management of menorrhagia, they are not considered first-line treatment. They are often used when other treatments have failed or are unsuitable due to side effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Drug of choice for precocious puberty

  • Continuous GnRH analogues (like leuprolide) are a drug of choice for precocious puberty. They cause suppression of endogenous GnRH production.

Option B: The side effect is osteoporosis

  • Prolonged use of GnRH agonists, including Leuprolide, can lead to decreased bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis.

Option C: Can be used for Controlled Ovarian Hyperstimulation for IVF

  • GnRH analogue used for Controlled Ovarian Hyperstimulation in IVF cycles.
  • It is used in a pulsatile manner which leads to oocyte recruitment.
  • Continuous use causes controlled hyperstimulation by pituitary suppression

questions.text: A 25-year-old previously healthy female presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, photophobia, high fever, and vomiting. On physical examination, she exhibits neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski's sign, and Kernig's sign. Given the suspicion of acute meningitis lumbar puncture is ordered . What is the correct sequence in which layers are pierced from outwards to inside during a spinal procedure?

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Duramater and arachnoid mater
Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Duramater and arachnoid mater
Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Interspinous ligament, Duramater and arachnoid mater
Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Ligamentum flavum, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Duramater and arachnoid mater

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Duramater and arachnoid mater:

  • Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Duramater and arachnoid mater.

  • This option is correct. It correctly identifies the sequence in which layers are pierced during a spinal procedure, starting from the skin, moving through the Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, and finally the Duramater and arachnoid mater reaching the subarachnoid space filled with CSF.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Duramater and subarachnoid space:

  • This option is incorrect because it places the Interspinous ligament before the Supraspinous ligament in the sequence. The correct order is to pierce the Supraspinous ligament first before reaching the Interspinous ligament.
