Option C- Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Interspinous ligament, Duramater and subarachnoid space:

  • This option is incorrect because it places the Ligamentum flavum before the Interspinous ligament in the sequence. The correct order is to pierce the Interspinous ligament before reaching the Ligamentum flavum.

Option D- Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue, Ligamentum flavum, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Duramater and subarachnoid space:

  • This option is incorrect because it places the Ligamentum flavum before the Interspinous ligament in the sequence. The correct order is to pierce the Interspinous ligament before reaching the Ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying the adverse effects of various drugs. A trial is conducted, and a group of mice are injected with various drugs and the drug effects on neurotransmitters in the brain are studied. They find that many drugs alter the dopaminergic neurons of the basal ganglia and can cause features of Parkinsonism, including resting tremors, bradykinesia, postural instability and shuffling gait. Which of the following drugs is not implicated in causing Parkinsonism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Domperidone:

  • Domperidone is a dopamine antagonist used to treat motion sickness and gastroparesis and promote milk secretion from the breast. It has not been implicated in causing drug-induced Parkinsonism because it does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • Parkinson's disease results from a loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra. The basal ganglia and substantia nigra are balanced systems comprising dopaminergic and cholinergic neurons. In Parkinson's disease, the dopaminergic neurons are compromised, and the cholinergic system is unopposed.
  • Parkinsonism refers to the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease, including resting tremors, rigidity, akinesia, postural instability, shuffling gait and micrographia.
  • Primary Parkinsonism refers to a disease that is solely due to a pathology of the brain.
  • Secondary Parkinsonism can be induced by drugs that block the dopaminergic system. These drugs include:
    • Antipsychotics such as haloperidol and phenothiazine are dopamine antagonists used to treat schizophrenia, psychosis, bipolar disorders and Huntington's disease. Side effects of antipsychotics include extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, akathisia and Parkinsonism. Parkinsonism is more common with first-generation antipsychotics but can also occur with second-generation antipsychotics.
    • Antiemetics dopamine antagonists such as metoclopramide and prochlorperazine can also cause Parkinsonism.
    • Antihypertensives such as reserpine and alpha-methyldopa can rarely cause Parkinsonism.
    • Drug-induced Parkinsonism can also be seen rarely with antiepileptics (most commonly valproic acid), although this more commonly causes isolated tremors rather than Parkinsonism.
    • Methyl-phenyl tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) can cause drug-induced Parkinsonism by forming a metabolite methyl-phenyl pyridinium (MPP) toxic to substantia nigra.
    • Other causes of secondary Parkinsonism include:
      • Tumours
      • Infections
      • Vascular diseases
      • Normal pressure hydrocephalus
      • Trauma
      • Liver failure toxins (carbon monoxide, manganese, cyanide, hexane, methanol and carbon disulfide) can also cause Parkinsonism

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Phenothiazine:

  • Phenothiazine is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia. It blocks dopamine receptors and can cause features of Parkinson's disease.

Option B- Haloperidol:

  • Haloperidol is a first-generation high-potency antipsychotic that works by blocking dopamine receptors. It causes extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, akathisia, and Parkinsonism.

Option C- Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a liver toxin that can cause signs and symptoms of Parkinsonism (resting tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity and shuffling gait).

questions.text: Which of the following toxins acts on the Stratum granulosum responsible for causing Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin: 

  • The presence of a toxin that acts on Stratum granulosum and causes Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) indicates the involvement of the Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin. SSSS is characterized by the separation of the epidermis at the level of the Stratum granulosum, leading to widespread exfoliation of the skin.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Panton valentine toxin: Panton-Valentine (PV) toxin is a two-component toxin composed of the S and F components. Such bi-component membrane-active toxins have been grouped as synergohymenotropic toxins, associated with community-acquired Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

Option C - Enterotoxin: Enterotoxin A is the most common enterotoxin among the different enterotoxins. It is Heat stable and causes Food poisoning. It has Vagomimetic action leading to emesis.

Option D - Alpha Hemolysins: These hemolysins cause partial lysis of sheep or human red blood cells. This type of hemolysis is often observed in species like Staphylococcus aureus. They are inactivated at 70 degrees and activated again at 100 degrees.

questions.text: What is the base sequence of RNA formed from the template strand during mRNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: CGGUAAAGCUUA

DNA and RNA:

  • DNA is the basic unit of life. At the same time, RNA is involved in the synthesis of proteins.
  • DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, while RNA is ribonucleic acid.
  • DNA is divided into nuclear DNA and mitochondrial DNA. Transfer RNA, messenger RNA, and ribosomal RNA are the main types of RNA.
  • The bases present in DNA are adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine. In RNA, thymine is replaced by uracil.
  • DNA is a double-stranded structure, while RNA is single-stranded.
  • DNA contains an antiparallel helix while RNA structure is a hairpin and loops.
  • The process by which DNA is converted into RNA is known as transcription.
  • During this process, the coding strand, also known as the template strand of DNA, is used to synthesize RNA.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil.

Incorrect options

Option B: AUUCGAAAUGGC

  • It does not show the transcription of the non-template stand shown above.
  • Therefore, this is not the right answer.

Option C: GCCATTTCGAAT

  • This sequence shows the template strand and not the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

Option D: UAAGCUUUACCG

  • This sequence does not show the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

questions.text: A 28 yrs old male, while driving an auto rickshaw, was thrown and dislodged after a four-wheeler hit his vehicle from the rear. During this momentary collision, his chest directly hit on the handlebar of his vehicle. He fell on the roadside. He was conscious and physically active as an argument followed. Subsequently, within a short time, he developed chest pain and breathlessness. He was then brought to the hospital, and resuscitation was started, but within a very short time, he passed away. What is the most probable cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option B: Tracheobronchial rupture

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is undergoing a hernia operation. On the table, the surgeon asks the nurse to hand over an instrument to incise the skin. The nurse attaches the device to the power. What is the name of the surgical instrument given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Monopolar diathermy:

  • Diathermy uses an alternate high-frequency polarity radio-wave electrical current to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery.
  • It is now utilized in almost all surgical specialties because it creates precise incisions with little blood loss. Electrical current at extremely high frequencies (about 0.5–3 MHz) is used in diathermy.
  • To facilitate cutting and coagulation, the radio frequencies produced by diathermy heat the tissue by causing intracellular oscillation of molecules within the cells.
  • Various outcomes depend on the temperature attained: at 60º C, cell death (fulguration); between 60 and 99º C, tissue coagulation; and at about 100º C, tissue vaporization (cutting).
  • The configuration of the diathermy devices may be monopolar or bipolar; both operations necessitate the completion of the electrical circuit but do so in different ways.
  • In a monopolar action, the electrical current oscillates between the surgeon's electrode and the patient's body before it finally connects with the "grounding plate" (usually located beneath the patient's leg) to complete the circuit.
  • Different electrosurgical waveforms with various tissue effects are available with this electrosurgery.
  • A pencil-like electrode is used in a monopolar electrosurgical operation to cut the target tissue and stop bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Harmonic scalpel:

  • A harmonic scalpel is a surgical tool that cuts and cauterizes tissue simultaneously. It is the most recent gadget to be released in the previous ten or so years.
  • The Harmonic Scalpel is well known for using ultrasonic energy, which is transformed into mechanical energy at the active blade.
  • The active blade, which generates high-grade frictional force, is the primary mechanism, whereas the inactive upper arm maintains tissue in apposition.

 

 

 

 

Option B - LigaSure:

  • A bipolar electrosurgical tool powered by radiofrequency is called LigaSure (bipolar vascular sealing) technology.

 

 

Option D - Bipolar diathermy:

  • The two electrodes in bipolar diathermy are located on the device itself. A dispersive electrode is not required in a bipolar setup; a pair of comparable sizes is employed in tandem. After that, the current is moved between the electrodes.
  • The most frequent uses of bipolar are in microsurgery, procedures on the digits (to prevent monopolar current from being focussed over a smaller area), and patients who have pacemakers (to avoid electrical interference with the pacemaker).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose and mouth. The lesions have gradually increased in size and are not painful or pruritic. Two months ago, he was treated for esophageal candidiasis. Physical examination shows one pinkish-brown papule on the right wing of the nose and two similar nodular lesions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. A biopsy of one of the lesions shows spindle-shaped endothelial cells and infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option D: Human herpes virus 8

  • Kaposi sarcoma is a malignant, multifocal, highly vascularized tumour of the endothelial cells that most commonly affects the skin but may also involve the lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera.
  • It is commonly associated with HIV and can occur at any CD4 count (typically < 500/mm3). 
  • Caused by human herpes virus 8 (HHV8), a large DNA gamma herpes virus
  • Routes of transmission include 
    • Saliva
    • Sexual contact
    • Potentially via blood transfusion and IV drug use
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painless, nonpruritic, papules or nodules on skin and mucosa (especially face/oral cavity and chest) 
    • Solitary, darkly pigmented plaques, which can evolve into nodular, bluish, submucosal, and painful skin changes
    • Lesions resemble those of bacillary angiomatosis.
  • Progression may disseminate to the organs, particularly the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and lymph nodes.
    • Gastrointestinal tract involvement: abdominal pain and diarrhoea; haemorrhage and bowel obstruction in severe cases 
    • Pulmonary involvement: Lesions cause dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis.

Other options

Option A: Bartonella henselae

  • A gram-negative, aerobic, rod-shaped bacterium that causes cat scratch disease. Bartonella henselae infections can cause bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients. The infection causes vascular proliferation, which leads to the development of multiple red or flesh-coloured papules that bleed easily.
  • While the papules can appear very similar to the lesions seen in this patient, biopsy findings typically show clusters of bacilli and neutrophilic infiltration, as opposed to the spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltration found in his biopsy.

Option B: Polyomavirus

  • Polyomaviridae: A family of non-enveloped, double-stranded, circular DNA viruses most commonly affect immunosuppressed (HIV and transplant) patients.
  • Two common members include the JC virus (progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy) and the BK virus (nephropathy and hemorrhagic cystitis).
  • Polyomavirus infection has been associated with Merkel cell carcinoma, an aggressive neuroendocrine tumour of the skin that is much more frequent in HIV-infected individuals.
  • However, unlike this patient's pinkish-brown papules, Merkel cell carcinoma appears as flesh-coloured or bluish-red nodules. 
  • Skin biopsy is diagnostic and typically reveals dermal proliferation of small, blue cells containing large nuclei, finely granular chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and minimal cytoplasm.

Option C: Human papillomavirus 6

  • Human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) is a low-risk HPV type that causes exophytic cauliflower-like lesions appearing as anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) or laryngeal papillomatosis. 
  • HIV infection is associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but a biopsy of HPV-associated lesions characteristically shows hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, parakeratosis, and koilocytes.

questions.text:
Consider the following four events of development of fetus:

Centers of ossification for calcaneum
Centers of ossification for lower end of femur
Centers of ossification for talus
Centers of ossification for cuboid

What is the order in which they appear from lower to higher gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 3, 2, 4:

The order in which they appear from lower to higher gestation:

1. Centers of ossification for calcaneum

  • 20 weeks: Center of ossification for calcaneum appears.

3. Centers of ossification for talus

  • 28 weeks: Center of ossification for talus appears.

2. Centers of ossification for lower end of femur

  • Ossification centers for lower end of femur (36–37 weeks).

4. Centers of ossification for cuboid

  • Cuboid and Capitate appear at birth.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the process of gene expression in different cells of the body. His finding points out that although all the cells of the body have the same genetic information in their nucleus the genetic material is selectively expressed depending on the specific type and function of the cell in the tissue. The figure below shows the technique used by the researcher for this purpose. Which of the following genetic techniques is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Microarray:

  • The figure shows the technique of DNA microarrays.
  • DNA microarrays consist of thousands of short DNA sequences arranged on a glass or silicon chip.
  • Samples of DNA or RNA are labeled with fluorescent dyes and hybridized with the DNA sequences on the array.
  • The relative fluorescence indicates the level of hybridization between the samples.
  • Microarrays are utilized to measure and compare gene expression, as well as for clinical genetic testing, genotyping, cancer mutation typing, and genetic linkage analysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D:

  • The image in the vignette represents the genetic technique of Microarrays.
  • The CRISPR-Cas system edits genes by utilizing Cas9 guided by RNA with complementary bases to target DNA sections.
  • RNA interference silences mRNA using microRNA.
  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism identifies DNA polymorphisms using restriction endonucleases that cut at palindromic sites.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female presents to the clinic complaining of vaginal discharge. The discharge is yellowish in tint and with a foul odour. Endocervical biopsy revealed chlamydial antigen. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Azithromycin + contact tracing

  • Chlamydia trochamatis is a leading cause of cervicitis and vulvovaginitis. It is the number 1 cause of tubal blockage in India.
  • The discharge in chlamydia is yellowish with a strong odour.
  • Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms, and microscopy reveals more than 30 poly-morphonuclear neutrophils per field.
  • Azithromycin 1 gm single dose
  • Doxycycline : 100 mg BD x 7 days
  • Erythromycin: 500 mg BD x 7 days
  • Ofloxacin : 200 mg BD x 7 days
  • For both partners, a single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm can be used to treat both Neisseria and Chlamydia.
  • Contact tracing, abstinence from sexual intercourse or using barrier contraceptives while having intercourse are equally important to avoid recurrence.

Option A: Doxycycline + metronidazole

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD can be prescribed for 7 days to treat a chlamydial infection.
  • Metronidazole is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella. It is not indicated for chlamydia.

Option C: Fluconazole + azithromycin

  • Azithromycin 1 g orally as a single dose can be prescribed to treat chlamydial infections.
  • Fluconazole is an antifungal agent and can be used to treat Candida infections. It is not indicated in chlamydial infections.

Option D: Ampicillin + probenecid

  • Ampicillin is a penicillin derivative antibiotic to cover gram-positive bacteria. In genital infections, it treats pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Actinomyces israelii.
  • Probenecid is a gout medication. However, it can be used with penicillin and penicillin derivatives like ampicillin and nafcillin to increase serum concentrations and prolong plasma half-life. The usual daily dosage for this effect is 1 g.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with decreased vision several months after undergoing cataract surgery. On examination, the ophthalmologist confirms the presence of posterior capsular opacification. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nd YAG Laser posterior capsulotomy:

  • Nd YAG laser posterior capsulotomy is a non-invasive procedure used to treat posterior capsular opacification (PCO) following cataract surgery. This technique involves using a laser to create a small, precise opening in the cloudy posterior capsule of the eye. This allows light to pass through the previously obstructed capsule, addressing visual disturbances and glare sensitivity. It is a minimally invasive outpatient procedure and is highly effective in restoring clear vision for patients experiencing PCO.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Repeat cataract surgery: We have already removed the cataract, so this is not an option.

Option B - Topical antibiotic drops: Topical antibiotic drops are used to prevent or treat eye infections, particularly after eye surgery. They are not a primary treatment for posterior capsular opacification (PCO).

Option D - Oral corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids are medications that can be used for various medical conditions, including reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune system.

questions.text:
Match the following radiographs with the appropriate diagnosis.


	
		
			
			1. 
			
			
			a) Poncets arthritis
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b) Spina ventosa
			
		
		
			
			3. 
			
			
			c) Rheumatoid arthritis
questions.solution:

A - 1-b,2-a,3-c

questions.text: All are true about live vaccines except?

choices.text: Longer duration of immunity is produced
Poor mucosal, and cell-mediated immunity are produced
IgA and IgG are the immunoglobulins produced

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Poor mucosal and cell-mediated immunity are produced:

  • This is an incorrect statement regarding the live vaccine.
  • Live vaccines typically induce robust mucosal and cell-mediated immunity. They are composed of weakened viral or bacterial strains that can still replicate in the body, stimulating both antibody and cellular immune responses.
  • Examples include the MMR vaccine, rotavirus vaccine, smallpox vaccine, and chickenpox vaccine.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D - 

  • These are the correct statements about live vaccines.

questions.text: Which bone does not form the wrist joint?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ulna

  • Ulnar bones do not participate in the formation of the wrist joint.
  • It forms the elbow joint but do not participate in the wrist joint formation
  • It also articulates with the radius proximally and distally

Option A: Scaphoid

  • It one of the carpal bones
  • Located on the thumb side between the hand and the forearm that is the wrist joint

Option C: Radius

  • Wrist joint is also referred to as radiocarpal joint
  • Lower end of the radius participates in the wrist joint formation

Option D: Triquetral

  • It is a pyramid shape bone
  • One of the carpal bones
  • Participates in the wrist joint formation

questions.text: A postpartum woman presents with a painful and engorged right breast. On examination, the breast is enlarged, and tender, and appears warmer than the surrounding skin. Ultrasound suggests generalized inflammatory changes. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: The source of the infection is usually the infant’s gastrointestinal tract
Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage
The most common offending organism is Escherichia coli.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage

  • The presence of painful, engorged, tender unilateral breast with USG s/o generalized inflammatory changes suggests mastitis.
  • Acute puerperal mastitis:
  • The most common organism is a staphylococcus aureus (especially MRSA). Other organisms include coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and Streptococcus viridans.
  • The most common source of infection is the baby's nasopharynx.
  • Symptoms and signs:
  • Fever with chills, myalgia, malaise
  • Engorged and tender breast
  • Mostly unilateral
  • Approximately 10 per cent of women with mastitis develop an abscess that requires drainage.
  • Breast milk expression, antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally four times daily, may be started empirically.
  • Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin hypersensitive
  • A lactating woman presenting with painful, tender unilateral signs of inflammation suggests mastitis.
  • It is treated with penicillins and breast milk expression. It may complicate a breast abscess if not treated.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: The initial treatment is tetracyclines

  • Tetracyclines are contraindicated in breastfeeding and are not the first line for treating Staph infections.

​​​​​​​Option B: The source of the infection is usually the infant’s gastrointestinal tract

  • Mastitis is an infection of the tissue of the breast that occurs most frequently during the time of breastfeeding.
  • It can occur when bacteria from the baby's mouth enter a milk duct through a crack in the nipple.
  • Most common source of infection is the baby's nasopharynx.

Option D: The most common offending organism is Escherichia coli.

  • Breast abscess usually occurs during lactation; the responsible organism is often S. Aureus. Breast abscess in non-lactating women is extremely rare, and limited data is available in the literature regarding this entity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding NCCT (Non-Contrast CT) and CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT)?

choices.text: NCCT is used for diffused lung conditions, while CECT is used for space-occupying lesions.
In NCCT, the aorta appears grey, while in CECT, it appears white due to the iodinated contrast.
NCCT is preferred for fractures, except stress fractures, while CECT is preferred for inflammatory or infectious pathology.
Both NCCT and CECT cannot visualize acute hemorrhage

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: NCCT is preferred for fractures, except stress fractures, while CECT is preferred for inflammatory or infectious pathology

  • NCCT (Non-Contrast CT) and CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) are two different types of CT scans that serve different purposes in clinical practice.
  • NCCT is preferred for fractures (excluding stress fractures) because it provides excellent visualization of bone structures. On the other hand, CECT is preferred for evaluating inflammatory or infectious pathology, as the contrast agent helps in highlighting areas of increased vascularity or abnormal enhancement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - NCCT is used for diffused lung conditions, while CECT is used for space-occupying lesions: The statement in option A is not accurate. NCCT is typically used for conditions such as bone fractures, renal stones (calcification), and acute hemorrhage. On the other hand, CECT is commonly employed for the visualization of space-occupying lesions, such as metastasis.

Option B - In NCCT, the aorta appears grey, while in CECT, it appears white due to the iodinated contrast: In NCCT, the aorta appears white due to its intrinsic density on CT, while in CECT, the iodinated contrast agent enhances the blood vessels, making them appear brighter or white.

Option D - Both NCCT and CECT cannot visualize acute hemorrhage.: The statement in option D is not accurate. Both NCCT and CECT can visualize acute hemorrhage, but chronic hemorrhage, which involves the deposition of iron or hemosiderin, is better visualized with MRI.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes presents to the endocrinology clinic for a routine follow-up visit. He has been managing his diabetes with lifestyle modifications and metformin. However, recent laboratory investigations show elevated urinary albumin levels and declining estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Histopathology of the kidney is given below:



Considering his renal impairment, which antidiabetic drug would be suitable to be added to his treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Linagliptin:

  • Based on the given clinical scenario and the histopathology findings (which show Kimmelsteil Wilson lesions, i.e., nodular glomerulosclerosis due to diabetes), the most suitable antidiabetic drug to be added to the treatment regimen for this patient with declining renal function and elevated urinary albumin levels would be linagliptin.
  • Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that helps regulate blood glucose levels by reducing the degradation of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) produced by enterocytes responsible for increased uptake of glucose by adipose tissue. Unlike other antidiabetic drugs, linagliptin does not require dose adjustment based on renal function and has a favorable renal safety profile as it undergoes bile elimination and enterohepatic recycling. Therefore, it is a suitable choice for patients with renal impairment, including those with diabetic nephropathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Metformin: Metformin is generally considered the first-line drug for managing type 2 diabetes. However, in the presence of declining renal function and elevated urinary albumin levels, metformin may need to be used with caution or discontinued due to the risk of lactic acidosis.

Option B - Glibenclamide: Glibenclamide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells. However, it is metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. With declining renal function, the risk of hypoglycemia may increase. Therefore, glibenclamide may not be the best choice in this case.

Option C - Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an analog of amylin, a hormone that is co-secreted with insulin by the beta cells of the pancreas. While pramlintide can be beneficial in certain cases, it is not primarily indicated for the management of renal impairment or diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the ER with palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. He is on long-term theophylline therapy. His heart rate is 120 beats per minute, blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. An electrocardiogram is performed, which is shown below:



Which of the following statements are true about the treatment of this condition?

choices.text: DC shock is the preferred treatment of choice
Amiodarone cannot be given as a long term treatment modality
Verapamil acts on SA node and stabilizes the heart rate
Metoprolol when given causes stabilization of the membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Amiodarone cannot be given as a long-term treatment modality:

  • The combination of an irregular rhythm with varying P-wave morphologies in a patient on theophylline therapy for COPD is consistent with the diagnosis of Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT).
  • Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic medication with a membrane-stabilizing effect, can be recommended for the treatment of MAT. However, its potential for toxicity limits its use as a long-term treatment option.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A-DC shock is the preferred treatment of choice: DC shock is not the preferred treatment for Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) because it is ineffective in the presence of theophylline toxicity and does not provide long-term benefit.

Option C- Verapamil acts on SA node and stabilizes the heart rate: Verapamil primarily acts on the AV node, not the SA node, and is not the preferred medication for managing MAT.

Option D- Metoprolol when given causes stabilization of the membrane: Metoprolol works by blocking adrenaline's effects on the heart, but it does not directly stabilize the membrane. It is used to manage heart rate and symptoms in MAT.

questions.text: Which of the following studies involves matching?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Case-control study:

  • Matching in case-control studies ensures similarity between cases and controls by pairing them based on background variables, reducing variability and systematic differences. This method allows for comparing exposure to the risk factor of interest between cases and controls.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Retrospective cohort study

Option C - Prospective cohort study

Option D - Cross-sectional study

matching is not done in these studies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with bilateral and symmetrical swellings on either side of the septum. The patient complains of nasal obstruction, pain, fever, and headache. On examination, enlarged submental or submandibular lymph nodes are found. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Septal abscess 

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including bilateral and symmetrical swellings, nasal obstruction, pain, fever, headache, and lymphadenopathy, is consistent with a septal abscess.
  • It can occur following a septal hematoma or due to infection in the nose, finger picking, or furunculosis.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Septal hematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septum.
  • While it can progress to a septal abscess if left untreated, it does not present with the additional symptoms of fever, headache, and lymphadenopathy seen in this case.

Option C - Furunculosis

  • Furunculosis refers to the development of multiple boils or abscesses in the skin, usually caused by a bacterial infection of hair follicles.
  • While it can be associated with the development of a septal abscess, it does not explain the bilateral and symmetrical swellings seen in this case.

Option D - Meningitis

  • Meningitis is an infection and inflammation of the meninges, the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Although it can present with fever and headache, it does not cause bilateral and symmetrical swellings on either side of the septum or enlarged submental or submandibular lymph nodes.

questions.text: A Sudden and irresistible force compelling a person to commit an offense consciously is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Impulsiveness:

  • A sudden and irresistible force compelling a person to commit an offense consciously is known as an impulse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Illusion: Illusion is a false interpretation by the senses of an external object or stimulus which has a real existence, e.g., when a person sees a dog and mistakes it for lion.

Option B - Obsession: Obsession: In this, a single idea, thought, or emotion is constantly entertained by a person which he recognizes as irrational, but persists inspite of all efforts to drive it from his mind. It is a disorder of content of thought.

Option C - Twilight state: Twilight state is seen in visual hallucinations, Epilepsy, Head injury, Hysteria, and Punch-drunkenness.

questions.text: What term best describes the phenomenon exhibited by a 35- year-old male who while speaking, switches topics abruptly and displays continuous speech flow with no pauses or breaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flight of ideas

  • Flight of ideas refers to rapid, continuous speech with abrupt shifts from one topic to another, often with superficial or loose connections between ideas.

  • It is commonly seen in mania, where the person appears to be talking non-stop and jumping between topics.

  • The speech is pressured, and the transitions may follow understandable associations, even if tenuous.

Definitions:

Term Definition
Derailment Also known as loosening of associations, where ideas slip off track onto unrelated tangents. Unlike flight of ideas, connections are not logical or understandable.
Thought blocking A sudden interruption in speech or thought, where the patient abruptly stops speaking, often reporting a “blank mind.” Seen in schizophrenia.
Neologism The creation of new, meaningless words that are not part of any recognized language. Common in schizophrenia.

 

Derailment (Option A):
Incorrect – There is a lack of connection between ideas, whereas in flight of ideas, the flow remains connected superficially.

Thought blocking (Option B):
Incorrect – Describes a sudden halt in speech, not rapid continuous speech.

Neologism (Option D):
Incorrect – Refers to newly made-up words, not rapid topic shifting.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with atticoantral CSOM presents with extensive bone destruction involving the annulus, tympanic bone, ossicles, and tegmen tympani. The patient has a foul-smelling and purulent ear discharge. Which of the following treatment approaches would be the most appropriate for managing this patient's condition?

choices.text: Aural toilet and ear drop administration

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Reconstructive surgery (e.g., tympanoplasty)

  • In cases of atticoantral CSOM with extensive bone destruction and chronic disease, reconstructive surgery (e.g., tympanoplasty) is often the most appropriate treatment approach.
  • This surgery aims to reconstruct the middle ear structures and restore hearing function.
  • Given the presentation of extensive bone destruction and the need for long-term management, reconstructive surgery would likely offer the best outcome for this patient. Therefore, this choice is more likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aural toilet and ear drop administration:

  • Aural toilet, which involves removing debris and aural polyps, and administering ear drops (e.g., Neomycin+ Polymyxin + Chloromycetin or gentamicin) are medical treatment options for CSOM.
  • However, in a case of extensive bone destruction and foul-smelling purulent discharge, these measures alone may not be sufficient to manage the condition effectively. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Option B - Systemic antibiotics for acute exacerbation:

  • Systemic antibiotics are typically used in cases of acute exacerbation in CSOM.
  • However, in a scenario with extensive bone destruction and chronic atticoantral CSOM, systemic antibiotics alone may not provide adequate control of the disease. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Option C - Mastoid x-rays and audiogram assessment:

  • Mastoid x-rays and audiogram assessment are important diagnostic tools to evaluate the extent of bone destruction and the degree of hearing loss in CSOM.
  • While these investigations are essential in the management of CSOM, they are primarily used for evaluation rather than a definitive treatment approach. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: Rifampicin is most likely to induce the metabolism of which of the following antiretroviral drugs?
questions.solution:
Option B: Nevirapine

  • Rifampicin is a microsomal enzyme inducer that increases several CYP450 isoenzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP1A2, and CYP2C subfamily.
  • Therefore, it enhances the metabolism of many drugs, including warfarin, oral contraceptives, corticosteroids, sulfonylureas, HIV protease inhibitors, non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTls), theophylline, metoprolol, fluconazole, ketoconazole, clarithromycin, phenytoin, etc.
  • Nevirapine is an NNRTI used to treat and prevent HIV/AIDS.

Option A: Tenofovir

  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse-transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI).
  • It is used to treat chronic hepatitis B and to treat and prevent HIV/AIDS.
  • Rifampicin and tenofovir is well tolerated and there is only a small decrease in plasma tenofovir levels during combination treatment. 

Option C: Ritonavir 

  • Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor (PIs). 
  • It is used to treat and prevent HIV/AIDS.
  • Rifampicin causes reduction of concentration of all protease inhibitors except Ritonavir. 

Option D: Zidovudine

  • Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTIs).
  • It is used to treat and prevent HIV/AIDS.
  • Only long-term combination therapy of Rifampicin and Zidovudine leads to increased clearance of zidovudine.

questions.text: A 26- year old gravida 3 para 2 living 2 at 40 weeks of gestational age presents in the second stage of labour. The baby's head delivers spontaneously but then retracts back against the perineum; even with downward traction, the baby's anterior shoulder fails to deliver. Which of the following is not the appropriate step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Instruct the nurse to apply fundal pressure
Instruct the nurse to flex the hip joint so that the patient's legs are up to her chest

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A: Instruct the nurse to apply fundal pressure

Shoulder dystocia occurs when the foetal shoulders fail to deliver spontaneously after the head has been delivered due to the impaction of the anterior shoulder against the pubic bone.

Steps in the management of shoulder dystocia:

  1. Call for help
  2. Apply suprapubic pressure to disengage the anterior shoulder
  3. Flex the mother's legs over the abdomen, i.e. McRobert's manoeuvre
  4. Rotate the posterior shoulder and attempt delivery of the posterior shoulder, i.e. Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre
  5. Push the delivered foetal head back into the delivery canal in preparation for a caesarean section, i.e. Zavanelli's restitution
  6. Apply modest downward traction to the posterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal sacrum) or upward traction to the anterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal symphysis) with the patient on her hands and knees, i.e. Gaskin manoeuvre
  7. A generous episiotomy should always be made to allow manipulations
  8. There is no role for fundal pressure.

Option B: Call for help

  • Calling for help is the first and foremost step in managing complicated labour.

Option C: Cut a generous episiotomy

  • A generous episiotomy should always be made to allow manipulations.

Option D: Instruct the nurse to flex the hip joint so that the patient's legs are up to her chest

  • Flexing the mother's hip joint until her legs are up to her chest is the McRoberts manoeuvre.
  • It requires two persons, one at each leg of the patient.
  • The helpers grip and press the maternal foot cephalad, causing hyperflexion of the maternal hips and knees and minor hip abduction, resulting in a 1-2 cm superior displacement of the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the hospital by his mother. The primary complaint includes mild pallor and frequent abdominal and joint pain. His medical history included jaundice and pneumonia last year. The baby also has difficulty walking or talking. Laboratory reports reveal mild splenomegaly. The hemogram shows elliptocytes and ovalocytes. The image of the blood smear is given below. What is the likely diagnosis from the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sickle cell anaemia

  • In this case, sickle-shaped RBCs are seen in peripheral smears, suggesting sickle cell anaemia.
  • Sickle cell anaemia
    • It is a group of inherited disorders of structural hemoglobinopathy that affect the shape of red blood cells. In this case, some red blood cells are shaped like crescent moons. These sickle cells also become sticky and rigid and block or slow down blood flow.
    • These crescent-shaped red blood cells die within 10 to 20 days and result in a shortage of red blood cells (anaemia). Without enough RBCs, the body can't get enough oxygen, which causes fatigue.
    • It happens due to a point mutation in the 6th codon of the β-globin gene, so there is a replacement of glutamate with valine.
    • Diagnosis:
      • Sickling test: mixing a blood sample with metabisulfite or dithionate induces sickling of RBCs if HbS is present.
      • Howell- Jolly bodies: due to asplenia
      • Spleen biopsy: Gamma Gandy bodies
      • Hb Electrophoresis: To detect HbS-confirmation
    • Treatment: 
      • Maintain hydration
      • Avoid infections and prompt correction of any inflammation.
      • Acute painful crisis → vigorous hydration and analgesia.
      • Hydroxyurea for patients with severe symptoms (increased HbF levels).
      • Bone marrow transplantation and gene therapy.

Option A: Megaloblastic anaemia

  • It is a blood disorder in which the bone marrow produces stem cells that make abnormally large red blood cells. 
  • It is caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency and results in anaemia.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils (image below) in cases of megaloblastic anaemia. 

Option B: Thalassemia

  • It is a group of inherited diseases in which the body produces either no or less haemoglobin.
  • The blood smear shows a reduced number of red blood cells with severe anisopoikilocytosis and nucleated RBCs.
  • It is a type of microcytic hypochromic anemia.

Option D: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Iron deficiency anaemia is a common type of anaemia which affects red blood cells.
  • The patient's blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells.
  • The blood smear of this condition shows microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents to a rural clinic complaining of chronic eye irritation, redness, and mucopurulent discharge. There are follicular conjunctival changes, upper limbal scarring, and inturned eyelashes on examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the active stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Oral azithromycin:

  • The clinical picture suggests the diagnosis of Trachoma, and Azithromycin is the drug of choice to treat the active stage of the disease.Azithromycin is also a drug of choice for blanket therapy of trachoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Topical tetracycline: Topical 1% tetracycline can be used in the treatment but it is not the drug of choice since it is less effective than oral azithromycin, has poor compliance and can lead to tooth staining in children.

Option B – Topical corticosteroids: Topical corticosteroids are not used in the treatment for the active or chronic cicatricial stage of trachoma.

Option C – Artificial tears: Artificial tears are not the primary treatment for trachoma. While they can provide symptomatic relief for dry eyes, they do not address the underlying bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the hospital after being involved in physical fights in a bar. He has multiple injuries and fractures in his body. The patient receives an emergency blood transfusion as part of the resuscitation. The nurse uses a device during a blood transfusion. What purpose is the device shown in the image used for?

choices.text: Prevent transmission of RBCs which have expired

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Prevent transfusion-related reactions

  • The image shows a blood transfusion set with a Leukocyte reduction filter that will generate leuco-depleted blood.
  • The second-generation filters of size 40 μm can remove micro aggregates of fibrin, platelets and leucocytes
  • The main immediate advantage is reduced incidence of febrile non-haemolytic transfusions.
  • Blood components should be filtered during blood transfusion to remove small clumps and clots of white blood cells and platelets that form during collection and storage.
  • 170 - 260 micron filters are present in standard blood infusion set.
  • Smaller component sets, including in-line filters for RBC, WBC, platelet, and plasma, are also available.

Option A: Prevent transmission of RBCs which have expired

  • This blood transfusion set cannot prevent the transmission of expired RBCs.

Option C: Prevent transfusion-associated circulatory overload

  • Blood transfusion set with a filter can prevent febrile non-haemolytic transfusions.
  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload occurs due to the excessive volume of transfused blood.

Option D: Prevents transfusion-related acute lung injury

  • Activation of recipient neutrophils by donor-derived antibodies that target HLA (human leukocyte antigens) or HNA (human neutrophil antigen) causes transfusion-related acute lung injury.
  • A blood transfusion set cannot prevent this reaction.

questions.text: Which among the following vaccines is not given to a health professional following a disaster?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Measles:

  • This vaccine is not given to a health professional following a disaster.
  • However, natural disasters may negatively affect the maintenance of ongoing national or regional eradication programs against polio and measles.
  • Disruption of these programs should be monitored closely. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are the vaccines given to a health professional following a disaster.

questions.text: During the menstrual cycle, which of the following is the main source of estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Developing follicles:

  • During the menstrual cycle, the main source of estrogen is the developing ovarian follicles. These follicles contain granulosa cells, which produce estrogen in response to stimulation by follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. This estrogen is essential for the growth and maturation of the follicles and plays a crucial role in regulating the menstrual cycle.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Corpus luteum: The corpus luteum primarily produces progesterone, not estrogen. While it does produce some estrogen, it is not the main source during the menstrual cycle.

Option C - Endometrium: The endometrium responds to estrogen but does not produce it. Estrogen acts on the endometrium to induce proliferation during the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle.

Option D - Stromal cells of the ovaries: Stromal cells of the ovaries are involved in follicle development but are not the main source of estrogen during the menstrual cycle. They support follicle growth and function but do not produce significant amounts of estrogen.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with glaucoma presents with excessive daytime sleepiness and a history of sleep apnea. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brimonidine:

  • Based on the given information, brimonidine is contraindicated in children due to its association with sleep apnea and heart blocks in this age group. Therefore, it should be avoided in this patient with a history of sleep apnea and excessive daytime sleepiness.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Apraclonidine: 

  • Apraclonidine does not specifically cause sleep apnea or heart blocks in children. However, apraclonidine can cause lid retraction.

Option C - Adrenaline:

  • Adrenaline does not specifically cause sleep apnea or drowsiness, rather they causes conjunctival pigmentation or deposits.

Option D - None of the above:

  • It is incorrect option.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man inspires at an Oxygen (O2) tension of 138 mmHg, a nitrogen tension of 556 mmHg, and a water vapor pressure of 42 mmHg at sea level. A clot in the pulmonary blood vessels completely blocks blood flow to a small group of alveoli. What is the O2 and carbon dioxide (CO2) tension in these alveoli?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 

CO2

O2

0

138
  • When the blood supply to alveoli is obstructed, the composition of the alveolar air becomes equal to the inspired air composition, which has a CO2 tension of about 0 mmHg (0.3mmHg) and O2 tension of about 138 mmHg in this case.
  • This is known as dead space, as the perfusion is zero.

​​​​Incorrect Options:

Option B - 

CO2

O2

0

0
  • When an alveolus is not perfused, the tension of CO2 is 0 mmHg. However, the tension of O2 should be 138 mmHg

Option C - 

CO2

O2

40

104
  • These are the normal values of CO2 and O2 tension in alveoli. Hence, this answer choice is incorrect.

Option D - 

  • CO2
  • O2
  • 42
  • 138

  • When there is no perfusion, the CO2  and O2 tension equalizes to that of inspired air. However, the tension of CO2 in inspired air is 0 mmHg. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of irritation and tearing in the right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes entropion characterized by horizontal lid laxity and overriding of the preseptal over the pretarsal muscle. The patient's lashes are rubbing against the cornea, leading to discomfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Quickert procedure:

  • The patient is suffering from involutional entropion due to the overriding of preseptal over pretarsal orbicularis oculi and horizontal laxity. The preferred procedure is the Quickert procedure, which involves the Wies procedure i.e., transverse lid splitting, and then everted sutures are given for overriding of preseptal over pretarsal orbicularis oculi and pentagon incision to correct horizontal laxity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Wies procedure: Wies procedure is only performed to correct overriding of preseptal over pretarsal orbicularis oculi but does not correct the other underlying cause of entropion i.e., horizontal laxity.

Option B – Pentagon incision: The Pentagon incision will correct only the horizontal laxity but will not address the overriding of preseptal over pretarsal orbicularis oculi.

Option C – Jones procedure: The Jones procedure is done to address the Disinsertion of the lower lid retractors.

questions.text: Below is an image of a condition caused due to maternal consumption of thalidomide during pregnancy. Identify it correctly.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phocomelia:

  • Limbs resemble flippers of a seal
  • Maternal intake of thalidomide during pregnancy is a risk factor
  • Short proximal segments of limbs

Incorrect Options

Option B - Osteogenesis imperfecta:

  • It is characterized by Blue sclera, deafness, bony deformities, Hyperextensible joints

  • So this cannot be the answer

Option C - Scurvy:

  • It is characterized by gum bleeding, Petechiae, Subperiosteal hemorrhage involving long bones, painful pseudo paralysis, crying on touch

Option D - Osteopetrosis:

  • Clinical Features
  • Neurological problems due to compression of nerves, Deafnes,pancytopenia-anemia, bleeding, infections, Increased extramedullary hematopoiesis: Large head, hepatosplenomegaly

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with early morning nausea and vomiting for 1 month. He also complains of blurred vision and headache, which worsens while defecating and straining. Fundoscopy reveals severe bilateral papilledema. A raised intracranial pressure is suspected. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved first in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abducens nerve:

  • Abducens is the sixth cranial nerve which is a pure motor nerve and supplies lateral rectus. After leaving the pontomedullary junction, it enters the subarachnoid space and after a variable distance, it penetrates the dura and leaves the intramural space.
  • It travels through the osteofibrous Dorello's canal under the petrosphenoidal ligament (PSL), also known as Gruber's ligament. It then penetrates the cavernous sinus, riding along with the inferior petrosal sinus. In the cavernous sinus, it lies immediately lateral to the pericarotid sympathetics.
  • Abducens nerve has the longest subarachnoid course. Therefore, whenever there is suspicion of raised intracranial pressure, the abducens nerve is affected first.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve has the longest intracranial route. It is very thin in diameter and it is the only nerve that has a dorsal origin. However, it is not the most common nerve affected by raised intracranial pressure.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal is the thickest nerve in diameter. It is a mixed nerve, and it is least likely to be affected by the raised intracranial pressure

Option D - Facial nerve: The facial nerve has the longest intraosseous route. It is mostly affected by ear infections, e.g. Herpes zoster oticus or Ramsay Hunt syndrome. It is not a commonly affected nerve following a raised intracranial pressure

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of a lesion in his oral cavity, which looks like a frog’s belly. He is scheduled for elective surgery. During the surgery, the surgeon employs the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Doyen’s mouth gag:

  • The patient has an intra-oral ranula and is being planned for marsupialization.
  • The above-given image shows a Doyen’s mouth gag.
  • It has blades that are semi-circular and curved at the tip.
  • It is used to keep the mouth open during intra-oral surgeries like
    • Glossectomy
    • Cleft palate
    • Intra-oral ranula
    • To acquire a biopsy from a suspicious lesion

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Joll’s thyroid retractor

 

  • The Joll’s self-retaining retractor is a speciality surgical tool used for challenging incision sites.
  • It is commonly used for thyroid and vaginal procedures due to its unusual form, which allows it to access these anatomical locations more effectively.

Option B: Morris retractor

  • The Morris Retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall, loin, and subcostal incisions.
  • It can fit a wide range of wounds at any depth.
  • The handle has an oval ring that provides an improved grip for an assistant's fingertips.

Option D: Beckman Weitlaner retractor

  • The Beckman Weitlaner retractor is a surgical instrument used in veterinary surgery to retract tissues and skin.
  • It is most typically utilized in spinal and intracranial procedures.
  • The instrument is equipped with finger ring grips and a self-locking mechanism.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female is brought to the operation theatre for an open reduction of humerus fracture. After Anesthetic fitness, the patient is given general anaesthesia, and nitrous oxide and Sevoflurane are given as inhalant anaesthetic agents. Which of the following is the measuring pressure in the gauge if the Pressure of the Nitrous oxide cylinder is at 100% and 40% volume, respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 750 Psi and 750 Psi:

  • In cases of gases which are in liquid form in the cylinder (N2O), pressure gauze is always full till it becomes Zero.
  • Thus, in the case of N2O, whether the cylinder has 100% or 40% volume, the pressure gauze will always show 750 Psi.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 750 Psi and 500 Psi: The amount of gas in the cylinder doesn't matter; it always shows a hundred percent of the gas in the cylinder.

Option C - 750 Psi and 375 Psi: The measuring pressure should be 750 PSI at both 40% and 100% volume of gas.

Option D - 750 Psi and 275 Psi: The measuring pressure should be 750 PSI at both 40% and 100% volume of gas.

questions.text: To which Runyon's classification group do Mycobacterium gordonae, a slow-growing mycobacterium producing a yellow-orange pigment regardless of light conditions, belong?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Group II:

  • Non-tubercular mycobacteria (also called atypical mycobacteria) have been classified into four groups by Runyon based on pigment production and rate of growth.
  • M. Gordonae belongs to group II (scotochromogens).
  • They always produce pigmented colonies (yellow-orange-red), i.e. in the dark and in light.
  • Examples: M. Flavescens, M. gordonae, M. scrofulaceum, and M. szulgai.
  • M. gordonae, formerly called Mycobacterium aquae, is slow growing mycobacteria, usually requiring up to 3 weeks to reach mature growth.
  • M gordonae is ubiquitous and may be found in soil, water (e.g., ground, tap, bottled), whirlpools, unpasteurized milk, mucous membranes of healthy persons, urine, and gastric fluid.
  • Common symptomatic manifestations include cough, weight loss, dyspnea, hemoptysis and fever.
  • Various radiographic findings are possible, including pulmonary nodules, cavities, infiltrates, bronchiectasis and consolidation.
  • In addition to clinical symptoms and radiographic abnormalities, positive cultures from sputum, bronchial wash, or transbronchial or lung biopsy are necessary.
  • The treatment regimen for M. gordonae infection is not well defined, but antimicrobial agents with the most consistent in vitro activity include ethambutol, rifamycins, clarithromycin, linezolid, and fluoroquinolones.
  • In addition, the organism is sometimes sensitive to cycloserine, trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole.
  • M. gordonae is resistant to isoniazid.
  • Although commonly regarded as a contaminant, M. gordonae is capable of causing significant infections in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts, and its isolation should not completely be dismissed without further evaluation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Group I:

  • These are called photochromogens.
  • They produce pigmented colonies (yellow-orange) only when exposed to light but not in the dark.
  • Examples: M. asiaticum, M. kansasii, M.marinum, and M. simiae

Option C - Group III:

  • These are called non-photochromogens.
  • They do not produce pigment.
  • Examples: M. avium complex (MAC), M. haemophilum, M. gastri, M. ulcerans, M. xenopi, and M. Nonchromogenicum.

Option D - Group IV:

  • These are called rapid growers/Chromogenic.
  • This is a heterogeneous group of mycobacteria capable of rapid growth, with colonies appearing within 7 days of incubation. Within the group, photochromogenic, scotochromogenic, and nonchromogenic species occur.
  • Chromogenic (pigment-producing) rapid growers are mostly saprophytic, e.g. M. Phlei and M. Smegmatis. M. fortuitum.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia & underwent allogenic stem cell transplantation a year ago. In her follow-up visit, she has manifestations of chronic graft-versus-host disease but otherwise is doing well & has no evidence of recurrence. Which of the following vaccines should not be administered to this patient at this point in time?
questions.solution:
Option C: Measles, mumps, and rubella

  • Patients who have undergone allogenic stem cell transplantation remain at risk for infectious complications
  • Graft versus host disease (GVHD) requires immunosuppression, increasing infectious risk.
  • Measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine is a live virus vaccine so avoided in transplantation patients with a history of GVHD
  • It can be safely given after 24 months if the patient does not have GVHD

Option A: Diphtheria-tetanus

  • The diphtheria-tetanus vaccine is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Option B: 23-Valent pneumococcal polysaccharide

  • 23-Valent pneumococcal polysaccharide is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Option D: Poliomyelitis via injection 

  • Poliomyelitis via injection is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: All are methods of Controlled tipping except
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bangalore method:

  • This is not a method of controlled tipping. It is a method of Composting
  • Compositing is an integrated method of refuse and night soil disposal.
  • Compositing is achieved by two methods (CBI):
    • Bangalore method: It is based on an anaerobic hot fomentation process.
    • Indore method: aerobic process.
  • Compositing is not a preferred method for a population of more than 1,00,000.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are the methods of Controlled tipping

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a road traffic accident. On examination, he has a right femur fracture. His blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, and his pulse is 110 per minute. A decision is made to transfuse RBCs and proceed with emergency surgery for the femur fracture. At which of the following temperatures are packed RBCs stored?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2-6°C:

  • Blood products and transfusion:
    • Although the incidence of severe transfusion reactions and infections is now very low, in recent years, it has become apparent that there is an immunological price to be paid for the transfusion of heterologous blood, leading to increased morbidity and decreased survival in certain population groups (trauma, malignancy).
    • Supplies are also limited, and therefore the use of blood and blood products must always be reasonable and justifiable for clinical need.
    • Whole blood is now rarely available in civilian practice as it is an inefficient use of limited resources. However, whole blood transfusion has significant advantages over packed cells as it is coagulation factor rich and, if fresh, more metabolically active than stored blood.
    • Packed red blood cells are spun-down and concentrated packs of red blood cells. Each unit is approximately 330 mL and has a hematocrit of 50–70 per cent.
    • Packed cells are stored in a SAG-M solution (saline–adenine–glucose–mannitol) to increase shelf life to 5 weeks at 2–6°C. (Older storage regimens included storage in CPD – citrate–phosphate–dextrose solutions with a shelf life of 2–3 weeks.)
  • Indications for blood transfusion:
    • Acute blood loss, to replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery
    • Perioperative anemia to ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase
    • Symptomatic chronic anemia without hemorrhage or impending surgery

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - −40 to −50°C:

  • Fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) is rich in coagulation factors and is removed from fresh blood and stored at −40 to −50°C with a two-year shelf life.
  • It is the first-line therapy for coagulopathic bleeding. Rhesus D-positive FFP may be given to a rhesus D-negative woman.
  • However, seroconversion can occur with large volumes due to red cell fragments, and rhesus D immunization should be considered.

Option B -  −30°C:

  • Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP and is rich in factor VIII and fibrinogen. It is stored at −30°C with a two-year shelf life. It is given in low fibrinogen states or factor VIII deficiency.

Option D - 20-24°C:

  • Platelets are supplied as a pooled platelet concentrate and contain about 250 × 109 /L. Platelets are stored on a special agitator at 20–24°C and have a shelf life of only 5 days. Platelet transfusions are given to patients with thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction who are bleeding or undergoing surgery.

questions.text: Which of the chromosome responsible for determining the sex of the resulting fetus?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acrocentric

  • The centromere is present near the end of chromosomes.
  • It forms a very short p arm & a very long q arm
  • Cytogenetically, the Y chromosome is composed of two pseudoautosomal regions, a short arm and the long arm separated by a centromere, and is an acrocentric chromosome. The pseudoautosomal regions are euchromatic along with the long arm's proximal portion juxtaposed to the centromere, and a large portion of the long arm is heterochromatic.
  • In humans, chromosome numbers 13, 14, 15, 21, 22, and Y are acrocentric.

Option A: Metacentric

  • The centromere is present in the middle part of the chromosome and is divided into two equal arms.
  • The p & q arms are almost equal in length
  • The shape of the metacentric chromosome is X because of the equal length of the p and q arms.
  • In humans, chromosome numbers 1, 3, 16, 19 & 20 are examples of metacentric chromosomes.
  • Sometimes fusion of two acrocentric chromosomes by translocation leads to the formation of one metacentric chromosome.

Option C: Sub-metacentric

  • The centromere is present near the middle part and divides the chromosome into two unequal arms.
  • The shape of the submetacentric chromosome is L-shape.
  • In humans, Most of the chromosomes are sub-metacentric
  • Chromosome numbers 2, 4 to 12, 17, 18, & X chromosome.

questions.text: At 19, a female visits the outpatient department with a severe 18-hour-long pulsating headache, nausea, and photophobia. Apart from these episodes, she has no significant medical history. The physician diagnoses her and prescribes sumatriptan. Which statement about this drug is false?

choices.text: It is contraindicated in coronary artery disease

questions.solution:
Option A: It has 99% oral bioavailability

  • This patient’s presenting symptoms (unilateral pulsatile headache, nausea, photophobia) and history of recurring episodes mostly suggest a severe acute migraine.
  • Sumatriptan has 15% oral bioavailability and is also available in subcutaneous injection and nasal spray formulations for better bioavailability
  • Frovatriptan is the longest-acting, and rizatriptan is the fastest-acting congener.

Option B: It is contraindicated in coronary artery disease

  • Triptans can cause coronary vasospasm and are contraindicated in coronary artery disease.

Option C: It constricts cranial vessels

  • Sumatriptan reduces headaches by constricting cranial blood vessels, preventing pain signal transmission to the brain.

Option D: It is a selective 5-HT 1B/1D receptor agonist

  • Sumatriptan is a selective serotonin (5-HT 1B/1D) receptor agonist.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient was diagnosed with Vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient’s blood work revealed elevated levels of a certain type of acid. Which of the following best describes the properties of this acid?

choices.text: It is 100% dissociated at its pKa

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Weak dibasic acids:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia with neurological symptoms.
  • Methylmalonic acid accumulates due to B12 deficiency.
  • Methylmalonic acid is a weak dibasic acid that partially dissociates into acids and conjugate bases.
  • Weak acids like methylmalonic acid have conjugate bases that are strong.
  • Thus, methylmalonic acid is correctly identified as a weak dibasic acid.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Strong acid:

  • Strong acids like HCl dissociate completely in water.
  • Weak acids only partially dissociate.
  • Methylmalonic acid, containing a carboxyl group, is a weak acid, not a strong one.

Option C - It is 100% dissociated at its pKa:

  • Strong acids dissociate completely, weak acids partially.
  • Weak acids exist in equilibrium between their undissociated and dissociated states.
  • Methylmalonic acid is only 50% dissociated at its pKa, so it doesn't fit this description.

Option D - Major intracellular buffer:

  • Buffers resist pH changes.
  • Physiological buffers include bicarbonate, orthophosphate, and proteins, not methylmalonic acid.
  • Thus, methylmalonic acid isn't a major intracellular buffer.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about growth hormone?

A. Diabetogenic hormone.

B. Increase deposition of proteins by the chondrocyte osteogenic cells that cause bone growth.

C. Increase muscle mass.

D. Non-lipolytic

choices.text: A, B, C, and D are all correct
A, B, and C are correct
A, C, and D are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A, B, and C are correct:

Growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone stimulates growth in almost all body tissues by increasing cell size, promoting mitosis, and fostering cell differentiation, particularly in bone and muscle.

Action of growth hormone:

  • Metabolic functions:
    • Protein metabolism: Enhances amino acid transport, RNA translation, and DNA transcription, promoting protein synthesis and decreasing protein catabolism.
    • Fat metabolism: Increases lipolysis and release of free fatty acids for energy.
    • Carbohydrate metabolism: Decreases glucose uptake in tissues, increases glucose production by the liver.
  • Actions on specific tissues:
    • Bone & Cartilage: Increases protein deposition, chondrocyte and osteogenic cell reproduction, and conversion of chondrocytes into osteogenic cells, promoting bone growth.
    • Muscle organ & soft tissues: Increases muscle mass and growth of internal organs and soft tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D: Are incorrect refer to explanation above

questions.text: What's the correct statement about the condition of a 32-year-old breastfeeding woman with a painful, swollen left breast, erythema, and localized warmth, but no fever or systemic symptoms, and a tender, palpable mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, based on FNAC results?

choices.text: Cellulitis is a common symptom of Staphylococcal infection.
During weaning, the causative organism can enter through cracks in the nipple.
Surgical drainage is necessary for the treatment.
Streptococcus is a less common cause of mastitis.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Streptococcus is a less common cause of mastitis:

  • The FNAC of an acute mastitis breast shows an accumulation of acute inflammatory cells including neutrophils, histiocytes, and occasional plasma cells.

  • Most commonly due to Staph. aureus and cause single or multiple abscesses in the breast. In case of a Streptococcal infection, there is cellulitis of the breast.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Cellulitis is a common symptom of Staphylococcal infection:

  • This statement is not accurate. Staphylococcal infection, especially Staphylococcus aureus, commonly causes acute mastitis, which may present with localized inflammation, abscess formation, and not necessarily cellulitis.

Option B - During weaning, the causative organism can enter through cracks in the nipple:

  • Mastitis is more commonly associated with breastfeeding and can occur due to milk stasis, blocked ducts, or bacterial infection. Cracks and fissures in the nipple can contribute to the development of mastitis, but it is not limited to the weaning period and is more common during the first month of breastfeeding.

Option C - Surgical drainage is necessary for the treatment:

  • Surgical drainage is not typically the first-line management for uncomplicated cases of mastitis. Initial management usually involves antibiotic therapy, warm compresses, and continued expression of milk from the breast. Surgical drainage may be considered in cases of severe abscess formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a complaint of itchy skin in her underarms and around her nipples. On examination, small, skin-colored to yellowish papules are observed in the affected areas. The patient reports that the condition worsens during periods of increased sweat production. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fox-Fordyce disease:

  • Fox-Fordyce disease is a rare skin condition that presents with small, skin-colored to yellowish papules in areas with apocrine sweat glands, such as the underarms, nipples, and genital region. The condition is associated with blockage of the apocrine ducts, leading to inflammation and the formation of the characteristic papules. Itching is a common symptom, and the condition can worsen during periods of increased sweat production. Gender predilection, 90% cases in females

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hidradenitis suppurativa:

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the hair follicles and apocrine sweat glands. It presents with painful, inflamed nodules and abscesses, which can lead to the formation of tunnels and scarring. Unlike Fox-Fordyce disease, hidradenitis suppurativa is associated with more significant inflammation and suppuration.

Option C - Psoriasis:

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by raised, red patches with silvery scales. It typically occurs on the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. Psoriasis is not directly related to apocrine sweat glands and does not present with small, yellowish papules as seen in Fox-Fordyce disease.

Option D - Contact dermatitis: 

  • Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction caused by exposure to allergens or irritants. It leads to red, itchy, and sometimes blistered skin. While it can occur in various body regions, it is not specifically associated with apocrine sweat gland areas and does not present with small, skin-colored to yellowish papules like Fox-Fordyce disease.

questions.text: Which among the following rickets is also known as Vitamin D-resistant rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - VDDR type 2:

  • This is also known as Vitamin D-resistant rickets
  • End organ resistance to 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit D3 At the level of receptors

Clinical Features

  • Early onset Rickets
  • High prevalence of alopecia and ectodermal defects:(oligodontia, Milia, Epidermal cysts)

Investigations

  • Hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia
  • Secondary hyper PTH
  • Elevated 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit D3 Level

Treatment

  • A large dose of Ca2+ for a prolonged period
  • Responses to treatment are not satisfactory

Incorrect Options:

Option A - VDDR type 1

Option C - Familial Hypophosphatemic Rickets

Option D - Nutritional rickets

  • These are not known by Vitamin D-resistant rickets

questions.text: A 38-year woman presents in the OPD with the complaint of menorrhagia and severe pelvic and lower abdominal pain for the last 2 days. Her USG reveals a large fibroid for which she needs a hysterectomy. She is admitted to the ward for surgery. A gynaecologist instructs his residents regarding the pre-operative preparation of patients planned for hysterectomy during ward rounds. Which of these is a relevant instruction?

choices.text: A prophylactic antibiotic is given at the time of skin incision
The dose of antibiotic should be repeated after 3 hours in case the surgery is prolonged, or there is excessive bleeding
Povidone-iodine preparations have a lower rate of SSI than chlorhexidine alcohol-based preparations
All patients must be screened for bacterial vaginosis and adequately treated

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: The dose of antibiotic should be repeated after 3 hours in case the surgery is prolonged or there is excessive bleeding.

  • Prophylactic antibiotic: single dose 30 to 60 minutes before skin incision (and not at the incision). Cefazolin 1 to 2 g and increased to 3 g for obese patients is recommended.
  • Re-dosing is recommended after 3 hours of surgery and with excessive bleeding.
  • Chlorhexidine-alcohol–based skin preparations have lower surgical site infection odds than povidone-iodine preparations. Concentrations of 4% or less can be used in the vagina.
  • Although treating all patients with bacterial vaginosis may decrease vaginal cuff cellulitis, universal screening preoperatively is not recommended as a routine.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Prophylactic antibiotic is given at the time of skin incision.

  • A single dose of antibiotic should be given at 30 to 60 minutes before skin incision (and not at the time of incision)as the effective amount of serum and tissue level of the drug, at the time of incision, is needed to ensure its function.

Option C: Povidone-iodine preparations have a lower rate of SSI than chlorhexidine alcohol-based preparations.

  • Chlorhexidine alcohol is more effective in SSI than povidone-iodine preparations.

Option D: All patients must be screened for bacterial vaginosis and adequately treated

  • It is better to treat the infection before surgery, but it is not a requirement.

questions.text: A P1L1 woman with previous normal delivery, presents with irregular bleeding and uterine mass. The HCG is 8,120 mIU/mL. Biopsy reveals trophoblast tissue with absent chorionic villi with local invasion. The patient is now being evaluated for spread of disease and prognosis. Which of the following is TRUE about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Most common site of metastasis is vagina
Presence of Lung metastasis classifies as stage 4 GTN
This HCG value has a good prognosis
Prognosis is good as previous pregnancy is a full term delivery

questions.solution:
Option C : BHCG <10,000 carries good prognosis.

PROGNOSTIC SCORING 0 1 2 4
1. Age <=39 >39    
2. Antecedent pregnancy mole abortion term pregnancy  
3. Interval (pregnancy and start of CT) <4 4-6 7-12 >12
4. Hcg <10,000 1000 - 10,000 10,000 - 1 lakh >1 lakh
5. Blood group   O or A B or AB  
6. Largest tumor size <3 3-5 >5  
7. Site of metastasis   spleen, kidney GIT Brain, liver
8. No. of metastasis   1-3 4-8 >8
9. Prior chemotherapy     1 drug >=2 drugs

Option A : Most common site of metastasis in choriocarcinoma is lung, which is classified as stage 3.

Option B : Lung involvement in choriocarcinoma is classified as stage III and not IV.

Option D :GTN following term pregnancy carries worse prognosis than that following a molar pregnancy or an abortion.

questions.text: What epithelium lines the lingual surface of the epiglottis ?
questions.solution:
Option D: Stratified squamous epithelium
