  • The stratified squamous epithelium present in the oropharynx ,lingual surface of epiglottis is non-keratinized. It consists of multiple layers of cells. Cells present at the top layer are squamous in shape and lack keratinization.
  • In contrast, the laryngeal surface of the epiglottis is lined by pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar epithelium (respiratory epithelium).

Option A: Simple Columnar

  • Simple columnar epithelium: Height > Breath; Oval Basal nucleus.

Option B: Pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar

  • Pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar cells are usually present in the respiratory tract.
  • This type of epithelium with Stereocilia is also seen in male reproductive tubes like epididymis and ductus deferens

Option C: Simple Cuboidal

  • Simple Cuboidal cell: height=Breath; Central Spherical nucleus.
  • Present in Thyroid follicle and kidney (PCT, DCT).

questions.text: Preterm babies are born with thinner and less developed skin compared to full-term infants. Which of the following is a characteristic feature associated with the skin of preterm babies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Absence of Stratum Corneum:

  • Preterm babies, being born prematurely, often have underdeveloped skin, which can lead to the absence or immaturity of certain skin layers. The Stratum Corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis and is responsible for providing a protective barrier to the skin. In preterm infants, this layer may be less developed or absent, making their skin more susceptible to fluid loss, infection, and external irritants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Absence of Stratum Basale: The Stratum Basale is the deepest layer of the epidermis, and it is responsible for cell proliferation and regeneration of the epidermal layers. It contains basal cells that continuously divide to produce new keratinocytes. The Stratum Basale is an essential layer for the renewal and repair of the epidermis. It is not typically affected in preterm babies.

Option B - Absence of Stratum Granulosum: The Stratum Granulosum is a layer of the epidermis located between the Stratum Spinosum and the Stratum Corneum. It plays a crucial role in the production of keratin and the formation of keratohyalin granules, which contribute to the skin's barrier function. While preterm babies may have less-developed Stratum Granulosum due to their premature birth, it is not specifically known for its absence

Option D - Absence of Stratum Lucidum: The Stratum Lucidum is a clear, translucent layer of the epidermis found in specific areas such as the palms and soles. While preterm babies may have less-developed Stratum Lucidum due to their premature birth, it is not specifically known for its absence

questions.text: A patient with barotrauma-related effusion and severe pain that did not improve with conservative treatments presents for further management. Which of the following interventions is the most appropriate consideration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Myringotomy:

  • Myringotomy is a surgical procedure that involves making a small incision in the tympanic membrane (eardrum) to drain fluid or relieve pressure in the middle ear.
  • It is an effective intervention for cases of barotrauma-related effusion and severe pain that do not respond to conservative treatments.
  • By creating a controlled opening, it allows for the drainage of accumulated fluid and can alleviate symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Politzerization:

  • Politzerization is a technique used to deliver air into the middle ear by applying positive pressure through the nasopharynx.
  • It is commonly used to treat Eustachian tube dysfunction and can help equalize pressure in the middle ear.
  • However, in the case of barotrauma-related effusion and severe pain, it may not be the most effective intervention.

Option B - Catheterization:

  • Catheterization involves inserting a catheter through the Eustachian tube to deliver air or fluids into the middle ear. It is used to relieve Eustachian tube blockage and can be helpful in certain cases of Eustachian tube dysfunction. However, it may not be the most suitable intervention for barotrauma-related effusion and severe pain.

Option C - Antihistaminic medications:

  • Antihistaminic medications are commonly used to treat allergies and can help reduce inflammation and congestion in the nasal passages.
  • While they may provide some relief for symptoms associated with barotrauma, they are not specifically targeted at resolving effusion or severe pain.

questions.text: A 40-year-old returning traveler from Africa presents with fever, headache, and swollen posterior cervical lymph nodes, showing the Winterbottom sign. The vector for this infection is the tsetse fly. The two forms of the disease are West African sleeping sickness and East African sleeping sickness. What are the treatment options for these two forms of sleeping sickness?

choices.text: Both West African and East African sleeping sickness are treated with pentamidine.
West African sleeping sickness is treated with pentamidine, while East African sleeping sickness is treated with suramine.
West African sleeping sickness is treated with suramine, while East African sleeping sickness is treated with pentamidine.
Both West African and East African sleeping sickness are treated with suramine

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - West African sleeping sickness is treated with pentamidine, while East African sleeping sickness is treated with suramine:

  • West African Sleeping Sickness (T.B. gambiense): This form of sleeping sickness is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and primarily affects humans. Treatment for West African sleeping sickness involves the use of pentamidine, an antiparasitic medication.
  • East African Sleeping Sickness (T.B. rhodesiense): This form is caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and mainly affects animals. It is more virulent and resistant than T.B. gambiense. For East African sleeping sickness, the treatment of choice is suramine.
  • The Winterbottom sign, which includes posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, is characteristic of both forms of sleeping sickness. The differentiation in treatment options lies in the species causing the infection and their respective sensitivities to medications.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A 29yr old woman with IUCD Presents with amenorrhea of 5 weeks and a pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely fate of this pregnancy??

choices.text: Pregnancy with the high possibility of fetal malformations.
Intra Uterine pregnancy with a high possibility of spontaneous abortion.
Invasive mole is a high possibility.

questions.solution:
Option C : Pregnancy test must be done when any woman on IUCD presents with amenorrhea. While there is a significant increase in rate of ectopic pregnancy if the patient conceives with an IUCD, the greatest probability is that the pregnancy would be intrauterine. The IUCD should be removed, if possible, as soon as the patient is found to be pregnant.

Pregnant IUCD users still have a 25% chance of spontaneous abortion even if the IUCD is removed. However, failure to remove the IUCD during pregnancy increases the risk of spontaneous abortion to 50%.

Also, there is significant chance of septic abortion and premature birth if the IUCD cannot be removed.

Option A : The risk of ectopic pregnancy is there, but not invariably.

Option B : IUCD users who are pregnant are not at risk for fetal malformations.

Option D : IUCD pregnancy is not associated with an increased risk of invasive mole .

questions.text: A healthy 4-year-old girl is brought in by her parents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset vomiting and diarrhea for the last 2 hours. Within four hours, her symptoms worsened, followed by decreasing responsiveness and seizures with tachycardia. Her blood reports show marked hypokalemia and hyperglycemia. Her parents have a suspicion that she might have ingested her father's tablets this morning. Which of the following drugs has been ingested by the patient, causing these features?
questions.solution:
Option D: Theophylline

  • Based on the clinical symptoms and signs given in the scenario, the most likely drug ingested by the child is theophylline. 
  • Theophylline is primarily used as a bronchodilator for patients with asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 
  • Theophylline is also used to treat bradycardia and apnea in premature newborns.
  • Theophylline has a narrow therapeutic window, and even levels slightly above this therapeutic window can have many adverse effects in the setting of acute and chronic toxicity. Theophylline intoxication can cause hypokalemia, and hyperglycemia.
Clinical Effects of Theophylline Intoxication
Clinical   Laboratory
CNS Agitation, hyperreflexia, tremor, ataxia, seizures. Hypercalcemia Hypokalemia
GI Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, hematemesis. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis.
CVS Sinus tachycardia, hypotension, volume depletion, supraventricular tachycardia, ventricular tachycardia, cardiac arrest.  
Pulmonary Tachypnea  

Option A: Propranolol

  • Propranolol is a nonselective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker,
  • It is used to treat high blood pressure, irregular heartbeats, and essential tremors and is indicated in the prevention of migraine headaches.
  • Its side effects are usually mild and short-lived, including bradycardia, vomiting, cold extremities and trouble sleeping

Option B: Clonidine

  • Clonidine belongs to centrally acting alpha-agonist hypotensive agents.
  • It is used to treat high blood pressure and migraine headaches. 
  • Clonidine is commonly associated with adverse effects such as dry mouth, sedation, dizziness and constipation
  • Serious adverse effects are cardiopulmonary instability and central nervous system depression.

Option C: Verapamil

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker.
  • It works by relaxing the muscles of the heart and blood vessels.
  • It is used to treat hypertension, angina and certain cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of liver disease presents with complaints of incoordination, slurred speech, and hand tremors. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes a characteristic brownish-golden ring at the periphery of the cornea. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the disease the patient is suffering from?

choices.text: The ring starts superiorly and inferiorly first.
Ring is formed due to deposition of the copper.
All cases with hepatic involvement will present with the ring.
Most cases with Neurological involvement will present with the ring.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - All cases with hepatic involvement will present with the ring:

  • The patient is suffering from Wilson disease, and the brownish-golden ring is a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring.
  • Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a characteristic sign of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder that results in the accumulation of copper in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eye.
  • While KF rings are commonly associated with Wilson's disease, not all cases with hepatic involvement will necessarily present with these rings; only 65% of cases will show KF rings. The presence of KF rings is often seen in patients with neurological (95% cases) involvement rather than hepatic involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The ring starts superiorly and inferiorly first: This statement is true. In Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings typically start to appear at the superior and inferior portions of the cornea due to the deposition of copper. Over time, the ring becomes more complete.

Option B - Ring is formed due to the deposition of copper: This statement is true. KF rings are indeed formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet's cornea membrane.

Option D - Most cases with Neurological involvement will present with the ring: This statement is true. KF rings are often associated with neurological involvement in Wilson's disease. While not all patients with Wilson's disease will have neurological symptoms, when neurological symptoms are present, KF rings are more likely to be observed as well.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 32 weeks and three days of pregnancy, presents with vaginal bleeding. A recent transabdominal pelvic ultrasound report mentioned a placenta previa. In which of the following situation it is possible to do conservative management?

choices.text: Significant bleeding making mother hemodynamically unstable

questions.solution:
Option C: Transverse lie

Management of bleeding placenta previa

  • The first episode of bleeding in placenta previa usually subsides with conservative management in 90% of cases. Thus, antepartum haemorrhage (APH) prior to 34 weeks may be managed conservatively. This is the basis of Mcaffee Johnson’s conservative management in APH due to placenta previa

Contraindications of conservative management/ Indications of termination of pregnancy in placenta previa:

  • Pregnancy >37 weeks
  • Maternal decompensation secondary to significant bleeding
  • Fetal distress
  • Intra Uterine fetal death
  • Malformed Fetus

An important point to remember is that malpresentation or malposition is not a contraindication to conservative management.

Option A: Fetal heart rate of 86/min

  • Normal fetal heart rate (FHR) is between 110-160 beats per minute (bpm) with an acceleration of 10-15 bpm for 15 seconds or above and no recurrent or variable deceleration.
  • In this option, the FHR is 81 bpm which indicates fetal bradycardia or fetal compromise, an indication of delivery.

Option B: Intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD)

  • Intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) indicates that the fetus has died inside the uterus after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • In cases of IUFD, there is no point of conserving the pregnancy, thus focus is on maternal health and well-being.
  • The mode of delivery in IUFD is determined by the age of gestation or maternal condition. However, as the fetus is already dead,  C-section are avoided.

Option D: Significant bleeding making mother hemodynamically unstable

  • Significant bleeding leading to maternal hemodynamically unstable condition is an indication of aggressive management of placenta previa.

questions.text: What does the A fragment of cholera toxin primarily do intracellularly?

choices.text: Blocking sodium channels in the intestinal epithelium.
Blocking the binding of GM1 ganglioside

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Activating adenylate cyclas:

  • Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae bacteria and is responsible for the characteristic clinical features of cholera, including profuse, watery diarrhea ("rice water stools") and severe dehydration.

The cholera toxin is indeed bipartite, consisting of two main fragments: A and B.

  • Fragment A (action): This fragment is responsible for the intracellular actions of the toxin. It has two fragments, A1 and A2. The A2 fragment only links the biologically active A1 fragment to the B subunit. A1 fragment activates adenylate cyclase, which is an enzyme responsible for converting ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP). Increased levels of cAMP in the intestinal epithelial cells lead to phosphorylation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulatory protein (CFTR) leading to increased secretion of chloride ions (Cl-) and bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) into the intestinal lumen. This disrupts the normal osmotic balance and results in a massive efflux of water, leading to the profuse, watery diarrhea seen in cholera.
  • Fragment B (binding): This fragment is responsible for binding to the GM1 ganglioside on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding allows the toxin to be internalized into the cells, where the A fragment exerts its effects.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Blocking sodium channels in the intestinal epithelium: This statement is incorrect. Cholera toxin does not directly block sodium channels. Instead, it primarily affects the adenylate cyclase pathway, as described above, leading to increased chloride and bicarbonate secretion and subsequent water efflux.

Option B - Inhibiting adenylate cyclase activity: This statement is incorrect. Cholera toxin actually activates adenylate cyclase, as described above. It does not inhibit its activity.

Option D - Blocking the binding of GM1 ganglioside: This statement is incorrect. The B fragment of cholera toxin is responsible for binding to the GM1 ganglioside on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding is essential for the toxin's internalization and subsequent intracellular actions of the A fragment.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient is admitted to the neurosurgery floor with a complaint of seizures. An MRI is done, which is suggestive of a tumour. A stereotactic brain biopsy of the tumour is taken in which tumour cells exhibit a histological pattern, as shown in the image. The tumour has high vascularity. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma tumours make their own blood supply, which helps them grow. It was previously called glioblastoma multiforme.
  • The histologic appearance of glioblastoma is similar to anaplastic astrocytoma, with the additional features of necrosis and vascular/endothelial cell proliferation.
  • Necrosis in glioblastoma often occurs in a serpentine pattern in areas of hypercellularity. Tumour cells produce a histologic pattern referred to as pseudo-palisading (i.e. Tumor cells collect along the edges of the necrotic regions).

  • Pseudopalisading, i.e. necrosis surrounded by tumour cells.

  • Glomeruloid body, i.e. endothelial cell proliferation

Option B: Meningiomas

  • It is a common benign tumour.
  • It is more common in females than males.
  • It occurs along the surface of the brain or spinal cord.
  • Extra-axial (external to brain parenchyma) and may have a dural attachment.
  • It is often asymptomatic; may present with seizures or focal neurologic signs.
  • Histology shows arachnoid cell origin.
  • Spindle cells are concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern; with laminated calcifications called psammoma bodies.

Option C: Cerebellopontine angle schwannoma

  • Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading it.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is characterized by the occurrence of bilateral vestibular (cranial nerve VIII) schwannomas, multiple meningiomas, and ependymomas of the cervical spinal cord.
  • Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively.
  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is commonly seen.
  • Resulting structures with central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei are termed Verrocay bodies.
  • In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas, the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with the microcyst formation

Option D: Ependymoma

  • Most commonly found in the fourth ventricle.
  • Histologically, it is of ependymal origin.
  • Characteristic “peri-vascular pseudo-rosettes” are seen.
  • Rod-shaped blepharoblasts (basal ciliary bodies) are found near the nucleus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of nasal obstruction and a unilateral nasal mass. On examination, a crescent sign is observed. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Excisional biopsy of the nasal mass

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery 

  • The surgery of choice for AC polyps is Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS).
  • FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for the removal of diseased tissues while preserving as much normal mucosa as possible. It is performed using an endoscope and helps to alleviate the symptoms caused by the polyp.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medical therapy with antibiotics:

  • According to the given information, medical therapy has no role in the treatment of Antrochoanal (AC) polyps. While antibiotics may be given to clear any associated infection, they will not resolve the polyp itself.

Option B - Observation and follow-up:

  • AC polyps typically require surgical intervention for definitive treatment. Observation and follow-up alone would not address the underlying problem.

Option D - Excisional biopsy of the nasal mass:

  • While it is important to evaluate any nasal mass, an excisional biopsy is not the primary treatment for AC polyps. FESS is the preferred surgical approach for these polyps.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady known for fibroid uterus presents to OPD with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding associated with lower abdominal pain. She is advised to undergo the procedure of laparoscopic myomectomy. Which one of the following instruments used in laparoscopic myomectomy is shown below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Laparoscopic Myoma Screw

  • The laparoscopic Myomectomy screw is similar to the myomectomy screw used in open myomectomy.
  • The 'Screw' is inserted into the fibroid specimen to provide traction, which helps dissection around the fibroid to release it from the muscular grip of the uterine walls.
  • The laparoscopic Myomectomy Screw is shown below:

  • The myomectomy screw used for Open Myomectomy is shown below:

Option A: Myoma Morcellator

  • This device is commonly used in laparoscopic hysterectomy and myomectomy for piecemeal extraction of specimen through small ports.

  • The picture mentioned above shows the myoma morcellator

Option C: Myomectomy clamp

  • This device is used for clamping the vascular bundles during myomectomy for temporarily devascularizing the uterus to reduce blood loss during surgery. 
  • The commonly used one is a Bonney's clamp as shown below.

Option D: Bonney’s elevator/ myomectomy clamp

questions.text: Active management of the third stage of labor involves using a uterotonic, uterine massage, and controlled cord traction. Oxytocin is a uterotonic drug. What is the mean half-life of oxytocin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Option A: 3-5 min

  • The mean half-life of the oxytocin is between 3 to 5 minutes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 1-3 min

Option C: 5-6 min

Option D: 7-8 min

questions.text: In June 2007, India banned 25 pesticides. On the 'banned' pesticides and formulations list, are aldrin, Benzene hexachloride, Calcium cyanide, Chlordane, Copper cetoarsenite, Cibromochloropropane, Endrin, and 19 others. All the following statements about Endrin are true, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Least toxic organochlorine:

  • Endrin is the MOST toxic organochlorine.
  • It is often referred to as 'plant penicillin' due to its broad-spectrum activity against various insect pests.
  • A kerosene-like smell emanating from the mouth and nostrils is a sign of Endrin poisoning. This odor may be detectable even in decomposed bodies.
  • Endrin resists putrefaction and can be
  • detected in the viscera quite sometime after death.

Incorrect Options:

Option B/ C/ D - Also known as plant penicillin/ Has kerosene-like smell/ Resists putrefaction:

  • Endrin is also called 'plant penicillin' because of its broad spectrum of activity against various insect pests.
  • Kerosene-like smell from the mouth and nostrils, may be found even in decomposed bodies and resists putrefaction.
  • These statements are true

questions.text: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) comprises a group of interventions performed to provide oxygenation and circulation to the body during cardiac arrest. The American Heart Association produces the most widely accepted guidelines for cardiopulmonary Resuscitation in North America. Which is the ventilation to cardiac compression ratio in adult CPR with two rescuers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2:30:

  • The ratio of ventilation to cardiac compression is 2:30
  • Chest compression and Resuscitation:
    • High-quality cardiopulmonary Resuscitation involves adequate chest compressions to a depth of at least 5 cm (2 inches) in adults.
    • If a feedback device is used, the compression depth can be increased to 6 cm.
    • The compression rate should be 100-120/ minute.
    • Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.
    • Minimize interruptions in compressions (10 seconds or less).
    • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or earlier if fatigued.
    • A 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio is used
    • Avoid excessive ventilation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1:15:

  • This is not the ventilation-to-compression ratio used in CPR.
  • The recommended ratio is 2:30

Option C - 30:2:

  • 30:2 is the compression-to-ventilation ratio, not the ventilation-to-compression ratio

Option D - 2:10:

  • The recommended ventilation-to-compression ratio is 30:2

questions.text: What are the components of the Currarino triad?

choices.text: Pre-sacral meningocele + Sacral defect + Tethered cord
Ectopia vesicae + Anorectal malformation + Sacrococcygeal osseous defect
Anorectal malformations + Sacrococcygeal osseous defect + Presacral mass
Tethered cord + Anorectal malformations + Ectopia vesicae

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anorectal malformations + Sacrococcygeal osseous defect + Presacral mass:

  • The Currarino triad or ASP triad is an inherited disorder characterized by anomalies of the sacrum, anorectal, and presacral soft tissues.
  •  The characteristic findings of the Currarino triad are:
    • Anorectal malformation or congenital anorectal stenosis
    • Sacrococcygeal osseous defect (always present)
      • Classically, hemi sacrum with intact first sacral vertebra ("sickle-shaped sacrum")
      • Mild (hypoplasia) to severe (agenesis) of sacrum and coccyx
    • Presacral mass (various types)
      • Anterior sacral meningocele
      • Tumour, e.g., mature teratoma
      • Dermoid/epidermoid cyst

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pre-sacral meningocele + Sacral defect + Tethered cord:

  • Tethered spinal cord syndrome is the abnormal stretching of the spinal cord.
  • This syndrome is associated with the following:
    • Spina bifida
    • Spinal surgery
  • The tethered spinal cord is not associated with the Currarino triad.

Option B - Ectopia vesicae + Anorectal malformation + Sacrococcygeal osseous defect:

  • Ectopia vesicae is a congenital anomaly causing exstrophy of the bladder.
  • It is associated with the exstrophy-epispadias complex.
  • Ectopia vesicae are not associated with the Currarino triad.

Option D - Tethered cord + Anorectal malformations + Ectopia vesicae:

  • Tethered spinal cord and ectopia vesicae are not associated with the Currarino triad.

questions.text: In a population where tuberculosis is endemic, a 54-year-old male patient presents with a history of recurrent cough, low-grade fever, and weight loss over the past 6 months. Upon further investigation, sputum smear microscopy reveals acid-fast bacilli (AFB), and subsequent drug susceptibility testing confirms resistance to Isoniazid (H). Which of the following best defines a patient with pre-XDR tuberculosis?

choices.text: Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H)
Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to fluoroquinolone and Group-A drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin)
Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to fluoroquinolone:

  • Pre-Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis (Pre-XDR TB): TB caused by strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis) meeting the criteria for multidrug-resistant and rifampicin-resistant TB (MDR/RR-TB), and additionally resistant to any fluoroquinolone.
  • Drug-susceptible TB and XDR TB are spread the same way.
  • Because Pre-XDR TB is resistant to the most potent TB drugs, the remaining treatment options are less effective, have more side effects, and are more expensive.
  • Pre-XDR TB is of special concern for persons with HIV infection or other conditions that can weaken the immune system.

Drug resistance:

Multi drug resistant (MDR) Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H),
Poly-Drug resistant ( PDR) Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H)
pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR) Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.
Xtensive resistant (XDR) Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and
atleast 1 additional Group-A drug (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Resistance to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H):

  • Poly-drug resistance (PDR) in Tuberculosis is defined as resistance to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Option B - Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to fluoroquinolone and Group-A drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin):

  • Xtensive resistance (XDR) in Tuberculosis is defined as Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and at least 1 additional group A drug  (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

Option D - Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H):

  • MDR in Tuberculosis is defined as resistance to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

questions.text: A 36 years old woman has not had menses for the last 4 months. A pregnancy test is negative. USG pelvis showed no significant abnormality. On per vaginal examination, no abnormality was detected, and the patient is a non-smoker and not using tobacco and illicit drugs. On laboratory evaluation, serum levels of LH & FSH were raised. Serum estradiol level was low. These findings are suggestive of which the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Premature menopause

  • The woman has presented with secondary amenorrhea with raised LH, FSH, and low estrogen, which are suggestive of menopause. Menopause occurring at 40 years or less is known as premature menopause.

Menopause is characterized by: 

  • ↑ FSH level
  • ↑ FSH/LH ratio
  • Low E2 level

This patient has raised both LH and FSH, with FSH being higher than LH leading to premature menopause

Incorrect options:

Option A: Bilateral tubal obstruction

  • Bilateral tubal obstruction usually interferes with fertility, but the hormonal profile may be normal or with slight variation but does not cause amenorrhea.

Option B: PCOD

  • PCOD shows a reversal of LH: FSH ratio, 2:1 or 3:1; however, this patient does not show any history of cystic ovarian disorder.

Option D: Exogenous estrogen administration

  • Exogenous estrogen administration does not cause amenorrhea and is associated with low FSH and high estrogen

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, which instrument is used to create a pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Veress Needle:

  • A Veress needle, or Veres needle, is a spring-loaded needle used in laparoscopic surgery to create pneumoperitoneum.
  • The Veress needle technique is the oldest and most traditional of the three general approaches to laparoscopic access.
  • Modern needles range in length from 12 to 15 cm and have an external diameter of 2 mm.
  • The outer cannula has a beveled needlepoint for cutting through abdominal wall tissues. Within the outer cannula is a spring-loaded inner stylet. The blunt tip of this inner stylet protects any viscera from injury by the sharp outer cannula. The direct pressure on the tip, such as when piercing tissue, forces the blunt stylet into the shaft of the outer cannula. The blunt inner stylet springs forward when the needle tip enters a space, such as the peritoneal cavity. The Veress needle is then used to inflate the space, resulting in a pneumoperitoneum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hasson’s Cannula:

  • Hasson’s cannula was a blunt (open) mini-laparotomy access to reduce the incidence of injuries associated with the blind access of the peritoneal cavity with the Veress needle and the initial trocar.
  • It is a reusable device that looks like a standard cannula but has an olive-shaped cone attached to it (sleeve).
  • Several disposable open-access devices have been released.
  • They are similar to Hasson's reusable system, except the stay sutures are attached directly to the olive, allowing cannula depth manipulation without detaching the stay sutures.
  • However, the primary method of peritoneal access has stayed the same.

 

Option B: GB trocar

  • The Ochsner gallbladder trocar is a 100 mm long instrument in various circumferences.
  • The primary purpose of this trocar is to drain a fluid-filled cavity using a sharp point.
  • For example, if there is pus or mucus in the gallbladder, this instrument can remove it.

Option D - Central venous Catheter:

  • A central venous catheter is a thin, flexible tube inserted into a vein, usually below the right collarbone, and guided (threaded) into the superior vena cava, a large vein above the right side of the heart.
  • It is employed in administering intravenous fluids, blood transfusions, chemotherapy, and other drugs.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to the physician complaining of swelling in both feet. He had a low anterior resection for colon cancer 15 days ago. Examination of the lower extremities reveals non-pitting edema extending till the lower thighs. One of the interns made a differential diagnosis of primary lymphedema after a microscopic examination of the interstitial space in this patient's lower extremities. Which of the following statements about the patient's current pathology is correct?

choices.text: Familial version of lymphedema praecox is known as Milroy disease
Lymphedema tarda is seen after 35 years
In congenital lymphedema, the swelling is limited to the foot and calf
Familial version of congenital lymphedema is known as Meig’s disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lymphedema tarda is seen after 35 years:

  • This is a case of lymphedema in which the patient complains of swelling in both feet. 

Congenital Lymphedema

Lymphedema Praecox

Lymphedema Tarda
  • Onset before 1st year of life
  • Edema is typically present at birth
  • It can involve a single lower extremity, multiple limbs, genitalia, or face
  • More likely to be bilateral and involve the whole leg
  • A familial version of congenital lymphedema is known as Milroy disease
  • Onset between 1-35 years
  • MC type, seen in 90% of cases
  • More common in women
  • Mostly unilateral
  • Limited to foot and calf
  • A familial version of lymphedema praecox is known as Meig’s disease
  • Onset after 35 years
  • Relatively rare

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The familial version of lymphedema praecox is known as Milroy disease:

  • A familial version of lymphedema praecox is known as Meig’s disease
  • Milroy disease is a different pathology
  • Lymphedema praecox is the most common type of lymphedema.

Option C - In congenital lymphedema, the swelling is limited to the foot and calf:

  • In congenital lymphedema, swelling is not limited to the foot and calf.
  • Congenital lymphedema can involve a single lower extremity, multiple limbs, genitalia, or face.

Option D - The familial version of congenital lymphedema is known as Meig’s disease:

  • A familial version of lymphedema praecox is known as Meig’s disease.
  • Congenital lymphedema is typically present at birth.
  • A familial version of congenital lymphedema is known as Milroy Disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was a case of a right inguinal hernia and was posted for hernioplasty under spinal anaesthesia. Injection bupivacaine 0.5% hyperbaric solution was given at L3-L4 space. What is the order of sensory blockade expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Temperature – pain – touch – pressure:

  • Different fibre types respond differently to local anaesthetic blocking.
  • Small myelinated axons (Aγ motor and Aδ sensory fibres) are most vulnerable to impulse inhibition.
  • Large myelinated fibres Aα and Aβ follow in block order.
  • Small non-myelinated C fibres are the least vulnerable.
  • Clinical trials of block effectiveness targeting Aδ sensory fibres

C sC - 0.3-1.3 0.7-1.3 Postganglionic sympathetic Various autonomic function ++
