Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pain – pressure – touch – temperature:

  • Temperature is the most sensitive to local anaesthetics, so it would be lost first.
  • It is the last to recover after the reversal of the block

Option C - Pressure – touch– pain– temperature:

  • This is the order in which the sensations are regained after the reversal of the block.
  • The sensation least sensitive for the local anaesthetic is regained first, and the most sensitive is regained at the very end.

Option D - Touch – pain – pressure – temperature:

  • Temperature is the most sensitive to local anaesthetics, so it would be lost first.
  • It is the last to recover after the reversal of the block

questions.text: A 2-day-old male baby presents to the hospital with complaints of yellowish skin discoloration associated with acholic stools. Which of the following is the most common cause of cholestatic jaundice in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Biliary atresia

  • Neonatal cholestasis is defined biochemically as prolonged elevation of the serum levels of conjugated bilirubin (> 2 mg/dl or >20% of total bilirubin level) beyond the first 14 days of life.
  • The most common cause of neonatal cholestasis is Biliary atresia > Neonatal hepatitis
  • This condition is commonly found in newborns, where the bilirubin is not transferred to the intestine, so it accumulates in the liver and damages the liver.
  • In this disease, fibro-obliterative obstruction of the bile duct causes cholestasis.
  • The definitive treatment is surgery.
  • It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in infants

Option B: Neonatal hepatitis

  • Neonatal hepatitis is the inflammation of the liver that occurs between the first and second months of life.
  • It causes an increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin levels

Option C: Choledochal cyst

  • A choledochal cyst is a swelling of the bile duct in which the transport of bilirubin from the liver to the intestine is disrupted. So the bilirubin accumulates in the liver.
  • It is a congenital condition with increased carcinoma or gallbladder cancer risk. There are 5 types of choledochal cysts, but Type 1 and Type 4 have more complicated forms.

Option D: Physiological jaundice

  • In physiological jaundice, the baby's liver cannot be removed from the body.
  • It typically appears on the second and third day of life

questions.text: Which of the following images represents the correct location of codons and anticodons during the transcription and translation of genetic information?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – C:

  • mRNA codons are read in the 5'-3' direction.
  • tRNA features a cloverleaf structure with three arms and an amino acid attachment site on its stem, where the CCA sequence is added post-transcriptionally.
  • The anticodon arm of tRNA binds to mRNA codons via complementary base pairing, following the Wobble principle, which allows for non-standard base pairing at the third codon position.
  • The three arms of tRNA include the pseudouridine (TѰC) arm, anticodon arm, and D arm.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – A:

  • The codon and anticodon locations are mislabeled.
  • AUG is the codon on mRNA, and UAC is the anticodon on tRNA.

Option B – B:

  • The codon AUG is correctly labeled, but the anticodon UAC on the tRNA is mislabeled.
  • 5’-CCA-3' is not the anticodon but rather the amino acid attachment site on tRNA.

Option D – D:

  • The codon and anticodon are both mislabeled.
  • AUG on the mRNA is the codon, UAC is the anticodon on the tRNA, and CAA is the amino acid attachment site on the 3' end of the tRNA.

questions.text: Acute retropharyngeal abscess is due to suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes, commonly seen in children below 3 years. What is the most likely cause of an acute retropharyngeal abscess?

choices.text: Acute suppurative lymphadenitis of lymph nodes of Rouviere

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Acute suppurative lymphadenitis of lymph nodes of Rouviere

  • This is the correct answer. Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly caused by the suppuration (formation of pus) of the lymph nodes of Rouviere, which are located in the retropharyngeal space.
  • This condition is more common in children with tonsillitis and adenoiditis, or in adults due to posterior pharyngeal wall injury, such as swallowing a fish bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Parapharyngeal space infection:

  • The parapharyngeal space is a different anatomical compartment located lateral to the retropharyngeal space.
  • Infections involving the parapharyngeal space can cause symptoms similar to a retropharyngeal abscess, but they are distinct entities.
  • Parapharyngeal space infections are usually associated with dental infections or the spread of infection from adjacent structures.

Option C - Infection of the peritonsillar space:

  • The peritonsillar space is another anatomical compartment surrounding the tonsils.
  • Infections in the peritonsillar space, known as peritonsillar abscess or quinsy, can cause severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a swollen tonsil.
  • Although peritonsillar abscess can be a complication of tonsillitis, it is not directly related to retropharyngeal abscess.

Option D - Medial pterygoid muscle inflammation:

  • The medial pterygoid muscle is located in the infratemporal fossa and is not directly associated with the retropharyngeal space. Inflammation of this muscle would not typically lead to a retropharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother due to delayed milestones, short stature, and obesity. A physical examination shows bowing of legs, proximal limb shortening, macrocephaly, and a trident hand. X-ray shows the champagne-glass appearance of the pelvis. What is the most likely cause of his short stature?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achondroplasia:

  • The gene involved is the FGFR 3 gene [Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor 3 Gene]
  • It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by:
    • Delayed milestones
    • Obesity
    • Bowing of legs
    • Proximal limb shortening
    • Large head
    • Trident hand
  • Short stature
  • Interpedicular distance between the vertebrae decreases
  •  Neurological problems
  • X-ray shows Champagne-glass pelvis
  • It is a type of Short limb dwarfism

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Osteogenesis imperfecta:

  • AD inheritance 
  • Type-I collagen Defect
  • Triad
    •  Recurrent fractures / Bony deformity
    •  Blue sclera
    •  Deafness

Option C - Rickets:

  • It is also a kind of short-limb dwarfism
  • The features in the question are not of Rickets
  • Craniotabes: Due to softening of cranial bones; also seen in OI, congenital syphilis, hydrocephalus, prematurity
  • Frontal and parietal bossing
  • Large AF and delayed closed of AF
  • Delayed dentition and dental caries
  • Rachitic rosary: Beading of costochondral junctions
  • Harrison sulcus: Due to the pulling of softened ribs by the diaphragm

Option D - Congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Birth weight & length usually normal
  • Wide open Anterior fontanelle and Posterior fontanelle
  • Prolonged physiological jaundice (earliest sign sometimes)
  • Myxedematous facies: Large, protruded tongue
  • Skin: Dry & scaly
  • Hypotonia, hypothermia, hoarse cry
  • Constipation

questions.text: A 68-year-old unconscious female with a known history of hypothyroidism was brought to the emergency department. Her medical records revealed she was diagnosed with a UTI 3 days back. Upon examination, the patient is lethargic, with a body temperature of 35 °C, bradycardia, and low blood pressure. Laboratory investigations reveal low free thyroxine (T4) and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. ECG revealed increased PR interval. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Myxedema coma:

  • Myxedema coma is a severe and life-threatening form of hypothyroidism.
  • It typically presents in elderly patients with a history of hypothyroidism.
  • Common triggers include infections (like UTI), cold exposure, or medications.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Hypothermia (low body temperature)
    • Bradycardia (slow heart rate)
    • Hypotension (low blood pressure)
    • Altered mental status (lethargy, unconsciousness)
  • Laboratory findings often show:
    • Low free T4
    • Elevated TSH
  • ECG may reveal bradycardia and prolonged PR interval due to the slowed metabolic state.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Hypothyroidism:

  • While the patient has hypothyroidism, the severe presentation (unconsciousness, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension) points to a more acute and severe condition.
  • Hypothyroidism alone without progression to myxedema coma would not typically present with such severe symptoms.

Option C – Hyperthyroidism:

  • Hyperthyroidism presents with opposite symptoms, such as tachycardia, weight loss, heat intolerance, and sometimes hyperthermia.
  • The laboratory findings of low free T4 and elevated TSH also contradict hyperthyroidism, where we would expect high free T4 and low TSH.

Option D - Thyroid storm:

  • Thyroid storm is a severe, life-threatening hyperthyroid state.
  • Symptoms include fever, tachycardia, hypertension, and altered mental status.
  • Laboratory findings would show high free T4 and low TSH, which is not consistent with this patient's results.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency with blurry vision and nausea. Her BP is 190/100 mmHg, and her urinalysis is positive for proteins. She is diagnosed with preeclampsia. Which of the following would be the most common warning feature of an eclamptic seizure?
questions.solution:
Option B:  Severe headache

  • The most common symptom immediately preceding a seizure is a severe headache.
  • Patients often describe it as the worst headache they have ever had.

Option A: Proteinuria

  • It is already present in preeclampsia.
  • Though it is present in eclampsia, it is not a warning clinical feature.

Option C: Facial oedema

  • It can be present in eclampsia; however, it is not the most common warning sign.

Option D: Nausea

  • It can be present in eclampsia; however, it is not a warning sign.

questions.text: A 2-day-old premature male neonate is brought to the emergency department by her mother with complaints of fever, poor feeding, and low birth weight. His mother gives a history of having burning micturition at 33 weeks of gestation. The baby has tachycardia, tachypnea, grunting, chest indrawing, and abdominal distention on examination. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test for the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Blood culture

  • This is a case of neonatal sepsis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, poor feeding, and low birth weight.
  • The neonate has a perinatal risk factor of maternal urinary tract infection at 33 weeks of gestation, and the examination findings suggest early-onset sepsis, so a sample for blood culture should be immediately taken to isolate the organism and modify the antibiotics accordingly.
  • Blood culture is the definitive test for the diagnosis of neonatal sepsis.
  • It is performed in all cases of suspected sepsis before starting antibiotics.
  • Early empiric therapy for neonates with sepsis should cover group B Streptococcus and gram-negative enteric organisms, especially Escherichia coli.
  • After retrieving the blood culture report, the treatment is modified accordingly.
  • A repeat blood culture monitors the response to antibiotics at 24 to 48 hours and the improvement in the clinical condition.

Option B: Urine culture

  • As suggested in the scenario, the baby is having an infection of the respiratory and gastrointestinal systems.
  • The gender of the baby is male, with a low incidence of urinary tract infection, and there is no history of increased urinary frequency or pyuria.

Option C: Immature: Total neutrophil ratio

  • The immature to total neutrophil (IT) ratio > 0.2 is one of the diagnostic features of sepsis.
  • This finding cannot make a diagnosis of neonatal sepsis alone.

Option D: Hemoglobin levels

  • Hemoglobin levels are significant if the baby has anemia.
  • There is no role for hemoglobin in diagnosing sepsis, as there is no significant change.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female on OCPs visits the clinic with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the last few months. Endoscopy shows ileum involvement with rectal sparing. The gross appearance of the intestine is shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific feature related to this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The specific characteristic associated with the endoscopic evaluation of ileum involvement with rectal sparing and with intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea is:

Option D. Superficial broad-based ulcers

Explanation:

This description is typical of Crohn's disease, which often involves the ileum and is characterized by the presence of superficial, broad-based ulcers. Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract but commonly involves the ileum and colon. The presence of rectal sparing (the rectum is typically not affected) is a distinguishing feature of Crohn's disease, as opposed to ulcerative colitis, another form of IBD that primarily affects the colon and rectum.

The other options are less characteristic of Crohn's disease:

Option A. Transmural involvement: While Crohn's disease can involve all layers of the intestinal wall (transmural), the presence of superficial ulcers is a key feature.

Option B. Presence of polyps: Polyps are not a defining feature of Crohn's disease but can occur in some cases.

Option C. Mucosal edema: While inflammation is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, the presence of superficial ulcers is a more specific finding. Mucosal edema may be present but is not as distinctive as the ulcers.

questions.text: An eight-year-old child living in an endemic area for leprosy presents to the community health center for prophylactic treatment. As part of the standard protocol, the healthcare provider decides to administer Rifampicin. Which of the following is the appropriate dose of Rifampicin that can be given for prophylaxis of leprosy in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 300 mg:

  • This is the correct dosage of Rifampicin for prophylaxis of leprosy in children aged 6-9 years.
  • This is in accordance with the Sparsh Programme.
  • Side effects of Rifampin include reddish discoloration or tears, sweat, and/or urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 350 mg:

  • This dose exceeds the recommended dosage for prophylaxis of leprosy in children 6-9 years and may increase the risk of adverse effects without providing additional benefit.

Option C - 400 mg:

  • This dose exceeds the recommended dosage for children 6-9 years and is not appropriate for prophylactic treatment of leprosy in this age group.
  • For children 10-14 years old, a single dose of 450 mg of Rifampin is recommended.

Option D - 600 mg:

  • This dose is higher than the recommended dosage for children 6-9 years for leprosy prophylaxis.
  • Administering such a high dose can lead to an increased risk of adverse effects without additional therapeutic benefit.
  • 600 mg is recommended for use in those ≥ 15 years of age.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman visits the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fever, and skin lesions. She reports experiencing muscle aches, joint pain, and fatigue for the past few weeks. On examination, palpable skin nodules, particularly on the lower extremities, are noted. The biopsy of a skin lesion is shown in the image.



Which of the following statements about the patient's condition is incorrect?

choices.text: It is associated with medium vessel involvement
The most common vessel affected is the renal vessel
The patient's condition is most likely rheumatoid arthritis
The microscopic image shows segmental, transmural fibrinoid necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The patient's condition is most likely rheumatoid arthritis:

  • The clinical scenario and the microscopic image described are consistent with Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN).
  • Segmental, transmural fibrinoid necrosis on histopathological examination.
  • Clinical manifestations related to organ system involvement in PAN:
    • Renal - Renal failure, hypertension
    • Musculoskeletal - Arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
    • PNS- Peripheral neuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex
    • GIT- Abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, bleeding, bowel infarction
    • Skin - Rash, purpura, nodules, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud’s phenomenon
    • Cardiac - Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, pericarditis
    • CNS- Cerebral vascular accident, altered mental status, seizures

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is associated with medium vessel involvement: PAN is characterized by inflammation of medium-sized vessels, leading to multiple organ involvement.

Option B - The most common vessel affected in PAN is the renal vessel: While PAN can affect various medium-sized vessels, the renal vessel is commonly involved.

Option D - The microscopic image shows segmental, transmural fibrinoid necrosis: The microscopic image supports the diagnosis of PAN, as it shows the characteristic feature of segmental, transmural fibrinoid necrosis seen in the affected medium-sized vessels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old adult presents with a sore throat and fever. On examination, the tonsils are red and enlarged, but there are no whitish yellow dots or a membrane present. Which type of tonsillitis is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Acute parenchymal tonsillitis

  • In acute parenchymal tonsillitis, the infection reaches the parenchyma of the tonsils, causing redness and enlargement of the tonsils.
  • This patient has red and enlarged tonsils without any whitish yellow dots or a membrane, consistent with acute parenchymal tonsillitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute superficial tonsillitis:

  • This is incorrect because in this type, there is only redness of the tonsils without any enlargement.

Option B - Acute follicular tonsillitis:

  • This is incorrect because in this type, the infection reaches the crypts of the tonsils, and whitish yellow dots (pus) are seen on the surface of the tonsils.

Option D - Acute membranous tonsillitis:

  • This is incorrect because in this type, a pearly white membrane forms on the tonsil, which is not observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman delivers a female baby by normal vaginal delivery. A pediatric resident examines the baby and notes an exaggerated Moro's reflex. Which of the following is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 1 (early/mild) Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy:

  • It causes an exaggerated Moro’s reflex

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage -3 (severe) Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy

Option B - Down syndrome

Option C - Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy

  • These conditions cause absent Moro’s reflex

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman is at 20 weeks gestation with blood group O positive, and her husband has blood group AB positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient’s query that she and her husband have different blood groups and how this would impact their baby ?

choices.text: ABO antigens elicit only an IgM response which does not cross the placenta
Antibodies to ABO antigens are not hemolytic
Newborns affected by ABO incompatibility will have only mild hemolytic disease
She is not at risk as the immune response is depressed during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Newborns affected by ABO incompatibility will have only mild hemolytic disease

  • ABO incompatibility typically occurs between a mother with blood group O and an infant with blood group A or B, which can cause mild hemolytic disease in the newborn. 
  • Affected infants are usually asymptomatic at birth or have mild anemia and may develop neonatal jaundice that typically responds to phototherapy
  • The reasons only MILD hemolysis are:
    • Low prevalence of incompatible red cell antigens;
    • Insufficient transplacental passage of fetal antigens or maternal antibodies;
    • Variable antigenicity
    • Variable maternal immune response to the antigen

Incorrect Options:

Option A: ABO antigens elicit only an IgM response that does not cross the placenta.

  • The antibodies are produced but have insufficient transplacental migration.
  • Moreover, IgG production can occur, which can cross the maternal placenta.

Option B: Antibodies to ABO antigens are not hemolytic

  • Antibodies are hemolytic, but they elicit mild hemolytic anemia due to insufficient transplacental migration. 

Option D: She is not at risk as the immune response is depressed during pregnancy

  • Although the immune system is not fully depressed during pregnancy, antibody production, and fetal transfer can occur.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with symptoms of memory loss, identity confusion, and sudden unexplained travels. Upon evaluation, you observe that the patient seems unconcerned and indifferent towards these symptoms. The patient denies any distress or impairment. Which treatment plan would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Behavior Therapy

  • The patient in the given scenario is likely experiencing symptoms of memory loss, identity confusion, and unexplained travels, suggesting a possible diagnosis of Dissociative Fugue or Dissociative Amnesia with identity confusion. The presence of "la belle indifference," or an unconcerned attitude towards the symptoms, is also observed.
  • This option focuses on addressing current symptoms and minimizing secondary and tertiary gains associated with the illness. It helps the patient move away from the symptom phase and encourages the assumption of a healthier role.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Abreaction: This option involves bringing unconscious memories and emotions to the patient's awareness. While it can be beneficial in certain cases, the patient's indifference and lack of distress make it less suitable in this scenario.

Option C - Psychodynamic Psychotherapy: This option explores the patient's unconscious conflicts and underlying psychological processes. However, since the patient appears unconcerned about their symptoms, other treatment approaches may be more appropriate.

Option D - Benzodiazepines: While benzodiazepines can be used for short-term anxiety relief, they are not the primary treatment for dissociative disorders. In this case, the patient's lack of distress and impairment suggests that pharmacotherapy may not be the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a vision center complaining of difficulty seeing at night. Upon further inquiry, she mentioned living in a poorly lit area without proper street lighting. The healthcare provider suspects her vision impairment might be due to inadequate lighting conditions. What is the unit of illuminance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Lux:

  • What is perceived as light is a narrow wavelength band of electromagnetic radiation from about 380 to 780 nm. Light containing all visible waves is perceived as white.
  • There are four measures of importance in the context of measuring light.
  • The four measures are:
    • Illumination or illuminance: It is the amount of light reaching a surface measured in lux per unit area.
    • Brightness or luminance: It is the amount of light reflected from a surface measured in lamberts.
    • Luminous intensity: It is the power of a light source considered as a point radiating in all directions. This is measured as candela or candle power.
    • Luminous flux: It is the flow of light related to a unit of solid angle measured in lumen.

Incorrect Options

Options A, C, and D- (Lambert, Lumen & Candela):

  • These units are already described in the correct answer explanation and are not the units of measurement for illuminance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with twin pregnancies has discordant twins on transvaginal ultrasound at 37 weeks of gestation. She is advised to have an elective LSCS. What should be the weight difference between two babies in discordant twins?

choices.text: 15% with the larger twin as an index
15% with the smaller twin as an index
20% with the larger twin as an index
25% with the smaller twin as an index

questions.solution:
Correct answer:

Option C : 20% with the larger twin as an index

In cases of discordant twins, where there is a significant difference in the weights of the two fetuses, the general guideline for considering an elective cesarean section (LSCS) is often a weight difference of 20% or more, with the larger twin as the index. This means that if the larger twin weighs at least 20% more than the smaller twin, it may be an indication for an elective cesarean section.

Incorrect Answers:

Explanation: 

Option A: 15% with the larger twin as an index: This option suggests a lower weight difference threshold of 15% with the larger twin as the index. However, in many clinical guidelines and practices, a 15% weight difference is considered too small to warrant an elective cesarean section.

Option B:15% with the smaller twin as an index: This option suggests a lower weight difference threshold of 15% with the smaller twin as the index. Again, this is a lower threshold than what is typically used in clinical practice.

Option D: 

25% with the smaller twin as an index: This option suggests a higher weight difference threshold of 25% with the smaller twin as the index. While a higher threshold would potentially identify more cases as discordant, it may be overly restrictive in practice.

The 20% weight difference with the larger twin as the index is a commonly used and balanced threshold that takes into consideration the potential risks associated with discordant twin pregnancies. However, it's important to note that the management of discordant twins can vary depending on various factors, including the specific clinical circumstances and the healthcare provider's judgment. Decisions regarding mode of delivery should always be made in consultation with a healthcare provider who can consider the individual case and the best interests of both the mother and the babies.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent episodes of flushing and diarrhea. The patient's stool shows an osmolar gap of less than 50 mOsm and has a rice-water appearance. The lab investigation reveals a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - WDHA syndrome:

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria), also known as VIPoma syndrome.
  • This condition is caused by excessive secretion of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) by a tumor, leading to the symptoms of flushing, diarrhea, and electrolyte disturbances such as hypokalemia.
  • The stool osmolar gap of less than 50 mOsm indicates that the diarrhea is due to excessive secretion of fluid into the intestinal lumen, which is characteristic of VIPoma syndrome (WDHA syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carcinoid syndrome:

  • Carcinoid syndrome can present with flushing and diarrhea, but it typically involves elevated levels of serotonin and urinary 5-HIAA.
  • Additionally, the osmolar gap and rice-water appearance of the stool are not characteristic of carcinoid syndrome.

Option B - Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinomas are rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that can cause diarrhea due to the inhibitory effect of somatostatin on gastrointestinal motility.
  • However, somatostatinomas are more commonly associated with diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea than with hypokalemia and a rice-water appearance of stool.

Option D - Glucagonoma:

  • Glucagonomas are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that can cause a characteristic syndrome including necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes mellitus, weight loss, and stomatitis.
  • While diarrhea can occur, it's not typically associated with a rice-water appearance of stool or significant hypokalemia.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a systematic review and a meta-analysis?

choices.text: Systematic review involves quantitative synthesis, while meta-analysis does not.
Meta-analysis involves quantitative synthesis, while systematic review does not.
Both systematic review and meta-analysis involve quantitative synthesis.
Neither systematic review nor meta-analysis involves quantitative synthesis.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Meta-analysis involves quantitative synthesis, while systematic review does not:

  • A systematic review involves structurally analyzing multiple research studies, from formulating review questions to presenting results, without statistically combining results. The meta-analysis, however, goes further by quantitatively synthesizing data from multiple studies to provide an overall estimate of effect size.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: Only meta-analysis involves quantitative synthesis, not systematic review.

questions.text: Based on the findings of the His Bundle Electrogram, if the AH Interval is prolonged, the block is most likely located at?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Within the AV node:

  • If the AH interval (the time between the activation of the atria and the activation of the His bundle, which reflects AV node conduction) is prolonged on the His Bundle Electrogram, it indicates that there is a delay within the AV node. This delay can lead to various degrees of AV block, depending on the severity of the conduction impairment.

HIS BUNDLE ELECTROGRAM (HBE)

  • A Wave - SA Nodal Depolarisation
  • H Wave - His Bundle depolarisation
  • V Wave - Ventricular depolarization

Indications

  • Heart Block → to Check whether the block is above (AV NODE) or below (Bundle branches) the His Bundle
  • To differentiate b/w ventricular & supra ventricular tachycardias
  • AH INTERVAL- (time taken for impulse to travel from SA Node to His bundle) 55 - 130ms
  • HV INTERVAL – (time taken for impulse to travel from His bundle to ventricles) 35 - 55ms
  • If AH Interval is prolonged - Block is above (AV block)
  • HV Interval is prolonged - Block is below (bundle branch block)

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Below the bundle branches: If the AH interval is prolonged, it indicates a delay in the conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node.The AV node is located above the bundle branches and is responsible for transmitting electrical signals from the atria to the ventricles. A prolonged AH interval suggests that there is an issue within the AV node itself.

Option C- In the atria: The AH interval represents the time taken for an electrical signal to travel from the atria to the ventricles. If it is prolonged, it implies a delay in the AV node's conduction, not an issue in the atria.

Option D- In the ventricles: The AH interval does not directly assess conduction within the ventricles. Instead, it primarily reflects AV node conduction. If there were an issue in the ventricles causing a prolonged AH interval, it would be indirectly due to the AV node's impaired ability to transmit signals effectively.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease abruptly discontinues his levodopa-carbidopa therapy due to fears of side effects. Shortly after, he manifests severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, confusion, elevated heart rate, blood pressure fluctuations, and profuse sweating. What is the most probable condition this patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Neuroleptic malignant syndrome:

  • Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is primarily associated with the use of antipsychotic medications, which block dopamine receptors, particularly D2 receptors. This blockade can lead to dysregulation of dopamine transmission in the brain, contributing to the development of NMS. Additionally, abrupt withdrawal or reduction of dopamine agonist medications, such as levodopa-carbidopa therapy used in Parkinson's disease, can also precipitate NMS due to sudden changes in dopamine levels.
  • The hallmark symptoms of NMS include severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, altered mental status (confusion), and autonomic instability (elevated heart rate, blood pressure fluctuations, sweating, etc.).
  • NMS is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention and typically involves hospitalization.
  • Treatment of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) involves halting the suspected neuroleptic medication and, if the withdrawal of dopaminergic drugs triggered the syndrome, reinstituting them promptly. Supportive medical care, including hydration and managing hyperthermia, is crucial. Bromocriptine and dantrolene are commonly used pharmacological treatments, while other dopaminergic agents and adjunctive medications may also be considered.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wearing-off phenomenon:

  • This refers to a phenomenon in which the effectiveness of Parkinson's disease medications, such as levodopa, starts to wear off before the next dose is due. It is characterized by a return of Parkinson's symptoms, such as tremors and rigidity, but it does not involve hyperthermia, severe muscle rigidity, or altered mental status.

Option B- Atypical parkinsonism:

  • Atypical parkinsonism refers to a group of neurodegenerative disorders that share some clinical features with Parkinson's disease but have different underlying pathology.
  • Conditions such as multiple system atrophy (MSA) and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) are examples of atypical parkinsonism.
  • These conditions may present with various symptoms including parkinsonism, autonomic dysfunction, and cognitive impairment, but they usually have a more insidious onset rather than the abrupt presentation described in the scenario.

Option C- Serotonin syndrome:

  • Serotonin syndrome is a condition characterized by excessive serotonin activity in the central nervous system. It can result from interactions between certain medications, including serotonergic antidepressants.
  • Symptoms may include agitation, confusion, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and autonomic instability, resembling NMS. However, the context of abrupt withdrawal from levodopa is not typically associated with serotonin syndrome.
  • The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome involves discontinuation of the offending medications, supportive care, and in severe cases, administration of serotonin receptor antagonists such as cyproheptadine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of thickened, discolored nails. He mentions that he has been experiencing this problem for several months and has noticed a gradual deterioration in the appearance of his nails. On examination, the patient's nails exhibit yellowish discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. There are no signs of inflammation or pain. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Tinea Unguium:

  • The clinical scenario describes a middle-aged male with thickened, discolored nails, yellowish discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. These findings are consistent with tinea unguium, also known as onychomycosis. Tinea unguium is a fungal infection of the nails caused by dermatophytes, yeasts, or molds. It commonly presents with nail thickening, discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis, without significant inflammation or pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Onychogryphosis: It is a condition characterized by overgrowth and thickening of the nails, usually due to neglect or trauma. It does not typically present with yellowish discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Option B – Paronychia: It is an infection or inflammation of the skin surrounding the nail. It is often associated with redness, swelling, and tenderness, which are not mentioned in the scenario.

Option C - Nail psoriasis: While nail psoriasis can cause changes in the nails, including onycholysis, pitting, and discoloration, the absence of signs of inflammation or pain makes nail psoriasis less likely. Nail psoriasis is often associated with skin involvement elsewhere on the body, such as plaques and scales, which are not mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe facial pain and pressure, nasal congestion, and purulent nasal discharge. She reports a history of recurrent sinus infections. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the frontal sinuses and bilateral nasal polyps. The patient is afebrile, and there are no signs of orbital or intracranial involvement. A diagnosis of chronic sinusitis is made.

Which of the following complications of sinusitis is characterized by cystic transformation of the maxillary sinus mucosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Mucocoele 

  • Mucocoele is a local complication of sinusitis characterized by cystic transformation of the maxillary sinus mucosa.
  • When the sinus ostium is obstructed, mucus accumulates in the sinus, leading to the formation of an epithelial-lined sac called a mucocoele.
  • Over time, the mucocoele gradually expands, causing thinning and destruction of the overlying bone.
  • If the mucocoele becomes infected, it is called a pyocoele.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Preseptal cellulitis:

  • Preseptal cellulitis is an orbital complication of sinusitis.
  • It is characterized by cellulitis of the skin and subcutaneous tissue anterior to the orbital septum.
  • It presents with eyelid edema, erythema, and tenderness but does not involve the globe or orbital contents.

Option B - Osteomyelitis:

  • Osteomyelitis is another local complication of sinusitis, but it refers to the infection and inflammation of the overlying bone.
  • It occurs when the infection spreads from the sinus to the surrounding bone, leading to bone destruction.
  • It can cause severe pain and swelling, often accompanied by fever.

Option D - Orbital abscess:

  • Orbital abscess is an orbital complication of sinusitis.
  • It refers to a collection of pus within the orbit.
  • It presents with severe orbital pain, proptosis (bulging of the eye), ophthalmoplegia (eye movement restriction), and impaired vision.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, crushing chest pain radiating to the left jaw that started 2 hours ago. ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V2-V6. He undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention and is started on antiplatelet and antithrombotic medications. Three weeks later, he returned with chest pain and a friction rub on auscultation. What is the pathogenesis of the problem that has arisen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Autoimmunity:

  • The constellation of symptoms in this patient is consistent with Dressler syndrome (post-MI pericarditis)
  • Dressler syndrome is a delayed autoimmune-mediated inflammatory response that occurs several weeks after an acute myocardial infarction (MI). It is characterized by inflammation of the pericardium, which can lead to chest pain and a friction rub heard on auscultation.
  • The immune system mistakenly targets healthy cardiac tissue, causing inflammation and the characteristic symptoms associated with Dressler syndrome.

Post-MI Complication

Time Frame

Arrhythmias

Hours to days

Heart Failure

Hours to days

Cardiogenic Shock

Hours

Ventricular Septal Rupture

Days

Papillary Muscle Rupture

Days

Free Wall Rupture

Days

Dressler Syndrome

Weeks

Thromboembolism

Days to weeks

Ventricular Aneurysm

Days to weeks

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infection: While infections can lead to inflammation of the pericardium (pericarditis), the timing and clinical presentation described in the case scenario are more indicative of Dressler syndrome

Option C - Infarction: The patient's initial presentation was of infarction event. However, the problem that has arisen during the follow-up visit, characterized by chest pain and a friction rub, is not due to a new infarction. It is more consistent with Dressler syndrome

Option D - Adverse Drug Reaction: While adverse drug reactions are always possible, there is no evidence or indication in the case scenario to suggest that the patient's current symptoms of chest pain and a friction rub are due to an adverse drug reaction. The patient's symptoms are more in line with Dressler syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the major Modified Duke Criteria in infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Transthoracic echocardiography is better than Transesophageal echocardiography
Coxiella requires only single positive culture for diagnosis
New onset murmur in previously healthy person with no heart lesions
Janeways lesion and roth spots are included in major criteria

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Coxiella requires only a single positive vulture for diagnosis:

  • This statement is CORRECT. Coxiella burnetii, which is the causative agent of Q fever endocarditis, requires only a single positive blood culture for diagnosis. In the context of the Modified Duke's Criteria, only one positive blood culture is typically required for diagnosing infective endocarditis in case of Coxiella

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Transthoracic echocardiography is better than Transesophageal echocardiography: This statement is INCORRECT. In diagnosing infective endocarditis, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is generally considered superior to transthoracic echocardiography (TTE). TEE provides more detailed and sensitive images of cardiac structures, making it more valuable in detecting endocardial involvement, valvular lesions, and the presence of vegetation. Therefore, TEE is the preferred imaging modality for diagnosing infective endocarditis in many cases.

Option C - New onset murmur in previously healthy person with no heart lesions: This statement is INCORRECT. A new onset murmur in a previously healthy individual without underlying heart lesions is NOT considered a major criterion for diagnosing infective endocarditis according to the Modified Duke's Criteria. Major criteria generally includes new onset murmur in patient with pre-existing heart lesion

Option D - Janeway's lesion and Roth spots are included in major criteria: This statement is INCORRECT. Janeway's lesions (small, painless, red macules on the palms and soles) and Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages with a pale center) are not included as major criteria in the Modified Duke's Criteria for diagnosing infective endocarditis. These cutaneous and ophthalmic findings can be indicative of the disease when combined with other clinical and microbiological criteria.

questions.text: A 51-year old male presents to the surgery department with complaints of cloudy discharge associated with burning micturition for the last week. He has a smoking history of 20-pack years. His is posted for a specific test to rule out the cause. The test in the image is done in which shreds are present only in the first glass. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Urethritis:

  • The patient discussed above suffers from urethritis, and the image shown is three glass tests. Urethritis is inflammation of the urethra.
  • It is usually caused by an infection
  • The term non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is used when the sexually transmitted infection is not caused by N.gonorrhoea.

  • The image shown in the question is a procedure of the three-glass test:
    • A three-glass test is a procedure to determine the location of an infection affecting the urinary system of a male.
    • The bladder is emptied by passing urine into a series of 3-ounce test tubes, and the contents of the first and the last are examined;
    • The first tube contains the washings from the anterior urethra,
    • The second material is from the bladder, and
    • The last material is from the posterior urethra, prostate, and seminal vesicles.
    • If flakes or threads of pus are passed in the urine, their source is usually urethral.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prostatitis:

  • Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland.
  • In three glass tests, material from the posterior urethra, prostate, and seminal vesicles would be visible on the third glass.

Option B - Cystitis:

  • Cystitis is the inflammation of the urinary bladder.
  • In three glass tests, the material from the bladder could be seen on the second glass.

Option D - Renal pathology:

  • Renal pathology does not appear on three glass tests.

questions.text: How much should be Chandler’s index for considering hookworm to be a minor public health problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 250-300 Eggs/GM of stool:

  • Chandler’s index: Identifies the importance of Hookworm infestation as a public health problem in community
  • Chandler’s index is 250-300 eggs/gm of stool to consider hookworm infection to be a minor public health problem.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - < 200 Eggs/GM of stool:

  • Hookworm infection is not significant when the Chandler’s index is < 200 Eggs/gm of stool

Option B - 200-250 eggs/GM of stool:

  • Hookworm infection is a potential danger when Chandler's index is between 200-250 eggs/gm of stool

Option D - > 300 eggs/GM of stool:

  • Hookworm infection is a major public health problem when Chandler’s index is > 300 eggs/gm of stool

questions.text: An 11-month-old infant was brought by his mother to OPD. He was born preterm and was underweight. His mother is worried about the growth and development of his son. She says that her son cannot hold his neck and cannot sit without support. Physical examination revealed that her son is below the 50th percentile for weight and height. He has a small jaw. Physical examination reveals clenched fists and index finger overlapping the other digits. His head circumference is 38 cm (N=43 and 45 cm). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Edward syndrome

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a classic case of Edward syndrome.
  • It is caused by chromosomal non-disjunction resulting in 3 copies of chromosome no. 18 
  • Clinical findings in Edward syndrome:
    • Low birth weight
    • Small head (microcephaly) and jaw (micrognathia)
    • An unusual-looking face and head
    • Low set of ears
    • Unusual hands and feet with overlapping fingers and webbed toes
    • Problems with feeding, breathing, seeing and hearing
    • Congenital abnormalities of the heart and lungs                                                                                                                                            

Option B: Maternal smoking

  • Maternal smoking is toxic to infants and can cause microcephaly
  • However, smoking is unlikely to cause other findings like overlapping fingers and facial features in this patient.

Option C: Angelman syndrome

  • It is a defect of gene silencing.
  • It is characterised by seizures, ataxia, mental retardation, and inappropriate laughter (happy puppets)

Option D: Glutaric aciduria type 1

  • Glutaryl aciduria type 1 is a rare metabolic disorder caused by a defect in the glutaryl CoA enzyme
  • It is autosomal recessive
  • It is associated with abnormally large head size
  • Onset is in the first 18-36 months of life
  • Treatment includes a low-protein diet.

questions.text: In a rural area, a program has been initiated to train birth attendants to improve maternal and neonatal health outcomes. As part of the training criteria, a set of requirements are established. Which of the following statements about the trained birth attendants in rural areas is FALSE?

choices.text: One trained birth attendant for every 1000 population
Completion of a one-month training program
Conducting a minimum of two supervised deliveries during the training period

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - At least 6th pass:

  • An extensive program has been undertaken under the Rural Health Scheme to train all categories of local dais (traditional birth attendants).
  • The emphasis during training is on asepsis so that home deliveries are conducted safely in hygienic conditions reducing maternal and neonatal mortality.
  • After successfully completing training, a certificate is provided along with a delivery kit.
  • No educational qualifications are required to acquire this training.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - One trained birth attendant for every 1000 population:

  • It indicates the recommended ratio of trained birth attendants to the population, ensuring adequate coverage for maternal and neonatal care in rural areas.
  • These birth attendants are expected to play a vital role in propagating small family norms since they are more acceptable to the community.

Option C - Completion of a one-month training program:

  • It outlines the duration of the training program required for individuals to become trained birth attendants, providing them with the necessary knowledge and skills to assist in childbirth safely.
  • Training is given at the PHC, or Sub-center for 2 days a week, and on the remaining 4 days of the week, they accompany the HWF to the villages.

Option D - Conducting a minimum of two supervised deliveries during the training period:

  • The minimum number of supervised deliveries required during training is two.
  • Conducting a higher number of supervised deliveries ensures that birth attendants gain sufficient practical experience and competency in managing childbirth complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents to the ENT clinic with a complaint of hearing loss and recurrent ear infections. Upon examination, you notice a perforation in the tympanic membrane. As you assess the characteristics of the perforation, you recall the different types of tympanic membrane perforations. Based on the provided information, answer the following question: What type of perforation involves all the quadrants of the pars tensa, but the annulus is intact?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Subtotal perforation

  • A subtotal perforation is a perforation that involves all the quadrants of the pars tensa, but the annulus remains intact.
  • In other words, it extends throughout the entire tense part of the tympanic membrane but does not disrupt the fibrous cartilaginous ring surrounding the membrane.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central perforation:

  • A central perforation refers to a tympanic membrane perforation that occurs in the pars tensa, which is the tense and tight part of the membrane. This type of perforation typically occurs in the central area of the membrane and does not involve the annulus.

Option B - Attic perforation:

  • An attic perforation is a perforation that specifically involves the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. The pars flaccida is the upper portion of the membrane, and unlike the pars tensa, it does not have an annulus.
  • Attic perforations are typically located in the upper part of the tympanic membrane near the superior part of the malleus handle.

Option C - Small central perforation:

  • A small central perforation is a perforation that involves only one quadrant of the pars tensa. It is limited to a specific area within the central portion of the membrane and does not extend to all the quadrants.

questions.text: In a community of 17,000 individuals, the number of new cases of diabetes is 350; existing cases in the same community are 200. What is the prevalence of diabetes in this community?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3%:

  • Prevalence is the total number of all individuals who suffer from a disease at a single point in time.
  • Total population = 17,000
  • New cases = 350
  • Existing cases = 200
  • Total cases = 550
  • Prevalence = (Total cases / Total population) × 100 = (350 + 200) / 17,000 × 100 = 550 / 17,000 × 100 = 3.23%

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 1%

Option B - 2%

Option D - 4%

questions.text: What is the minimum duration required between episodes to diagnose Recurrent Depressive Disorder?

choices.text: Minimum duration of 2 weeks between episodes.
Minimum duration of 1 month between episodes.
Minimum duration of 2 months between episodes.
Minimum duration of 6 months between episodes.

questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Minimum duration of 2 months between episodes.

  • To diagnose Recurrent Depressive Disorder, there must be a minimum duration of 2 months between each episode of depression. 

  • Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Major Depressive Episodes: Presence of at least two separate major depressive episodes.
  • Duration of Episodes: Each episode lasts for a defined period, typically two weeks or more.
  • Inter-Episode Interval: A minimum of 2 months without significant depressive symptoms between episodes.

  • Clinical Presentation:

  • During episodes: Depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure, changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulty concentrating, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide.
  • Between episodes: Individuals may experience a return to their baseline level of functioning, with a notable reduction in depressive symptoms.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with bone pain in his lower extremities. He has had a history of difficulty in the vision for 2 months. He was also admitted two times in hospital for bacterial infections last year. On physical examination, hepatosplenomegaly is also present. Laboratory values are given:

Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 85 μm3

White blood cell (WBC) count: 3000/mm3

Reticulocyte count: 0.3%

X-ray of his lower limbs done as a part of a skeletal survey shows the following picture:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Osteopetrosis

  • X-ray: Dense bones, with no visible marrow cavity, are diagnostic of osteopetrosis.
  • Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease:
    • Bone within bone appearance.
    • Due to mutation in CLCN7 gene → Leads to defective bone resorption
  • CLINICAL FEATURES:
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g. vision loss) due to increased thickness of skull foramina.
    • Pancytopenia due to loss of bone marrow.
    • Risk of severe infections due to decreased WBC
    • Macrocephaly, deafness.
    • Extramedullary hematopoiesis leading to hepatosplenomegaly.
  •  Investigation: Phosphorus and calcium levels are mostly normal, with normal Vitamin D and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

Option A: Scurvy

  • Painful pseudoparalysis (crying on touch), Gum bleeding.
  • Petechiae, scorbutic rosary (sharp, angular, painful and tender deformity).
  • Swelling of long bones, joint effusions.
  • X-ray: – pencil-thin outline of the cortex, Subperiosteal haemorrhages, Wimberger sign, Pelkin spur, Trummerfeld zone

Option B: Achondroplasia

  • A – Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • C – Champagne glass pelvis
  • H – Hand abnormality (Trident hands)
  • O – Obesity
  • N – Neurological problems
  • D – Delayed motor milestones
  • R – Recognised at birth
  • O – Bowing of legs
  • P – Proximal limb shortening
  • L – Large head
  • S – Short stature (short limb dwarfism)
  • I – Interpedicular distance between vertebrae is decreased

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta

  • Bony deformities, blue sclera, deafness, and Dentinogenesis imperfecta are typical features of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct representation of the Lactose Operon in E. coli?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - d:

  • E. coli's lac operon regulates lactose metabolism and is expressed only when lactose is present and glucose is absent.
  • Regulation involves the lac repressor and catabolite activator protein (CAP).
  • The CAP-cAMP complex binds to the CAP site, while the lac repressor tetramer complex binds to the operator site.
  • In the presence of lactose, the lac repressor ceases repression, allowing transcription.
  • Allolactose, an isomer of lactose, indirectly triggers this response.
  • Catabolite activator protein, often known as CAP detects low glucose levels through cAMP.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: Refer to the explanation of D

questions.text: Which among the following is not attached to the Deltoid ligament?
questions.solution:
Option D: Medial cuneiform

  • The deltoid ligament is also known as the medial ligament of the talocrural joint. It is a strong, flat triangular band of ligament. Tibionavicular ligament, tibiocalcaneal ligament, tibiotalar ligament. 
  • It is also attached to the medial side of the talus, the sustentaculum tali, the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, and the tuberosity of the navicular bone
  • The Deltoid ligament does not connect to the medial cuneiform.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Sustentaculum tali

  • Tibiocalcaneal fibers of the deltoid ligament descend almost vertically to the entire length of sustentaculum tali.

Option B: Spring ligament

  • The plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, called spring ligament, is a broad, thick band connecting the anterior margin of sustentacular tali to the plantar surface of the navicular bone.
  • Tibionavicular fibers of the deltoid ligament pass anteriorly to navicular tuberosity, which blends with the medial margin of the spring ligament.

Option C: Medial malleolus

  • The deltoid ligament forms the triangle, connecting the tibia to the navicular, calcaneus, and talus. It is also attached to the medial malleolus's apex and anterior and posterior borders.

questions.text:
Diagnostic Criteria for Smouldering Myeloma include all of the following Except?


	Plasma cells in bone marrow: >10%.
	M-component: >30 g/L.
	No evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.
	Evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.
	Plasma cells in peripheral blood - >2,000/µL.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 4,5:

  • Evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient is diagnostic criteria for Multiple Myeloma not Smouldering Myeloma
  • Plasma cells in peripheral blood - >2,000/µL is Diagnostic Criteria for Plasma Cell leukemia

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, D:

  • The diagnostic criteria for Smouldering Myeloma is
  • Plasma cells in bone marrow: >10%.
  • M-component: >30 g/L.
  • No evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.

questions.text:
Identify the fracture in the X-ray and mark the option with the right statements.



a) Piedmont fracture is another name for this condition

b) Galeazzi sign is seen in the above X-ray

c) Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon entrapment is common

d) ORIF with long plates and screws is the treatment of choice

e) Piano key sign is a classical sign

f)Monteggia fracture is more common than this fracture
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - a,d,e:

  • The X-ray shows fracture of lower-third of radius indicating a Galeazzi fracture
  • a) Piedmont fracture is another name for this condition
  • d) ORIF with long plates and screws is the treatment of choice
  • e) Piano key sign is a classical sign

Incorrect Options:

Option A - b,c,f:

  • The X-ray shows Galeazzi fracture and not Galeazzi sign. Galeazzi sign is found in DDH(ALLIS TEST).These two are completely different entities.
  • Entrapment of extensor carpi ulnaris tendon is rare.
  • Galeazzi fracture is more common than Monteggia fracture.

Option C - a,b,f: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

Option D - b,d,e: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is admitted to the surgical ward for a total thyroidectomy under anaesthesia. Her medical history is consistent with diabetes mellitus, hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her medications include aspirin, metformin, amlodipine and valsartan. Transthoracic echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 40% and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following inhalational anaesthetic agent to be avoided in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Halothane:

  • Halothane is a direct myocardial depressant.
  • Halothane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, and Sevoflurane produce similar and dose-dependent decreases in mean arterial pressure.
  • But Halothane decreases blood pressure due to the decrease in myocardial contractility and cardiac output, whereas others decrease by lowering systemic vascular resistance.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane increase heart rate.
  • Halothane causes an unchanged heart rate despite a decrease in blood pressure due to depression of the carotid sinus (baroreceptor reflex response) and drug-induced decreases in the rate of sinus node depolarization.
  • Junctional rhythm with the decrease in blood pressure reflects suppression of sinus node activity by Halothane.
  • It also decreases the speed of conduction of impulses through the AV node and His-Purkinje system.
  • Also sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine and is contraindicated in pheochromocytoma.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane do not have much effect on the cardiac output as increased heart rate tends to offset the drug-induced decrease in cardiac output but not with Halothane is no change in heart rate.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Isoflurane:

  • Isoflurane does not affect cardiac output as much as Halothane does.

Option C - Sevoflurane:

  • Sevoflurane's cardio-depressant effect is very little.
  • Halothane has the maximum and direct cardio-depressant effect.

Option D - Desflurane:

  • Desflurane increases heart rate.
  • It does not cause cardiac depression

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the gynaecologist with complaints of being unable to conceive for 2 years. She is diagnosed to have anovulatory cycles. She is started on a drug that acts by antagonizing estrogenic negative feedback on the hypothalamus. She is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is true about the drug involved in a patient's pathology?

choices.text: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men
1 – 2% increase in the rate of twin pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option A: Increases production of FSH

  • This is a case of anovulatory cycles.
  • Clomiphene citrate is used to cause ovulation
    • Trans enclomiphene 62%: anti-estrogenic
    • Cis zuclomiphene citrate 38%: mildly estrogenic
  • This primarily acts at the receptor in the hypothalamus rather than the ovarian and pituitary axis. Blockade increases the stimulus to the pituitary to produce more FSH.
  • Antagonises the beneficial actions of estrogens on the endometrium, and hence a supplementation of estrogen is required in patients on higher doses of clomiphene for ovulation induction
  • 6-12% increase in the rate of twins
  • Oligospermia relief is not the best benefit of clomiphene…statistically because roughly 10-15% only are benefited from this in oligospermia reversal.

Option B: Increases endometrial thickness

  • It doesn't play any role in increasing the endometrial thickness because it antagonizes the action of estrogens on the endometrium and causes endometrial thinning instead.

Option C: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men

  • It is ineffective in oligospermic men because only 10 to 15 % of patients benefit from this drug in oligospermic reversal.

Option D: 1-2% increase in the rate of twin pregnancy

  • It has a 6 to 12% increase in the twin pregnancy rate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the hospital complaining of fever, nausea, pain, and itching in the perineal region. On examination by a urologist, he is diagnosed as having infected bulbourethral (Cowper's) glands. He also finds that the infection has affected another thing as well. Which of the following is affected by this infection apart from the bulbourethral glands?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sphincter urethrae

  • The bulbourethral glands are present in the deep perineal space of the urogenital triangle.
  • Apart from the bulbourethral glands, the deep perineal space also contains the membranous urethra, sphincter urethrae, and deep transverse perineal muscles.
  • The bulbourethral glands are located on either side of the membranous urethra, embedded in the sphincter urethrae.

  • Their ducts open into the bulbous part of the penile urethra. If the infection affects the bulbourethral glands, it would also affect the sphincter urethrae as the bulbourethral glands are embedded in the sphincter urethrae.

Option A: Superficial perineal space

  • The bulbourethral gland does not lie in the superficial perineal space.
  • It lies in the deep perineal space.
  • So, an infection of the bulbourethral gland cannot affect the superficial perineal space.

Option B: Production of sperm

  • The sperm or spermatozoa are produced in seminiferous tubules of the testis and matured in the head of the epididymis.
  • So, the infection of the bulbourethral glands cannot affect the production of the sperms.

Option D: Seminal vesicles

  • The seminal vesicles are lobulated glandular structures, produce the alkaline constituent of seminal fluid that contains fructose and choline, and lie inferior and lateral to ampullae of ductus deferens against the fundus (base) of the bladder.
  • So, the infection of the bulbourethral glands cannot affect the seminal vesicles.
